The thimble scale has its 35th mark aligned with the main line. Therefore, the reading for A is 3.0 mm + (35 * 0.01 mm) = 3.35 mm. context_text: The speed-time graphs for Car A and Car B are plotted on Figure 1.2 based on the data in Figure 1.1. For Car A, the speed increases linearly from 0 m/s to 60 m/s over 15 seconds, and then remains constant at 60 m/s from 15 seconds to 30 seconds. For Car B, the speed increases linearly from 0 m/s to 60 m/s over 30 seconds.
question_text: At the end of 30.0 s, calculate the distance between the two cars.
answer_text: Distance covered by Car A = Area under Car A's speed-time graph = (½ × 15 × 60) + (15 × 60) = 450 m + 900 m = 1350 m. Distance covered by Car B = Area under Car B's speed-time graph = ½ × 30 × 60 = 900 m. Distance between the cars = Distance A - Distance B = 1350 m - 900 m = 450 m. [2 marks]

context_text: Figure 3.1 shows a car moving forward. The car has a mass of 1000 kg. At three different times (X, Y, Z), two horizontal forces are shown acting on the car: a forward force and a backward force. The 'direction of motion' is indicated as forward (to the right).

context_text: Figure 5.1 shows the main parts of an electric grill. It consists of a heating element, shiny material, an outer metal case, and food placed under the heating element. The heating element becomes red hot and emits visible light and infrared radiation. The infrared radiation is used to cook the food. There is a physical gap between the heating element and the food.
question_text: Explain why heat cannot be transferred by conduction from the heating element to the food.
answer_text: Air particles are very far apart. Energy cannot be transferred from particle to particle. [2 marks]

context_text: Figure 5.1 shows an electric grill with a heating element above the food. The heating element becomes red hot. The infrared radiation is used to cook the food. Heat transfer through convection involves the movement of fluid (liquid or gas).
question_text: Explain why heat cannot be transferred by convection from the heating element to the food.
answer_text: When the air around the heating element is heated, it becomes less dense. It rises and does not sink to the food. [2 marks]

context_text: Figure 5.1 shows an electric grill. There is a layer of shiny material between the heating element and the outer case on top of the grill.

answer_text: The shiny material is a poor absorber of infrared radiation. So, less heat is lost. [2 marks]

context_text: Figure 6.1 shows a man P standing some distance from a vertical wall. A second man Q is located 200 m behind P. question_text: If Q hears the first sound 0.625 s after P fires the gun, calculate the speed of sound in air.
answer_text: speed = distance travelled / time taken = 200 m / 0.625 s = 320 m/s. [1 mark]

context_text: Figure 10.1 shows a manual car park barrier, which is a beam pivoted at a point. The beam is horizontal. To the left of the pivot, at a distance of 0.5 m, a downward force of 2000 N is applied. The weight of the barrier beam itself is 550 N, acting downwards at its center of gravity, which is located 1.6 m to the right of the pivot. A rope is attached to the right end of the beam, at a distance of (1.6 m + 1.4 m) = 3.0 m from the pivot. This rope exerts an upward tension force (T) to keep the beam horizontal.
question_text: The weight of the barrier beam is 550 N and acts at 1.6 m to the right of the pivot. Calculate the tension needed in the rope in order to keep the beam horizontal.
answer_text: Anticlockwise moments = clockwise moments. (2000)(0.5) = T(3.0) + (550)(1.6). 1000 = 3.0 T + 880. T = 40 N. [3 marks]

context_text: From part (a), the barrier beam is balanced horizontally by an anticlockwise moment of 1000 Nm (from 2000 N force) and two clockwise moments: 880 Nm (from beam weight) and 120 Nm (from rope tension).
question_text: Describe and explain what will happen if the rope is suddenly detached from the metal ring.
answer_text: If the rope is suddenly detached, the anticlockwise moment is greater than clockwise moment. The barrier will turn anticlockwise. [2 marks]

context_text: Figure 10.2 shows two cones, Cone X and Cone Y, made of wood and metal. Cone X has a metal base and a wood top. Cone Y has a wood base and a metal top. Figure 10.3 shows these cones tilted by a force. The center of gravity (CG) of an object is where its weight effectively acts. For a composite object, the CG is closer to the denser material.
question_text: In Fig. 10.3, mark a possible position for the centre of gravity by 'x' and draw an arrow to show the weight for both cone X and cone Y.
answer_text: For Cone X (metal base, wood top), the centre of gravity ('x') should be located low, closer to the metal base. An arrow pointing vertically downwards from 'x' should be drawn to represent its weight. For Cone Y (wood base, metal top), the centre of gravity ('x') should be located high, closer to the metal top. An arrow pointing vertically downwards from 'x' should be drawn to represent its weight. [1 mark: 1/2 mark for each cone, correctly marking CG with 'x' and drawing a downward arrow for weight]

context_text: From part (c), Cone X has its center of gravity (CG) located low, closer to its metal base. Figure 10.3 shows Cone X tilted by a force.
question_text: Using your answer for (c), explain why cone X is in a state of stable equilibrium.
answer_text: When the force is released, the weight that acts on a lower centre of gravity falls within the base. An anticlockwise turning effect will bring it back to its original position. [2 marks]

context_text: From part (c), Cone Y has its center of gravity (CG) located high, closer to its metal top. Figure 10.3 shows Cone Y tilted by a force.
question_text: Using your answer for (c), explain why cone Y is in a state of unstable equilibrium.
answer_text: When the force is released, the weight that acts on a higher centre of gravity will fall outside the base. A clockwise turning effect that will topple it. [2 marks]

context_text: Figure 11.1 shows a ray of light traveling from air into a rectangular glass block (ABCD). The ray enters the block from air at surface AB. The angle of refraction (r) inside the glass block, measured from the normal, is 25°. The refractive index of glass is given as 1.58.
question_text: Given that the refractive index is 1.58, calculate the angle of incidence, i.

context_text: Figure 11.1 shows a ray of light entering a rectangular glass block from air at surface AB with an angle of incidence i = 41.9° and refracting to an angle r = 25°. This refracted ray then travels through the glass block and hits the opposite parallel surface CD. Since the glass block is rectangular and the initial refraction angle was 25°, the ray hits the surface CD at an angle of incidence of 25° (measured from the normal to CD).
question_text: In Fig. 11.1, draw how the ray emerges from the side CD.
answer_text: The ray should emerge from the side CD, refracting away from the normal with an angle of emergence of 41.9°. [1 mark]

context_text: Figure 11.2 shows the ray of light entering the same glass block (rectangular ABCD) from air. The incident ray and refracted ray inside the block are shown. This ray then travels through the glass block and strikes the internal surface BC. The angle of incidence at surface BC (measured from the normal to BC) is shown to be greater than the critical angle, as the ray is reflected internally within the glass block. Given the initial angle of refraction was 25 degrees, the angle of incidence at BC would be 90 - 25 = 65 degrees. The critical angle for glass (n=1.58) to air is arcsin(1/1.58) which is approximately 39.3 degrees.
question_text: State and explain what has happened to the ray at side BC.
answer_text: The ray undergoes total internal reflection. The angle of incidence must be greater than the critical angle. [2 marks]

context_text: Figure 12.1 shows a circuit with 3 identical resistors R1, R2 and R3, each with a resistance of 20 Ω. There is also a lamp with a resistance of 10 Ω. A 12 V battery is connected to the circuit. Switches S1 and S2 are present. For this part (a), both switches S1 and S2 are left open. When both switches are open, the circuit consists of the 12 V battery, resistor R1 (20 Ω), and the lamp (10 Ω) connected in series, as implied by the problem statement for part (a).
question_text: When both switches are left open, the current flows through R1 and the lamp only. Calculate the current through the resistor R1 and the lamp.
answer_text: Current = V / R = 12 V / (10 + 20) = 0.4 A. [2 marks]

context_text: From part (a)(i), when switches S1 and S2 are open, the current through the lamp is 0.4 A. The resistance of the lamp is 10 Ω.
question_text: Calculate the power of the lamp.
answer_text: Power = Current² x R = 0.4² x 10 = 1.6 W. [2 marks]

context_text: Figure 12.1 shows a circuit with 3 identical resistors R1, R2 and R3, each with a resistance of 20 Ω. There is also a lamp with a resistance of 10 Ω. A 12 V battery is connected to the circuit. In this part (b), switch S1 is closed (S2 remains open). The problem states that when S1 is closed, R1 and R2 are connected in parallel.
question_text: When switch S1 is closed, R1 and R2 are connected in parallel. Calculate the effective resistance of R1 and R2.
answer_text: R_effective = (1/20 + 1/20)⁻¹ = 10 Ω. [2 marks]

context_text: A vernier scale is shown. The main scale has markings at 6 cm and 7 cm, with 10 divisions between them, meaning each main scale division is 0.1 cm. The main scale reading aligns just past the 6.5 cm mark. The vernier scale has 10 divisions, and the 5th division on the vernier scale aligns perfectly with a main scale marking.

What is the reading on the vernier scale?
A 6.50 cm
B 6.55 cm

answer_text: B. The main scale reading is 6.5 cm. The coinciding vernier scale division is the 5th mark. With a least count of 0.01 cm, the vernier scale reading is 5 * 0.01 cm = 0.05 cm. The total reading is 6.5 cm + 0.05 cm = 6.55 cm.

context_text: A moon rover has a mass of 15 kg on Earth. The gravitational field strength on Earth is 10 N/kg, and on the Moon, it is 1.6 N/kg. The mass of an object is an intrinsic property and does not change with gravitational field strength, while weight is the force of gravity acting on an object.
question_text:
What are the mass and weight of the moon rover on the Moon?

mass / kg
weight / N
A 15 24
B 15 150
C 24 15
D 24 150
answer_text: A. The mass of the moon rover remains constant at 15 kg, regardless of its location. The weight of the moon rover on the Moon is calculated as mass × gravitational field strength on Moon = 15 kg × 1.6 N/kg = 24 N.

context_text: Three objects—a hexagon, a trapezoid, and a triangle—are cut from the same sheet of metal. This means they are all made of the same material. They all have the same mass. Density is an intensive property of a material, meaning it depends only on the material's composition, not on its size or shape.
question_text:
Which object has the greatest density?
A the hexagon
B the trapezoid
C the triangle
D all have the same density
answer_text: D. Since all three objects are cut from the same sheet of metal, they are made of the same material. Therefore, they will all have the same density, as density is a property of the material itself.

context_text: Electromagnetic waves encompass a spectrum of different types, including gamma rays, X-rays, ultraviolet rays, visible light, infrared, microwaves, and radio waves. All electromagnetic waves travel at a specific speed in a vacuum.
question_text:
Which electromagnetic wave travels at the highest speed through a vacuum?
A gamma rays
B microwaves
C ultraviolet rays
D All electromagnetic waves travel at the same speed through a vacuum.
answer_text: D. All electromagnetic waves, regardless of their frequency or wavelength (e.g., gamma rays, microwaves, ultraviolet rays), travel at the same speed in a vacuum, which is the speed of light (approximately 3 x 10^8 m/s).

context_text: Four objects, P, Q, R and S, are arranged in a line and in contact. Arrows indicate the direction of thermal energy travel between them. An arrow from Q points to P, indicating Q is hotter than P (T_Q > T_P). An arrow from R points to Q, indicating R is hotter than Q (T_R > T_Q). An arrow from S points to R, indicating S is hotter than R (T_S > T_R). This establishes a temperature order of S > R > Q > P.
question_text:
Which statement about the temperatures of the objects is correct?
A P is colder than Q and R.
B Q is hotter than R but colder than P.
C R is the hottest object.
D S and R have the same temperature.
answer_text: B. Based on the provided answer key, this option is stated as correct. However, standard interpretation of heat flow (hotter to colder) from the diagram's arrows (S>R>Q>P) would make option A correct. If Q is hotter than R (T_Q > T_R), this contradicts the arrow from R to Q. If Q is colder than P (T_Q < T_P), this contradicts the arrow from Q to P. There appears to be a discrepancy between the diagram's arrows and the provided answer choice.

context_text: A diagram shows three rays of light (X, Y, Z) from a point P passing through a converging lens. Each point labeled F represents a principal focus of the lens. According to standard ray tracing rules for a converging lens: 1. A ray parallel to the principal axis passes through the focal point (F) after refraction. 2. A ray passing through the focal point (F) emerges parallel to the principal axis after refraction. 3. A ray passing through the optical center of the lens goes undeviated. Ray X is shown parallel to the principal axis and then passing through F on the right. Ray Z is shown passing through F on the left and then emerging parallel to the principal axis. Ray Y is shown passing through the optical center, but visually appears to have a slight upward deviation.
question_text:
Which of the rays are drawn correctly?
A ray Y only
B ray Z only
C rays X and Y
D rays X and Z
answer_text: C. Based on the provided answer key, rays X and Y are considered correctly drawn. Ray X (parallel to principal axis, then through F) is drawn correctly. Ray Y is intended to represent a ray passing through the optical center, which should be undeviated, although the diagram shows a slight visual deviation. Ray Z (through F, then parallel to principal axis) is also correctly drawn based on standard optics, suggesting a potential ambiguity or error in the question's options or designated correct answer.

context_text: Two light, charged balls, P and Q, are suspended. A negatively charged plastic sheet is placed near them. Ball P is repelled by the negative sheet, and ball Q is attracted to the negative sheet. Like charges repel, and opposite charges attract. Additionally, a charged object can attract a neutral object through electrostatic induction.
question_text:
What are the original charges on P and Q?

charge on P
charge on Q
A negative negative
B negative positive
C positive negative
D positive positive
answer_text: B. Since ball P is repelled by the negatively charged plastic sheet, ball P must also be negatively charged (like charges repel). Since ball Q is attracted by the negatively charged plastic sheet, ball Q must be positively charged (opposite charges attract). While an uncharged object can also be attracted, among the given options, 'positive' is the most direct opposite charge.

context_text: A diagram displays electric field lines between two isolated point charges. The field lines originate from the left charge and terminate on the right charge. Electric field lines conventionally originate from positive charges and terminate on negative charges.
question_text:
Which two point charges produce this pattern?
A [Two positive charges]
B [A positive and a negative charge]
C [Two negative charges]
D [A positive and a negative charge (same as B)]
answer_text: B. Electric field lines point away from positive charges and towards negative charges. In the given pattern, the field lines originate from the left charge and end on the right charge. Therefore, the left charge is positive, and the right charge is negative.

context_text: A circuit contains a battery, a first ammeter (reading 1.0 A), and several resistors including a series resistor 'A' and three parallel branches labeled B, C, D (these labels refer to specific resistors within the parallel branches). The first ammeter is positioned in the main circuit path before any branches. If a second ammeter connected elsewhere in the circuit also reads 1.0 A, it must be measuring the total current.
question_text: The reading of the ammeter in the circuit is 1.0 A. When a second ammeter is connected to the circuit, it also reads 1.0 A. At which point, A, B, C or D is the second ammeter connected?
answer_text: D. The first ammeter reads the total current of 1.0 A. If a second ammeter also reads 1.0 A, it must be located in the main circuit path, where the total current flows. In the provided diagram, points A, B, and C are within individual parallel branches, so an ammeter there would measure only a fraction of the total current. Point D is located in the main circuit path, after the parallel branches recombine but before returning to the battery, hence an ammeter placed at D would measure the total current of 1.0 A.

context_text: Four circuit diagrams (A, B, C, D) are provided, each intended to show three lamps connected in parallel, controlled by a single switch. A parallel circuit for lamps means each lamp has its own separate path across the power supply. A single switch controlling all three lamps implies the switch is in the main circuit path.

B [Switch in series with three lamps connected in series.]

answer_text: D. Based on the provided answer key, diagram D is considered correct. However, standard circuit diagram interpretation defines 'three lamps connected in parallel' as each lamp being on its own branch directly across the power supply, which is accurately represented by diagram C. Diagram D shows a switch in the main line, then one lamp in parallel with a series combination of two other lamps, which is not a direct 'three lamps in parallel' configuration.

context_text: A rod is tested with a bar magnet. In position 1, the N-pole of a bar magnet picks up one end of the rod. In position 2, the same end (P) of the rod picks up an S-pole of a bar magnet. 'Picks up' indicates attraction. Magnetic materials (like iron and steel) are attracted to both poles of a magnet. Soft magnetic materials (like iron) are easily magnetized and demagnetized, while hard magnetic materials (like steel) retain magnetism strongly.
question_text:
Which material is the rod made from and what is the pole at end P of the rod when in position 2?

material
pole at P
A iron N - pole
B iron S - pole
C steel N - pole
D steel S - pole
answer_text: A. The rod attracts both the N-pole (in position 1) and the S-pole (in position 2) at the same end P by inducing an opposite pole. This behavior is characteristic of a soft magnetic material, such as iron, which can be easily magnetized and demagnetized. When the S-pole of the bar magnet is brought near end P in position 2, an N-pole is induced at end P to cause attraction.

context_text: A current-carrying wire is placed between the poles of a horse-shoe magnet, experiencing a force due to the motor effect (Fleming's Left-Hand Rule). In the original arrangement, the current flows from left to right, and the magnetic field goes from the N-pole (top) to the S-pole (bottom), producing a force out of the plane of the diagram. Three other arrangements (P, Q, R) alter the current direction and/or magnet orientation.
question_text:
Which arrangement(s) will produce a force in the same direction as the original arrangement?
A P only
B R only
C P and Q only
D P, Q and R
answer_text:
B. Applying Fleming's Left-Hand Rule to each arrangement:
Original: Current (right), Field (down) -> Force (out of page).
P: Magnet turned (S-top, N-bottom), so Field (up). Current (right) -> Force (into page, opposite).
Q: Current reversed (left). Magnet same (N-top, S-bottom), so Field (down) -> Force (into page, opposite).
R: Current reversed (left). Magnet turned (S-top, N-bottom), so Field (up) -> Force (out of page, same). Only arrangement R results in a force in the same direction as the original arrangement.

context_text: A person is para-sailing and is being towed horizontally at a constant speed of 8.5 m/s. This means the net horizontal force acting on the person is zero. The forces acting are weight (W), tension (T), and drag force (D). The horizontal component of the tension T provides the forward propulsion.
question_text: State the magnitude of the drag force D.
answer_text:
The problem states the person is moving at a constant horizontal speed, implying zero net horizontal force. The horizontal component of the tension T is T_x = T sin(50°) = 1600 N × sin(50°) ≈ 1225.6 N. For constant horizontal speed, the drag force D must be equal and opposite to this forward component. So D ≈ 1225.6 N. 
However, the marking scheme states: 'Drag force = resultant force [1] ecf'. If this refers to the resultant force calculated in part (a) (≈2200 N), then D would be 2200 N, which contradicts the physical equilibrium condition for constant horizontal speed.

context_text: A cyclist on a bicycle moves forward, subject to a driving force and air resistance. When the cyclist is moving at a constant speed, the net force acting on the system (cyclist + bicycle) is zero, according to Newton's First Law.
question_text: Compare the sizes of the two horizontal forces acting on the cyclist and his bicycle when he is moving at a constant speed.
answer_text: Air resistance is equal to the driving force. When moving at a constant speed, there is no net force, so the driving force must be balanced by the opposing air resistance.

context_text: A diagram (Fig 2.1) shows a cyclist on a bicycle. The task is to draw and label three vertical forces acting on the bicycle. Common vertical forces include the weight of the rider, the weight of the bicycle, and the normal contact force from the ground.
question_text: On Fig. 2.1, draw and label three vertical forces acting on the bicycle.
answer_text:
The three vertical forces correctly drawn and labelled on the diagram would typically be:
1. Weight of the cyclist (acting downwards from the cyclist's center of gravity).
2. Weight of the bicycle (acting downwards from the bicycle's center of gravity).
3. Normal force from the road on the bicycle (acting upwards from the wheels).

context_text: A tractor uses its bucket to push a fence post into the ground. The bucket applies a downward force of 6500 N on the fence post. The area of the post in contact with the ground is 100 cm². Pressure is defined as Force divided by Area.
question_text: Calculate the pressure that the fence post exerts on the ground.
answer_text:
Pressure = Force / Area (P = F/A).
Given: Force (F) = 6500 N, Area (A) = 100 cm².
P = 6500 N / 100 cm² = 65 N/cm².
(To convert to SI units: 100 cm² = 0.01 m². P = 6500 N / 0.01 m² = 650,000 Pa = 650 kPa).

context_text: A farmer is pushing a fence post into the ground. Initially, the post has a certain contact area. To make it easier to push, the farmer cuts the bottom of the post to make it more pointed, thus reducing its contact area with the ground while applying the same force. Pressure is inversely proportional to the area for a constant force.
question_text: A farmer cuts the bottom of the post to make it more pointed. He then uses the same force to push the post into the ground. Explain why he makes the post more pointed.
answer_text: By making the post more pointed, the farmer reduces the area of contact of the post with the ground. Since pressure = force/area, reducing the area while applying the same force results in a greater pressure being exerted on the ground. This increased pressure enables the post to be pushed into the ground more easily.

context_text: At the end of a race, a marathon runner's body is warmer than the surrounding air. Convection is a process of heat transfer in fluids (liquids or gases) involving the movement of fluid parcels. This process is driven by density differences that arise from temperature variations.
question_text: Explain how convection currents are set up around the runner at the end of the race.
answer_text: The air molecules immediately surrounding the runner's warmer body get heated up through conduction. This heated air expands, becomes less dense, and consequently rises. Cooler, denser air from the surroundings then sinks to replace the rising warm air. This cooler air is then heated by the runner's body, rises, and the cycle repeats, establishing convection currents that continuously carry thermal energy away from the runner.

context_text: A runner wears a shiny foil blanket to prevent rapid cooling. Shiny surfaces are known for their properties related to thermal radiation. They reflect incident radiation and are poor emitters of radiation.
question_text: Explain how the shiny foil blanket is able to stop him from cooling down too quickly.
answer_text: A shiny foil blanket is a good reflector and a poor emitter of infrared radiation. It reflects the infrared radiation (heat) emitted by the runner's body back towards the runner, thereby minimizing heat loss from the body to the surroundings through radiation. It can also trap a layer of air, reducing heat loss by convection.

context_text: The center of gravity of an object is a specific point related to its mass distribution and the gravitational force acting on it.
question_text: Explain what is meant by centre of gravity.
answer_text: The centre of gravity is defined as the single point on an object where the entire weight of the object appears to act, regardless of the object's orientation.

context_text: An object of weight 2.5 N is tilted and held in position by a force F, with its center of gravity G. It is pivoted at point P. The diagram shows G is to the right of the vertical line through P, meaning its weight creates a clockwise moment about P. If force F is removed, only the object's weight will exert a moment about P.
question_text: Describe and explain what will happen to the object when force F is removed.
answer_text: When force F is removed, the weight of the object (acting through its center of gravity G) will create an anticlockwise moment about the pivot point P, as G is to the right of the pivot in the tilted position. This moment will cause the object to rotate anticlockwise and fall back until it is stable and resting on its base, where the line of action of its weight falls within its base area.

context_text: A uniform beam is pivoted at its center. An object of 2.5 N is placed on one side at a distance of 18 cm from the pivot. A load of 1.5 N is suspended from a string on the other side at an unknown distance 'x' from the pivot. The beam is balanced.
question_text: State the principle of moments.
answer_text: The principle of moments states that for an object to be in rotational equilibrium (balanced), the sum of the clockwise moments about any pivot point must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments about the same pivot point.

context_text: A uniform beam is pivoted at its center. Its center of gravity is therefore located directly at the pivot point. A moment is the product of a force and the perpendicular distance from the pivot to the line of action of the force.
question_text: Explain if the weight of the beam produce any moment about the pivot.
answer_text: No, the weight of the beam does not produce any moment about the pivot. This is because the center of gravity of the uniform beam is located at the pivot point itself, meaning the perpendicular distance from the line of action of the beam's weight to the pivot is zero. Therefore, the moment (Force × perpendicular distance) is zero.

context_text: A circuit contains a 10 V battery, a variable resistor R, and a light bulb Q. An ammeter measures the total current, and a voltmeter measures the voltage across Q. When R is adjusted, the voltmeter reads 2.5 V across bulb Q, and the ammeter reads 0.5 A total current. In this series circuit, the current through Q is the total current.
question_text: Calculate the resistance of light bulb Q.
answer_text:
Using Ohm's Law, Resistance (R) = Voltage (V) / Current (I).
For light bulb Q: V_Q = 2.5 V, I = 0.5 A.
R_Q = 2.5 V / 0.5 A = 5 Ω.

context_text: A circuit contains a 10 V battery, a variable resistor R, and a light bulb Q in series. The total voltage of the battery is 10 V. The voltage across bulb Q is 2.5 V. The total current flowing through the series circuit is 0.5 A.
question_text: Calculate the resistance of variable resistor R.
answer_text: For components in series, the sum of voltages across them equals the total voltage. Voltage across R (V_R) = Total Voltage - V_Q = 10 V - 2.5 V = 7.5 V. The current through R is the same as the total current, I = 0.5 A. Using Ohm's Law, R_R = V_R / I = 7.5 V / 0.5 A = 15 Ω.

context_text: In a series circuit containing a variable resistor R and a light bulb Q, the resistance of R is increased from 15 Ω to 30 Ω. The resistance of light bulb Q (5 Ω) remains unchanged. The brightness of a bulb depends on the power dissipated by it, which is related to the current flowing through it and the voltage across it (P = I²R or P = V²/R).
question_text: The resistance of the variable resistor R is now increased to 30 Ω. Assuming that the resistance of light bulb Q remains unchanged, state and explain what happens to the brightness of light bulb Q.
answer_text:
1.  **Effective Resistance**: The total resistance of the series circuit (R_total = R + R_Q) increases because R increases from 15 Ω to 30 Ω. The new total resistance is 30 Ω + 5 Ω = 35 Ω.
2.  **Current**: According to Ohm's Law (I = V_total / R_total), with a constant total voltage (10 V) and an increased total resistance, the total current flowing through the circuit (and thus through bulb Q) will decrease.
3.  **Potential Difference Across Bulb Q**: Since the current (I) through bulb Q decreases and its resistance (R_Q) is constant, the potential difference (V_Q = I × R_Q) across bulb Q will also decrease.
4.  **Brightness of Bulb Q**: As both the current through bulb Q and the voltage across it decrease, the power dissipated by bulb Q (P_Q = I × V_Q or I²R_Q) will decrease. Therefore, the brightness of light bulb Q will decrease.

context_text: A circuit diagram (Fig 12.2) shows a configuration of light bulbs Q, A (10.0 Ω), and B (4.5 Ω) with four switches S1, S2, S3, S4. The general structure is: from X, one path goes to (Q and S1 in series). Another path goes to (S2 in series with a parallel combination of (A and S3 in series) and (B and S4 in parallel to B's terminals)). All paths then lead to Y.
question_text: Calculate the effective resistance between X and Y when S1 and S3 are closed.
answer_text:
When S1 and S3 are closed, S2 and S4 are assumed to be open. Following the paths in Fig 12.2, if S1 is closed, Bulb Q (resistance 5 Ω from 12a(i)) is active. If S2 is open (as it's not specified as closed), then the entire lower branch containing Bulbs A and B is open, regardless of S3 or S4. Therefore, the effective resistance between X and Y should simply be the resistance of Bulb Q, which is 5 Ω.

However, the provided marking scheme's calculation is: 'Effective resistance in parallel = (1/5 + 1/10)⁻¹ = 3.33 Ω [1] ecf from (a)(i) Effective resistance between X and Y = (3.33 + 4.5 )Ω = 7.83 Ω [1] ecf'. This calculation implies a circuit configuration where Q (5Ω) is in parallel with A (10Ω), and this combined parallel resistance (3.33Ω) is then in series with B (4.5Ω), which does not match the visual arrangement of Fig 12.2.

context_text: The graph illustrates how the distance traveled by a motorcycle changes with time. The x-axis represents time, and the y-axis represents distance. The curve starts at the origin (0,0). In the region labeled P, the slope of the curve is gradually increasing, indicating increasing speed or acceleration. In the region labeled Q, the slope is steep and positive, indicating a high constant speed. In the region labeled R, the slope is decreasing, indicating the motorcycle is slowing down or decelerating. In the region labeled S, the graph becomes a horizontal line, indicating that the distance traveled is no longer changing, meaning the motorcycle is at rest.
question_text:
Which statement is correct?
A at P, the motorcycle is decelerating
B at Q, the motorcycle has constant acceleration
C at R, the motorcycle is slowing down
D at S, the motorcycle has constant speed
answer_text: C. At R, the slope of the distance-time graph is decreasing, which indicates that the motorcycle is slowing down. At S, the horizontal line means the distance is constant, indicating the motorcycle is at rest.

context_text: The diagram shows a car wheel accelerating to the right. The wheel is rotating such that its bottom part moves to the left relative to the car's frame. Point 'C' is the contact point between the wheel and the road surface. An arrow labeled 'B' points horizontally to the left from C. An arrow labeled 'D' points horizontally to the right from C. An arrow labeled 'C' points vertically downwards from the wheel's center to the road contact point.
question_text:
In which direction does the frictional force between the wheel and the road surface act?
A
B
C
D
answer_text: D. The wheel rotates clockwise. For the car to accelerate to the right, the wheel pushes the road surface to the left. By Newton's third law, the road surface exerts a frictional force on the wheel to the right (in the direction of acceleration). Therefore, friction acts in direction D.

context_text:
The problem states that an object with a mass of 15kg on Earth is taken to Mars. The gravitational field strength (gfs) on Earth is 10N/kg, and on Mars, it is 3.7N/kg. A table is provided with columns for 'mass / kg' and 'weight / N'. The options are:
A: mass 15 kg, weight 56 N
B: mass 15 kg, weight 150 N
C: mass 41 kg, weight 15 N
D: mass 41 kg, weight 150 N
question_text:
What are the mass and weight of the object on the Mars?
A mass / kg: 15, weight / N: 56
B mass / kg: 15, weight / N: 150
C mass / kg: 41, weight / N: 15
D mass / kg: 41, weight / N: 150
answer_text: A. Mass is an intrinsic property of an object and remains unchanged regardless of its location, so the mass on Mars is 15kg. Weight is calculated as mass × gravitational field strength (W = mg). On Mars, W = 15kg × 3.7N/kg = 55.5N, which rounds to 56N.

context_text: A 200N force is applied horizontally to a box weighing 400N. The box moves 2.0m horizontally over a period of 20s. A diagram shows a box on a surface. A horizontal force of 200N is applied to the right. The weight of the box, 400N, acts downwards. The displacement is 2.0m.
question_text:
What is the average power?
A 20W
B 400W
C 60W
D 1200W
answer_text: A. Work done = Force × displacement = 200N × 2.0m = 400J. The 400N weight does no work as it is perpendicular to the horizontal displacement. Average Power = Work done / Time = 400J / 20s = 20W.

context_text: The diagram illustrates a tank containing water, with three labeled points: X, Y, and Z. Point X is located at the top-left surface of the water. Point Y is located at the bottom-left corner of the tank. Point Z is located at the bottom-right corner of the tank. The question asks for an arrangement (heating or cooling at one of the points) that would not allow a convection current to be set up.
question_text:
Which arrangement would not allow him to do this?
A cooling at X
B heating at X
C heating at Y
D heating at Z
answer_text: B. Convection currents occur when heated fluid becomes less dense and rises, or cooled fluid becomes denser and sinks. If heating occurs at the top surface (X), the hot water will be less dense and will remain at the top, preventing a circulation pattern needed for a convection current to establish.

context_text: The diagram shows a cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO) trace for a note emitted by a guitar. The trace displays a periodic waveform with multiple peaks and troughs of varying amplitude, characteristic of a complex sound. The waveform has a generally consistent frequency but its amplitude is not uniform, showing variations within each cycle, suggesting a rich harmonic content.
question_text:
If the same note is played again, but softer, how will the trace change?
A The peaks will be closer together.
B The peaks will be further apart.
C The peaks will be higher.
D The peaks will be lower.
answer_text: D. The loudness or softness of a sound corresponds to its amplitude. A softer sound means a lower amplitude, which would be represented on a CRO trace by peaks and troughs of lower height.

context_text:
A 0.40m length of resistance wire with a cross-sectional area of 0.20mm² has a resistance of 2.0Ω. A table provides properties for four other wires of the same material, with columns for 'wire', 'length / m', and 'area / mm²'.
Wire A: length 0.20 m, area 0.20 mm²
Wire B: length 0.20 m, area 0.40 mm²
Wire C: length 0.80 m, area 0.10 mm²
Wire D: length 0.80 m, area 0.40 mm²
question_text:
Which wire of the same material will also have a resistance of 2.0Ω?
A
B
C
D
answer_text:
D. The resistance R of a wire is given by R = ρL/A, where ρ is resistivity, L is length, and A is cross-sectional area. For the given wire, 2.0Ω = ρ(0.40m / 0.20mm²), so ρ = 1.0 Ωmm²/m. For another wire to have 2.0Ω resistance, its L/A ratio must be 2.0.
For Wire D: L/A = 0.80m / 0.40mm² = 2.0. Thus, R = 1.0 × 2.0 = 2.0Ω.

context_text: An electric oven is connected to the mains supply using insulated copper wires. The wires become very warm.
question_text:
What can be done to reduce the amount of heat produced in the insulated copper wires?
A use thicker copper wires
B use thicker insulation
C use thinner copper wires
D use thinner insulation
answer_text: A. The heat produced in a wire is given by H = I²Rt. To reduce heat, the resistance (R) should be reduced. Resistance is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area (R ∝ 1/A). Using thicker copper wires increases the cross-sectional area, thereby decreasing the resistance and reducing the heat produced for a given current.

context_text: The diagram displays a magnetic field pattern between two bar magnets placed horizontally side-by-side, with a gap between them. The magnetic field lines emerge from the left magnet and enter the right magnet through the gap, forming connecting loops. This pattern typically indicates magnetic attraction between the facing poles (North facing South or South facing North). Four options (A, B, C, D) show two bar magnets with their North (N) and South (S) poles labeled for their ends. For example, 'S N | S N' means the left magnet has South on its left, North on its right; the right magnet has South on its left, North on its right.
question_text:
Which two bar magnets produce this pattern?
A S N | S N
B S N | N S
C N S | S N
D N S | N S
answer_text: C. The provided diagram shows field lines connecting the two magnets, which indicates attraction. Magnetic field lines emerge from North poles and enter South poles. Therefore, the right end of the left magnet must be a North pole, and the left end of the right magnet must be a South pole. This corresponds to a N-S attraction. Option C: 'N S | S N' shows the right pole of the left magnet as South and the left pole of the right magnet as South, which would lead to repulsion. The marking scheme's reasoning for this answer is that 'like poles repel and magnetic field go into the S-pole', suggesting the pattern shown, or at least the intended answer, is for repulsion, despite the visual showing attraction.

context_text: This question is a follow-up to the previous part, where the resultant upward force from the two strings supporting the stone was determined to be 6.05N. The stone is in equilibrium, meaning the net force acting on it is zero.
question_text: State the weight of the stone.
answer_text: The weight of the stone is 6.05N. Since the stone is in equilibrium, the upward resultant force from the tensions must be equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the downward force of its weight.

context_text: As described in Figure 2.2, when the pulling force P is 6.0N, the acceleration of the crate is read from the graph as 1.25 m/s². The frictional force opposing motion is 1.0N.
question_text: By using P = 6.0N in Fig. 2.2, calculate the mass of the crate, m.
answer_text: When P = 6.0N, the acceleration a = 1.25m/s². The net force (F_net) acting on the crate is the pulling force minus the frictional force: F_net = P - F_friction = 6.0N - 1.0N = 5.0N. Using Newton's second law, F_net = ma, so 5.0N = m × 1.25m/s². Therefore, the mass of the crate m = 5.0N / 1.25m/s² = 4.0kg.

context_text: This question refers to a 'torture tool' as shown in Fig. 3.1, which consists of a plank with a seat for a victim and a stone for balancing, pivoted over a point. The problem involves concepts of balance and moments.
question_text: Explain what is meant by centre of gravity.
answer_text: The center of gravity is the imaginary point in an object where the entire weight of the object appears to act. It is the single point where the force of gravity acts on a body.

context_text: The total mass of the torture tool (without the stone) is 120kg. A stone of mass 100kg is placed at a distance of 2.0m from the pivot to balance the tool. The gravitational field strength (g) is 10N/kg. The tool is balanced when the clockwise moment equals the anticlockwise moment about the pivot.
question_text: Hence, calculate the distance of the centre of gravity of the torture tool to the pivot. (gravitational field strength, g = 10N/kg)
answer_text: Weight of the torture tool (W_tool) = 120kg × 10N/kg = 1200N. Weight of the stone (W_stone) = 100kg × 10N/kg = 1000N. Let 'd' be the distance of the center of gravity of the torture tool from the pivot. For balance, Anticlockwise moment = Clockwise moment. W_tool × d = W_stone × distance_stone_from_pivot. 1200N × d = 1000N × 2.0m. d = (1000 × 2.0) / 1200 = 2000 / 1200 = 1.67m (to 3 significant figures).

context_text: Figure 5.1 depicts a transparent block in air. A light ray enters the block at point A, refracts, and travels towards point B. At point A, the ray bends towards the normal. At point B, the light is refracted along the surface of the block. A dashed line represents the normal at point A. The refractive index of the block is 1.55. The task is to label the angle of incidence 'i' and angle of refraction 'r' at A, and the critical angle 'c' at B, on the diagram.
question_text: On Fig. 5.1, label (i) at A, the angle of incidence i and the angle of refraction r, (ii) at B, the critical angle c.
answer_text: At point A, label the angle between the incident light ray and the normal (dashed line) as 'i' (angle of incidence). Label the angle between the refracted light ray inside the block and the normal as 'r' (angle of refraction). At point B, where the ray grazes the surface, label the angle between the internally incident ray (traveling within the block towards the surface) and the normal as 'c' (critical angle).

context_text: The transparent block has a refractive index (n) of 1.55. The light ray is refracted along the surface at point B, indicating that the angle of incidence at B is the critical angle (c).
question_text: Calculate the critical angle c.
answer_text: The critical angle (c) is calculated using the formula sin(c) = 1/n, where n is the refractive index. Given n = 1.55, sin(c) = 1/1.55 ≈ 0.64516. Therefore, c = sin⁻¹(0.64516) ≈ 40.177°. Rounding to one decimal place, the critical angle c is 40.2°.

context_text: The transparent block is replaced by another block with a higher refractive index than 1.55. The question asks for one change, if any, to the light ray at the top surface (point A) where the light initially enters the block from air.
question_text: The block is replaced by another block which has a higher refractive index. State one change, if any, to the light ray at the top surface.
answer_text: If the block has a higher refractive index, the critical angle will be smaller (c = sin⁻¹(1/n), as n increases, sin(c) decreases). This means that total internal reflection is more likely to occur if the light ray inside the block attempts to exit, or the angle of refraction at point A would be smaller (the ray bends more towards the normal) for the same angle of incidence from air.

context_text: Ultrasound is used to find the distance from a ship to the seabed. Ultrasound waves are similar to sound waves but have a frequency that is too high to be heard by humans. The question asks for the definition of frequency.
question_text: State what is meant by frequency.
answer_text: Frequency is defined as the number of complete waves or oscillations that pass a point per unit time, usually per second.

context_text: Ultrasound waves have a frequency too high to be heard by humans. The question asks for the highest frequency of sound that can typically be heard by humans.
question_text: State the highest frequency of sound that can be heard by humans.
answer_text: The highest frequency of sound that can typically be heard by humans is 20000 Hz (or 20 kHz).

context_text: The speed of ultrasound in water is 1500m/s. The time taken for the ultrasound to be emitted from a ship, travel to the seabed, reflect, and return to the electronic system on the ship is 0.80s. This is the total time for a round trip.
question_text: Calculate the distance between the ship and the seabed.
answer_text: The total distance travelled by the ultrasound wave is speed × time = 1500m/s × 0.80s = 1200m. Since this is a round trip (down to the seabed and back up to the ship), the distance between the ship and the seabed is half of the total distance: 1200m / 2 = 600m.

context_text: Figure 8.1 shows a rigid wire placed horizontally between the poles of a U-shaped magnet. The magnet has its North pole (N) on the right and its South pole (S) on the left. Magnetic field lines are directed from the North pole to the South pole outside the magnet, and from South to North inside the magnet. Therefore, in the region where the wire is placed, the magnetic field is directed from left (S pole) to right (N pole). A force is exerted on the wire in an upward direction when current flows through it. The task is to draw an arrow on Fig. 8.1 to show the direction of the current in the wire.
question_text: On Fig. 8.1, draw an arrow to show the direction of the current in the wire.
answer_text: Using Fleming's Left-Hand Rule: If the Force (Thumb) is upward and the magnetic Field (Forefinger) is from left to right, then the Current (Middle finger) must be directed into the page. On a 2D diagram where the wire is horizontal, 'into the page' is represented by a downward arrow drawn perpendicular to the wire.

context_text: A rigid wire carrying current is placed in a magnetic field, resulting in an upward force. The question asks for two ways to increase the magnitude of this force.
question_text: State two ways to increase the magnitude of the force on this wire.
answer_text:
1. Increase the current flowing through the wire (e.g., by increasing the electromotive force (emf) of the power source).
2. Use a stronger magnet to increase the strength of the magnetic field in which the wire is placed.

context_text: A rigid wire experiences an upward force when current flows through it in a magnetic field. The question asks for one change that can be made to cause a downward force on the wire.
question_text: State one change that can be made to cause a downward force on the wire.
answer_text: To reverse the direction of the force, either the direction of the current or the direction of the magnetic field must be reversed. So, one change could be to reverse the direction of the current flow in the wire. Alternatively, one could swap the poles of the magnet to reverse the direction of the magnetic field.

context_text: Figure 9.1 shows a thermal flask insulated with foam. The flask has a stopper at the top and contains a hot liquid. The foam fills the space between the inner and outer walls of the flask. The foam traps small pockets of air between them.
question_text: Explain why the foam in Fig. 9.1 reduces loss of thermal energy by conduction.
answer_text: The foam effectively traps small pockets of air. Air is a very poor conductor of thermal energy, meaning it does not transfer heat well through conduction. By trapping this air, the foam significantly reduces heat transfer by conduction from the hot liquid to the surroundings.

context_text: Figure 9.2 shows another thermal flask design with a vacuum between double-walled silvered glass. This flask also has a stopper and contains hot liquid. The question asks to compare its insulation with foam.
question_text: Explain why the vacuum between the double glass walls in Fig. 9.2 provides a better heat insulation than foam.
answer_text: A vacuum provides better heat insulation because it completely removes the medium required for heat transfer by both conduction and convection. Unlike foam, which contains air (a poor conductor but still a medium), a vacuum contains virtually no particles, so there is no medium to facilitate heat transfer via molecular collisions (conduction) or by movement of fluid (convection).

context_text: Figure 9.2 shows a thermal flask with double-walled silvered glass. The inner surfaces of the vacuum flask are silvered.
question_text: Explain why the silvered glass in Fig. 9.2 helps to keep the liquid hot for a longer period of time.
answer_text: Silvered surfaces are excellent reflectors of thermal radiation and poor emitters of it. The silvering on the inner wall reflects infrared radiation emitted by the hot liquid back into the liquid, reducing heat loss by radiation. Similarly, silvering on the outer wall reflects external radiation, preventing it from reaching the liquid. This significantly slows down heat transfer due to radiation.

context_text: Figure 9.3 presents a cooling curve for water being cooled from room temperature T₁ in a freezer to make ice cubes. The graph plots temperature in °C on the y-axis against time in minutes on the x-axis. The curve shows a decrease in temperature from T₁ to T₂, a horizontal plateau at T₂, and then a further decrease in temperature from T₂ to T₃. T₂ is shown as a constant temperature phase.
question_text: State the physical meaning of temperature T₂.
answer_text: Temperature T₂ represents the freezing point of water (the temperature at which water changes from liquid to solid) or the melting point of ice (the temperature at which ice changes from solid to liquid).

context_text: Referring to the cooling curve in Figure 9.3, point A is on the curve where the substance is in its liquid state, specifically between temperatures T₁ and T₂. At this point, the substance is still liquid water.
question_text: Describe the arrangement of the molecules of the substance at point A.
answer_text: At point A, the substance is liquid water. Its molecules are packed relatively close together but are randomly arranged and can move past each other, giving the liquid its fluidity and shape-changing property.

context_text: Referring to the cooling curve in Figure 9.3, the substance cools from point B (the end of the freezing plateau, where it has fully solidified) to point C (where the solid continues to cool). The substance is in a solid state between B and C.
question_text: Describe the changes, if any, that occur to the motion of the molecules of the substance as it cools from B to C.
answer_text: As the solid substance cools from point B to C, the molecules, which are already in fixed positions within the solid lattice, vibrate about their fixed positions with reduced kinetic energy, meaning they vibrate slower and with smaller amplitudes.

context_text: Figure 10.1 shows a circuit with a thermistor (component T) connected in series with a resistor U. Resistor U has a resistance of 500Ω. The circuit is powered by a 9.0V battery. Figure 10.2 is a graph showing the variation of the resistance of the thermistor (y-axis, in Ω) with temperature (x-axis, in °C). The resistance of the thermistor decreases as temperature increases. The task is to use this graph to find the resistance of T when the temperature is 60°C.
question_text: When the temperature is 60°C, (i) use Fig.10.2 to determine the resistance of T,
answer_text: By locating 60°C on the x-axis of Figure 10.2 and reading the corresponding value on the y-axis, the resistance of thermistor T is determined to be 400Ω.

context_text: The total supply voltage is 9.0V. As the temperature drops to 30°C, the current decreases, the resistance of thermistor T increases, and the potential difference across resistor U decreases (as explained in 10b(ii)). In a series circuit, the sum of potential differences across components equals the supply voltage.
question_text: the potential difference across thermistor T.
answer_text: Since the potential difference across resistor U decreases, and the sum of potential differences across T and U must equal the constant supply voltage of 9.0V, the potential difference across thermistor T must increase to compensate (V_supply = V_T + V_U). Alternatively, since the resistance of T increases and the current through it decreases, V_T = I × Resistance_T. The increase in R_T is proportionally larger than the decrease in I, leading to an increase in V_T.

context_text: Figure 11.1 shows an air-conditioner installed high on a wall, near the ceiling. The air-conditioner is operated using a remote controller. The question asks why it is installed at the top of the wall.
question_text: Describe and explain why the air-conditioner is installed at the top of the wall.
answer_text: Air conditioners are installed at the top of the wall to facilitate efficient cooling through convection. Cooler air from the air conditioner is denser than the warmer air in the room, so it sinks. As the cool air sinks, it displaces the warmer, less dense air, which rises towards the ceiling and is then drawn into the air conditioner to be cooled. This process creates a continuous convection current that effectively circulates and cools the entire room.

context_text: An air-conditioner was switched on for 8 hours and used 4.0kWh of electrical energy. The cost per kWh is $0.30.
question_text: If the cost per kWh is $0.30, calculate the cost of using the air-conditioner.
answer_text: Cost of using the air-conditioner = Electrical energy used (kWh) × Cost per kWh = 4.0 kWh × $0.30/kWh = $1.20.

context_text: Figures 11.2 and 11.3 show a circuit breaker. In Fig. 11.2 (on state), current flows from terminal 1, through the springy metal contact, through the solenoid, and out through terminal 2. The solenoid is an electromagnet. In Fig. 11.3 (off state), the contact between terminal 1 and 2 is open. The question asks about the type of fault that would cause the circuit breaker to operate.
question_text: State the type of fault that could cause the circuit breaker to operate.
answer_text: The circuit breaker operates in response to an excessive current. This typically occurs due to a short circuit (where a low-resistance path allows a very large current to flow) or an overload (where too many appliances draw current, exceeding the circuit's safe limit).

context_text: Figures 11.2 and 11.3 show a circuit breaker. In Fig. 11.2 (on state), current flows from terminal 1, through the springy metal contact, through the solenoid, and out through terminal 2. The solenoid is an electromagnet. In Fig. 11.3 (off state), the contact between terminal 1 and 2 is open. The question asks to describe how the circuit breaker switches off the current.
question_text: Describe how the circuit breaker switches off the current.
answer_text: When a fault (like a short circuit or overload) causes the current flowing through the circuit breaker's solenoid to become excessively large, the magnetic field produced by the solenoid becomes strong enough to attract an iron armature. This attraction causes the iron armature to pivot or pull away from its normal position, which in turn releases the springy metal contact (which is held closed by a spring). The contact then opens, creating a break in the circuit between terminal 1 and terminal 2. This open circuit immediately stops the flow of current, protecting the appliance and wiring.

context_text:

context_text: The diagram shows the boiler of a coal-fired power station where hot gases heat cold water inside metal pipes to form steam. This process involves heat transfer through the metal pipes.
question_text: Using ideas about particles, explain how heat is transferred through the metal pipes by conduction.
answer_text:
As the hot air heats up the pipes, the heat is converted into kinetic energy of the particles in the metal and it vibrates more vigorously.
It collides with its neighbouring particles and causes them to vibrate more vigorously as well, passing the kinetic energy to them.
This continues until all the heat has transferred through the pipes.
