context_text: In the context of the man dropping a stone and feather on Earth, the feather is observed to fall at a constant speed, which is a terminal velocity. This occurs due to air resistance.
question_text:
Explain the reason for the feather to fall at constant speed, in terms of
forces acting on the feather.
answer_text: The feather falls at a constant speed (terminal velocity) because the upward force of air resistance acting on it becomes equal in magnitude to its downward weight. At this point, the net or resultant force acting on the feather is zero, leading to zero acceleration, and thus it continues to fall at a constant speed.

context_text: On Planet X, the gravitational acceleration is the same as Earth (10 m/s²), but there is no atmosphere, meaning no air resistance. An astronaut drops a stone and a feather on this planet.
question_text:
State two differences about the motion of the stone and the feather as
compared to the motion when they are on Earth.
answer_text:
1.  On Planet X, both the stone and the feather will fall with the same constant acceleration (10 m/s²) because there is no air resistance. On Earth, due to air resistance, the feather falls with a much lower, constant terminal velocity, while the stone accelerates more significantly. Consequently, the speed of the stone and feather on Planet X will be faster than their respective speeds when falling on Earth. 
2.  On Planet X, both the stone and the feather will hit the surface at the same time and with the same final speed, as they experience the same acceleration. On Earth, the stone would hit the ground significantly earlier than the feather due to the effects of air resistance.

context_text: The machine for crushing cans uses a lever with a pivot. An effort is applied by a hand on one end, and the crushing force is exerted on the can near the pivot. The hand applies force at a distance of 0.3 m from the pivot, while the crushing force is applied to the can at a distance of 0.2 m from the pivot. The lever is pushed downwards by hand to crush the can.
question_text: Explain how the design of this machine makes it easier to crush the cans.
answer_text: The design of this machine uses the principle of moments. By applying the effort force (from the hand) at a greater distance (0.3 m) from the pivot compared to the distance at which the load (crushing force on the can) acts (0.2 m), the lever acts as a force multiplier. This means a relatively small effort force exerted by the hand can generate a significantly larger crushing force on the can, making it easier to crush.

context_text: The can crushing machine uses a lever. A downward force of 50 N is applied at the handle. The distance from the pivot to where the hand applies the force is taken as 0.5 m (as used in the marking scheme for calculations, though the diagram visually labels it as 0.3 m). The distance from the pivot to the can being crushed is 0.2 m.
question_text:
A downward force of 50 N is applied at the handle. Calculate the force acting
on the can.
answer_text:
Using the principle of moments, where the effort force multiplied by its distance from the pivot equals the load force multiplied by its distance from the pivot:
Effort Force × Effort Distance = Force on Can × Load Distance
50 N × 0.5 m = Force on Can × 0.2 m
Force on Can = (50 × 0.5) / 0.2 = 25 / 0.2 = 125 N.

context_text: The force calculated to be acting on the can is 125 N. The can has a circular cross-section with a radius of 3 cm. Pressure needs to be calculated in Pascals.
question_text:
If the radius of the can is 3 cm, calculate the pressure acting on the can in
pascals.
answer_text: To calculate the pressure, first determine the area over which the force is applied. The radius of the can (r) is 3 cm = 0.03 m. The area (A) of the circular contact point is A = πr² = 3.14 × (0.03 m)² = 3.14 × 0.0009 m² = 0.002826 m². The force (F) acting on the can is 125 N. Pressure (P) = F / A = 125 N / 0.002826 m² = 44232.84 Pa. Rounded to 3 significant figures, the pressure acting on the can is 44200 Pa.

context_text: Inside a refrigerator (Figure 4), pipes containing fluid are located at the top. This fluid absorbs heat from the top part of the refrigerator compartment. Below these pipes are black metal fins, and a pump is located further down. The walls are insulated with polystyrene foam. The heat absorbed by the fluid is released into the air through the black metal fins outside the refrigerator.
question_text:
Explain how the entire fridge is kept cool as heat is removed from the top part of
the refrigerator.
answer_text: As the fluid in the pipes at the top of the refrigerator removes heat from the surrounding air, this air cools down, becomes denser, and sinks. Concurrently, the warmer, less dense air from the bottom of the compartment rises to take its place. This continuous cycle of rising warm air and sinking cold air establishes a convection current, effectively distributing the cooling effect throughout the entire refrigerator compartment.

context_text: In the refrigerator, heat is released into the surrounding air through black metal fins located outside the main cooling compartment.
question_text: Explain why the fins are painted black in colour.
answer_text: The fins are painted dull black because black surfaces are excellent emitters of thermal radiation. By making the fins black, they efficiently radiate the heat absorbed from the refrigerator's interior into the surrounding air, maximizing the rate of heat transfer out of the system and ensuring efficient cooling.

context_text: The refrigerator's outer walls contain a layer of polystyrene foam.
question_text:
Explain how the layer of polystyrene foam helps to keep the contents of the
refrigerator cool.
answer_text: Polystyrene foam is an effective thermal insulator. It contains many small pockets of trapped air, and both air (especially trapped air) and polystyrene are poor conductors of heat. This layer therefore significantly reduces the transfer of heat from the warmer external environment into the cooler interior of the refrigerator by both conduction and convection, helping to maintain a low temperature inside.

context_text: Petrol is being pumped into a can through a pipe. As the petrol flows, electrostatic charges build up, with the pipe becoming positively charged and the petrol in the can becoming negatively charged.
question_text:
Explain how the pipe becomes positively charged and the petrol becomes
negatively charged.
answer_text: When petrol flows through the pipe, charging by friction (triboelectric effect) occurs between the petrol and the inner surface of the pipe. During this process, electrons are transferred from the pipe material to the petrol. As the pipe loses electrons, it acquires a net positive charge, while the petrol gains electrons and becomes negatively charged.

context_text: Electrostatic charges build up on the pipe and petrol during pumping.
question_text:
Explain why it is dangerous to allow the electrostatic charges to continue to
build up.
answer_text: It is dangerous to allow electrostatic charges to build up because if the potential difference becomes sufficiently large, a sudden discharge can occur in the form of an electric spark. Petrol vapor is highly flammable, and such a spark could ignite the vapor, leading to a fire or explosion.

context_text: The question refers to an electrical circuit containing resistors and a battery, asking for the definition of electromotive force (e.m.f.).
question_text: Explain what is meant by the term electromotive force.
answer_text: Electromotive force (e.m.f.) is defined as the work done by a power source (e.g., battery or generator) in driving a unit positive charge around a complete circuit. It represents the total electrical energy supplied by the source per unit charge.

context_text: Figure 7.1 shows an electrical circuit. The circuit consists of a battery, a 5.0 Ω resistor, a parallel combination of a 4.0 Ω bulb and another 4.0 Ω resistor, and a 28 Ω resistor, all connected in series. The current flowing through the 4.0 Ω bulb is given as 1.0 A.
question_text:
Given that the current flowing through the bulb is 1.0 A, determine
(i) the current flowing through the 5.0 Ω resistor.
answer_text: The current flowing through the 4.0 Ω bulb is 1.0 A. Since the other 4.0 Ω resistor is in parallel with the bulb and has the same resistance, the current flowing through it is also 1.0 A. The 5.0 Ω resistor is in series with this parallel combination, so the total current flowing through the 5.0 Ω resistor is the sum of the currents in the parallel branches: 1.0 A + 1.0 A = 2.0 A.

context_text: Figure 7.1 shows an electrical circuit. The circuit consists of a battery, a 5.0 Ω resistor, a parallel combination of a 4.0 Ω bulb and another 4.0 Ω resistor, and a 28 Ω resistor, all connected in series. The current flowing through the 4.0 Ω bulb is given as 1.0 A. From part (b)(i), the total current flowing through the 5.0 Ω resistor and the parallel combination is 2.0 A. The equivalent resistance of the two parallel 4.0 Ω resistors is (4*4)/(4+4) = 2.0 Ω. The combined resistance of the 5.0 Ω resistor in series with this parallel combination is 5.0 Ω + 2.0 Ω = 7.0 Ω. The marking scheme's answer for this part, which asks for potential difference across the 28 Ω resistor, calculates the potential difference across the 5.0 Ω resistor and the parallel 4.0 Ω combination instead.
question_text:
Given that the current flowing through the bulb is 1.0 A, determine
(ii) the potential difference across the 28 Ω resistor
answer_text: Based on the provided marking scheme, the potential difference is calculated as: Current × Equivalent Resistance = 2.0 A × (5.0 Ω + (4.0 Ω || 4.0 Ω)) = 2.0 A × (5.0 Ω + 2.0 Ω) = 2.0 A × 7.0 Ω = 14 V. This value represents the potential difference across the 5.0 Ω resistor and the parallel combination of the two 4.0 Ω resistors.

context_text: Figure 7.1 shows an electrical circuit containing resistors of 5.0 Ω, 4.0 Ω (bulb), 4.0 Ω, and 28 Ω. However, this question refers to a '3.0 Ω resistor' which is not explicitly present in the given circuit diagram. The current from a preceding section is 2.0 A, and a voltage of 14V is also mentioned in the context of the marking scheme.
question_text:
Given that the current flowing through the bulb is 1.0 A, determine
(iii) the current flowing through the 3.0 Ω resistor,
answer_text: Based on the provided marking scheme, the current flowing through the (hypothetical) 3.0 Ω resistor is calculated as 2.0 A + (14 V / 28 Ω) = 2.0 A + 0.5 A = 2.5 A.

context_text: Figure 7.1 shows an electrical circuit. This question refers to a '3.0 Ω resistor' which is not explicitly present in the given circuit diagram. From the previous part (iii) (based on the marking scheme), the current flowing through this hypothetical 3.0 Ω resistor is 2.5 A.
question_text:
Given that the current flowing through the bulb is 1.0 A, determine
(iv)the power dissipated in the 3.0 Ω resistor.
answer_text: Based on the provided marking scheme, the power dissipated in the (hypothetical) 3.0 Ω resistor is calculated using the formula P = I²R. Given the current (I) is 2.5 A and the resistance (R) is 3.0 Ω: P = (2.5 A)² × 3.0 Ω = 6.25 × 3.0 = 18.75 W. Rounded to one decimal place, the power dissipated is 18.8 W.

context_text: Figure 8.1 displays a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) trace of sound from an electronic organ. The trace shows an oscillating wave whose amplitude gradually decreases as time progresses. A time period is marked as 0.020 s between two consecutive peaks. The y-axis represents amplitude.
question_text:
From Fig 8.1,
(a) state which property of the sound changes with time.
answer_text: From the c.r.o. trace in Figure 8.1, the amplitude of the sound wave is observed to decrease over time. The amplitude of a sound wave is directly related to its loudness. Therefore, the loudness of the sound changes (specifically, it decreases) with time.

context_text: Figure 8.1 displays a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) trace of sound from an electronic organ. The trace shows an oscillating wave whose period remains constant over time, as indicated by consistent spacing between peaks (0.020 s).
question_text: state which property of the sound is kept constant.
answer_text: From the c.r.o. trace in Figure 8.1, the time period (and thus the frequency) of the oscillations remains constant, as indicated by the consistent spacing between consecutive peaks (0.020 s). The frequency of a sound wave determines its pitch. Therefore, the pitch of the sound is kept constant.

context_text: Figure 8.1 shows a damped sound wave trace on a c.r.o. The initial amplitude of the wave is 6 units (from the central line to the first peak). The time period of one complete oscillation is 0.020 s, as indicated by the horizontal distance between consecutive peaks. The amplitude is observed to decrease with time.
question_text:
determine the time taken for the amplitude of the trace in Fig. 8.1 to
decrease to half its initial value.
answer_text: The initial amplitude of the trace, measured from the central line to the first peak, is 6 units. Half of this initial value is 3 units. By visually inspecting the trace, the amplitude decreases to 3 units at the peak of the fourth oscillation (after three full cycles from the first peak). Since the time period for one oscillation is 0.020 s, the time taken for the amplitude to decrease to half its initial value is 3 × 0.020 s = 0.060 s.

context_text: Figure 9.1 shows a three-core cable with brown, blue, and yellow/green wires, and a mains plug (with cover removed) showing terminals for earth, live, neutral, and a fuse, as well as a cable grip. The task is to describe the correct and safe connection of the wires to the plug.
question_text:
Describe how to connect the cable and the three wires correctly and safely
to the plug.
answer_text:
To connect the cable and wires correctly and safely:
1.  The brown wire, which is the live wire, must be connected to the live terminal (L), typically located on the right side of the plug.
2.  The blue wire, which is the neutral wire, must be connected to the neutral terminal (N), typically located on the left side of the plug.
3.  The yellow/green striped wire, which is the earth wire, must be connected to the earth terminal (E), typically located at the top of the plug.
4.  The cable's outer insulation should be held firmly by the cable grip to prevent strain on the internal connections, and the individual wires should be cut to the correct length so that no bare wire is exposed beyond their respective terminals. An appropriate fuse should also be fitted into the fuse holder, connecting the live terminal.

context_text: A table lamp (Figure 9.2) is constructed from plastic and has a cable with only two wires. Its power rating is 100 W, and it operates on a 230 V mains supply.
question_text: Which wire, earth, live or neutral, is not needed in the cable for the lamp?
answer_text: The earth wire is not needed for this lamp. Appliances with plastic casings are typically double-insulated, meaning they do not require an earth connection for safety.

context_text: The table lamp is made of plastic and uses a two-wire cable.
question_text:
Explain why the lamp is safe to use even though it has only two wires in the
cable.
answer_text: The lamp is safe to use with only two wires because its casing is made of plastic, which is an electrical insulator. This design makes the lamp 'double-insulated'. In the event of an internal fault where a live wire touches the casing, the plastic insulation prevents the casing from becoming live, thereby protecting the user from electric shock without the need for an earth wire.

context_text: Figure 10.2 depicts a motor effect demonstration setup. A copper wire P is positioned between the poles of a horseshoe magnet (North pole above, South pole below, so the magnetic field is directed downwards). Wire P rests on two other copper wires connected to a d.c. power supply. When the power supply is switched on, current flows through wire P. Based on the explanation in part (ii) of the marking scheme, the current flows into the plane of the page through wire P.
question_text:
State the direction the copper wire P would roll when the d.c. power supply is
switched on.
answer_text: When the d.c. power supply is switched on, the copper wire P would roll to the right.

context_text: Figure 10.2 shows a copper wire P in a magnetic field created by a horseshoe magnet (N pole above, S pole below, so the magnetic field points downwards). The wire P is connected to a d.c. power supply, and it is observed to roll to the right when switched on. The marking scheme specifies that current flows through wire P in a direction that is into the plane of the page.
question_text: Explain the observation made in (i).
answer_text: When the power supply is switched on, current flows through wire P in a direction into the plane of the page. The magnetic field from the horseshoe magnet is directed downwards (from the North pole above to the South pole below). According to Fleming's Left-Hand Rule (Motor Rule), when the forefinger points in the direction of the magnetic field (downwards) and the middle finger points in the direction of the current (into the page), the thumb points in the direction of the force. This force is directed to the right, causing wire P to roll in that direction.

context_text: In the motor effect demonstration, the copper wire P rolls to the right when the current flows into the plane of the page within the downward magnetic field. Now, the current direction is reversed.
question_text:
What difference would you notice if the following changes are made?
(i) The current is reversed.
answer_text: If the current in wire P is reversed (i.e., flows out of the plane of the page), according to Fleming's Left-Hand Rule, the direction of the magnetic force acting on the wire will also reverse. Therefore, wire P would now roll to the left.

context_text: In the motor effect demonstration, the copper wire P rolls to the right when the current flows into the plane of the page within the downward magnetic field. Now, the magnetic field direction is reversed (e.g., by flipping the magnet so the S pole is above and N pole is below, making the field direction upwards).
question_text:
What difference would you notice if the following changes are made?
(ii) The magnetic field is reversed.
answer_text: If the magnetic field direction is reversed (e.g., pointing upwards) while the current direction in wire P remains the same (into the plane of the page), according to Fleming's Left-Hand Rule, the direction of the magnetic force acting on the wire will reverse. Therefore, wire P would now roll to the left.

context_text: In the motor effect demonstration setup, the d.c. power supply is replaced with an alternating current (a.c.) power supply that has a low frequency. The copper wire P is in a constant magnetic field.
question_text:
State and explain what is observed if the power supply is changed to an
alternating current that has a low frequency.
answer_text: If the power supply is changed to a low-frequency alternating current, the direction of the current in wire P will periodically reverse. This periodic reversal of current direction, while the magnetic field remains constant, will cause the direction of the magnetic force on the wire to switch back and forth (e.g., from right to left and then left to right) according to Fleming's Left-Hand Rule. Consequently, the wire P will be observed to oscillate (roll back and forth) repeatedly as long as the alternating current is supplied.

context_text: A petrol-driven car starts from rest and accelerates to a constant cruising speed on a straight, level road.
question_text: State the energy changes in the car.
answer_text: As the car accelerates, the chemical potential energy stored in the petrol is converted primarily into kinetic energy (due to the car's motion) and also into thermal energy (due to friction in the engine and moving parts, and air resistance) and sound energy.

context_text: The question asks for the principle of conservation of energy in the context of a roller coaster cart's motion.
question_text: State the principle of conservation of energy.
answer_text: The principle of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed; it can only be transformed from one form to another or transferred from one system to another. The total amount of energy in an isolated system remains constant.

context_text: For the roller coaster cart: The calculated loss in gravitational potential energy between points A and B is 15000 J, while the calculated increase in kinetic energy over the same segment is 12500 J. These values are different.
question_text:
Suggest why the loss in gravitational potential energy and the increase
in kinetic energy are different and explain how the law of conservation
of energy applies to this situation.
answer_text: The loss in gravitational potential energy (15000 J) is greater than the increase in kinetic energy (12500 J) because the track is not perfectly smooth, implying the presence of resistive forces like friction and air resistance. These forces do work against the motion of the cart, converting some of the mechanical energy (gravitational potential energy) into non-useful forms, primarily thermal energy (heat due to friction) and sound energy. The law of conservation of energy still holds true: the total energy is conserved, with the difference (15000 J - 12500 J = 2500 J) being the amount of energy converted into thermal and sound energy, which is dissipated to the surroundings.

context_text: The diagram illustrates three points, X, Y, and Z, which form a triangle. The distance from X to Y is 5.0 m. The distance from Y to Z is 12.0 m. The distance from Z to X is 13.0 m. A person walks along the paths from X to Y, then to Z, and finally back to X.
question_text:
What is the value of the total displacement and of the total distance travelled?
A. total displacement / m: 0, total distance travelled / m: 0
B. total displacement / m: 0, total distance travelled / m: 30
C. total displacement / m: 30, total distance travelled / m: 0
D. total displacement / m: 30, total distance travelled / m: 30
answer_text: B. The total distance travelled is the sum of the lengths of all paths: 5.0 m + 12.0 m + 13.0 m = 30.0 m. The total displacement is 0 m because the person returns to the starting point X.

context_text: The graph shows how the distance of a train from a station varies with time, starting from time t=0. The x-axis represents time, and the y-axis represents distance. The curve starts at (0,0), increases smoothly to a maximum distance, and then decreases smoothly. The time interval between t1 and t2 is on the decreasing part of the curve, after the peak distance.
question_text:
Which statement about the motion of the train between t1 and t2 is correct?
A. Its speed is decreasing and it is moving away from the station.
B. Its speed is decreasing and it is moving towards the station.
C. Its speed is increasing and it is moving away from the station.
D. Its speed is increasing and it is moving towards the station.
answer_text: D. In a distance-time graph, the gradient represents speed. Between t1 and t2, the distance from the station is decreasing, indicating the train is moving towards the station. The gradient's magnitude is increasing (the curve is getting steeper), meaning the speed is increasing.

context_text: A diagram shows a wooden block resting on a table. A horizontal pushing force is applied to the block, moving it across the table at a constant speed.
question_text:
Which statement is correct?
A. The frictional force increases as the block moves at constant speed.
B. The frictional force is equal and opposite to the pushing force.
C. The frictional force is greater than the pushing force.
D. The frictional force is less than the pushing force.
answer_text: B. Since the wooden block is moving at a constant speed, its acceleration is zero, and thus the net force acting on it is zero. This means the pushing force is balanced by an equal and opposite frictional force.

context_text: A diagram shows an irregularly shaped lamina with a pivot point Q near its bottom edge. A thread is attached at point P near the top edge, exerting a horizontal force F to the right. The lamina is free to rotate about Q. Several dashed lines are drawn from Q to the line of action of force F. Line 'z' represents the perpendicular distance from the pivot Q to the line of action of force F.
question_text:
The lamina is free to rotate about point Q. The tension in the thread is F. What is the moment of F about Q?
A. Fw
B. Fx
C. Fy
D. Fz
answer_text: D. The moment of a force about a pivot is calculated as the product of the force and the perpendicular distance from the pivot to the line of action of the force. In the diagram, 'z' represents this perpendicular distance.

context_text: A displacement-distance graph of particles in a wave is shown. The x-axis represents distance, and the y-axis represents displacement. The wave starts at zero displacement, rises to a crest, passes through zero, drops to a trough, and returns to zero, completing one full wavelength. Point A marks the distance of the first crest from the origin (representing 1/4 wavelength). Point B marks the distance where the wave first crosses the x-axis after the first crest (representing 1/2 wavelength). Point C marks the distance of the first trough (representing 3/4 wavelength). Point D marks the distance where the wave completes one full wavelength from the origin (representing 1 wavelength).
question_text:
Which value is multiplied by the frequency to give the speed of the wave?
A. The distance marked by A.
B. The distance marked by B.
C. The distance marked by C.
D. The distance marked by D.
answer_text: C. The speed of a wave (v) is given by the formula v = fλ, where f is the frequency and λ is the wavelength. In the given diagram, the wavelength is represented by the distance 'D', which is the length of one complete wave cycle. However, according to the provided solution, 'C' is the correct answer, which represents three-quarters of a wavelength (the distance to the first trough). This may indicate a specific interpretation or an error in the provided answer key, as standard physics defines wavelength as 'D'.

context_text: This is a conceptual question about safety features in household electrical circuits.
question_text:
In a household electrical circuit, why are fuses and switches always placed in the live lead?
A. A break in the live wire cuts off the appliance from the voltage supply.
B. A break in the neutral wire would not stop current in the circuit.
C. The live wire carries a greater current.
D. The neutral wire carries no current.
answer_text: A. Fuses and switches are placed in the live lead to ensure that when a fault occurs (fuse blows) or when the appliance is switched off, the appliance is completely disconnected from the high potential (voltage supply). This makes the appliance safe to handle or repair, as no current can flow through it from the mains even if there is a path to ground.

context_text: A microphone in a recording studio has a weight W of 5.0 N. It is suspended from the ceiling by a cord attached to a small ring. A horizontal thread pulls the microphone to one side, keeping it stationary. The tension T in the horizontal thread is 8.0 N.
question_text: (a) Determine graphically the magnitude and the direction, relative to the vertical, of the resultant of forces W and T.
answer_text:
The resultant force can be determined graphically by constructing a vector diagram, representing the weight (W = 5.0 N downwards) and tension (T = 8.0 N horizontally) as vectors originating from the same point. The resultant vector would be the diagonal of the rectangle formed by these two forces. Graphically, by measuring the length and angle of this resultant vector from a scale diagram:
Magnitude of resultant = 9.3 N to 9.6 N.
Direction of resultant force = 36.7° from the 8 N horizontal force (angle between 36° to 40°) OR 62.9° from the 5 N vertical force (angle between 50° to 52°).

context_text: The microphone is suspended from the ceiling by a cord, and held stationary by a horizontal thread. Forces acting are the weight (W), the tension from the horizontal thread (T), and the tension from the cord (let's call it F_cord). Since the microphone is stationary, the system is in equilibrium.
question_text: (b) State how the magnitude and direction of the resultant in (a) compares with the force on the ring due to the tension in the cord.
answer_text:
1. Magnitude: The magnitude of the force on the ring due to the tension in the cord is the same as the magnitude of the resultant of forces W and T.
2. Direction: The force on the ring by the cord is opposite in direction to the resultant of forces W and T.
This is because for the microphone to be in equilibrium, the net force on it must be zero. Therefore, the cord's tension must exactly balance the combined effect of the weight and the horizontal tension.

context_text: An early water-powered device is used to raise a heavy load. It consists of a beam pivoted at its center. On the left, cylinder A contains water and has a piston A connected to the beam. On the right, cylinder B has a piston B that supports a heavy load and is connected to the beam. The weight of water in cylinder A is 80 kN.
question_text: (a) The weight of water in cylinder A is 80 kN. Calculate the mass of water in cylinder A.
answer_text:
The weight (W) of water is given by the formula W = mg, where m is mass and g is the acceleration due to gravity (assumed to be 10 m/s²).
Given W = 80 kN = 80,000 N.
80,000 N = m × 10 m/s²
m = 80,000 N / 10 m/s² = 8000 kg.
So, the mass of water in cylinder A is 8000 kg.

context_text: A diagram (Fig. 3.1) shows a wooden bench of weight 2000 N. The bench rests on two supports. Each support has an area of 0.040 m² in contact with the ground.
question_text: (a) Each of the two supports has an area of 0.040 m² in contact with the ground. Calculate the pressure on the ground due to the bench.
answer_text:
Pressure (P) is calculated as Force (F) divided by Area (A), P = F/A.
Total force exerted by the bench on the ground is its weight = 2000 N.
Total contact area with the ground = 2 supports × 0.040 m²/support = 0.080 m².
Pressure = 2000 N / 0.080 m² = 25,000 Pa.
The pressure on the ground due to the bench is 25,000 Pa.

context_text: A light ray in air is incident on a rectangular glass block at an angle of incidence (i) of 60° with the normal. The refractive index of the glass (n) is 1.5.
question_text: At the point where the light enters the glass, the angle of refraction is r. Calculate angle r.
answer_text:
According to Snell's Law: n_air × sin(i) = n_glass × sin(r).
Assuming n_air ≈ 1, and given n_glass = 1.5 and i = 60°.
1 × sin(60°) = 1.5 × sin(r)
sin(r) = sin(60°) / 1.5 = 0.8660 / 1.5 ≈ 0.5773
r = arcsin(0.5773) ≈ 35.26°.
The angle of refraction (r) is approximately 35.3° (or 35.26°).

context_text: A light ray enters a rectangular glass block, refracts, and then travels through the glass to an internal surface (side XY) at point P. The angle of incidence at P, measured from the normal to surface XY, is equal to the angle of refraction (r) previously calculated as approximately 35.25°. The critical angle (c) for the glass-air interface was calculated as approximately 41.81°.
question_text: (ii) At P, the angle θ between the ray and the normal is given by θ = 90° – r. State and explain what happens to the light when it is incident on side XY.
answer_text:
Total internal reflection occurs. The explanation is that the angle of incidence at point P (which is r ≈ 35.25°) is greater than the critical angle (c ≈ 41.81°), and light is travelling from an optically denser medium (glass) towards an optically less dense medium (air). This condition causes total internal reflection. 

Note: Based on calculations (r ≈ 35.25° and c ≈ 41.81°), the angle of incidence (r) is actually less than the critical angle (c). Therefore, light should refract out of the block into the air, rather than undergo total internal reflection. The answer provided in the solution contradicts standard physics principles for these calculated values.

context_text: An uncharged metal-coated sphere hangs from an insulating thread. A negatively-charged plastic rod is brought near the sphere. Point X is on the right side of the sphere, further from the rod. The sphere is a conductor.
question_text: (i) Draw on Fig. 6.2 how charge is distributed on the sphere when the negatively-charged rod is near.
answer_text: Due to electrostatic induction, when the negatively-charged rod is brought near the uncharged metal sphere, the free electrons in the sphere are repelled to the side furthest from the rod (the right surface, near point X) by the like negative charges of the rod. This leaves an excess of positive charges on the side closer to the rod (the left surface). Therefore, the left surface of the sphere becomes positively charged, and the right surface (near point X) becomes negatively charged. The sphere as a whole remains electrically neutral, with an equal number of positive and negative induced charges.

context_text: An uncharged metal-coated sphere hangs from an insulating thread. A negatively-charged plastic rod is brought near the sphere, and the sphere is attracted to the rod. When the rod is near, positive charges are induced on the side of the sphere closer to the rod, and negative charges are induced on the side further from the rod.
question_text: (ii) Describe and explain why the uncharged sphere is attracted to the negatively-charged rod.
answer_text: When the negatively-charged rod is brought near the sphere, it repels the free electrons within the sphere to the far side (right side), inducing a net positive charge on the near side (left side) and a net negative charge on the far side. The attractive force between the negatively-charged rod and the induced positive charges on the near side of the sphere is stronger than the repulsive force between the negatively-charged rod and the induced negative charges on the far side of the sphere, because the positive charges are closer to the rod. This results in a net attractive force, causing the sphere to be attracted to the rod.

context_text: An electrical circuit includes a cell with an electromotive force (e.m.f.) of 6.0 V. The circuit consists of a 2.8 Ω resistor connected in series with a parallel combination of two resistors: a 3.6 Ω resistor and a variable resistor X. An ammeter is placed in the main circuit.
question_text: (a) The resistance of the variable resistor X is set to 1.8 Ω. Determine (i) the total resistance of the circuit,
answer_text:
First, calculate the equivalent resistance of the parallel combination (R_p) of the 3.6 Ω resistor and the variable resistor X (1.8 Ω):
1/R_p = 1/3.6 + 1/1.8 = 1/3.6 + 2/3.6 = 3/3.6 = 1/1.2
R_p = 1.2 Ω.
Now, calculate the total resistance of the circuit (R_total) by adding the series resistor (2.8 Ω) to the parallel equivalent resistance:
R_total = 2.8 Ω + 1.2 Ω = 4.0 Ω.
The total resistance of the circuit is 4.0 Ω.

context_text: In the circuit from Q7, a 2.8 Ω resistor is in series with a parallel combination of a 3.6 Ω resistor and a variable resistor X. The electromotive force (e.m.f.) is 6.0 V. The resistance of the variable resistor X is increased.
question_text: (b) The resistance of X is increased. Explain why the p.d. across the 2.8 Ω resistor changes.
answer_text: When the resistance of X increases, the equivalent resistance of the parallel combination (3.6 Ω and X) also increases. Consequently, the total resistance of the entire circuit (which includes the 2.8 Ω resistor in series with the parallel combination) increases. According to Ohm's Law (I = V/R), if the total resistance increases while the e.m.f. (V) remains constant, the total current (I) flowing through the circuit decreases. Since the 2.8 Ω resistor is in series with the main circuit, the current flowing through it also decreases. The potential difference (p.d.) across the 2.8 Ω resistor is given by V = IR, so a decrease in current I will lead to a decrease in the p.d. across the 2.8 Ω resistor.

context_text: In the circuit from Q7, a 2.8 Ω resistor is in series with a parallel combination of a 3.6 Ω resistor and a variable resistor X. The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery is 6.0 V. A piece of copper wire of negligible resistance is connected between points P and Q. Point P is after the 2.8 Ω resistor, and point Q is after the parallel combination. Connecting P and Q with a negligible resistance wire effectively shorts out the parallel combination of the 3.6 Ω and X resistors.
question_text: (c) A a piece of copper wire of negligible resistance is connected to point P and Q. Determine the current measured by the ammeter.
answer_text:
When a copper wire of negligible resistance is connected across points P and Q, it shorts out the parallel combination of the 3.6 Ω and X resistors. This means that almost all the current will flow through the copper wire, effectively bypassing the parallel resistors. The total resistance of the circuit then becomes just the 2.8 Ω resistor (assuming the ammeter itself has negligible resistance). 
Total resistance (R_total) = 2.8 Ω.
Current (I) measured by the ammeter = e.m.f. / R_total = 6.0 V / 2.8 Ω ≈ 2.14 A.
The current measured by the ammeter is approximately 2.14 A.

context_text: Fig. 8.1 shows a small compass on a laboratory bench, with its needle pointing upwards. Fig. 8.2 shows a stationary bar magnet (N-pole on the left, S-pole on the right) on a laboratory bench. Three small compasses are placed around the magnet: one above the N-pole, one to the right of the S-pole, and one below the magnet near its center.
question_text: (a) State the material from which the compass needle in Fig. 8.1 is made.
answer_text: The compass needle in Fig. 8.1 is made of steel.

context_text: Fig. 8.2 shows a bar magnet with its N-pole on the left and S-pole on the right. Three small compasses are placed around it: one directly above the N-pole, one directly to the right of the S-pole, and one below the magnet, slightly to the right of its center.
question_text: (b) On Fig. 8.2, the compasses are placed within the magnetic field of the magnet. Sketch the positions of the compass needles.
answer_text:
The compass needles will align with the magnetic field lines. Magnetic field lines emerge from the N-pole and enter the S-pole.
- The compass above the N-pole would point generally upwards and slightly right, away from the N-pole.
- The compass to the right of the S-pole would point generally left, towards the S-pole.
- The compass below the magnet near the center would point from left to right, following the field lines curving from the N-pole to the S-pole.

context_text: An unmagnetized iron bar (PQ) is placed near a bar magnet. The magnet has its N-pole on the left and S-pole on the right. The magnet is moved slowly to the right. When the magnet is at a short distance from the iron bar, the iron bar moves very quickly to the left, towards the magnet. Iron is a soft magnetic material.
question_text: (c) Explain why the iron bar is attracted to the magnet.
answer_text: When the bar magnet is brought near the unmagnetized iron bar, the iron bar becomes an induced magnet due to magnetic induction. The end of the iron bar closer to the N-pole of the permanent magnet will have a S-pole induced in it, and the further end will have an N-pole induced. Since unlike poles attract, the induced S-pole of the iron bar is strongly attracted to the N-pole of the permanent magnet. The attractive force between the closer unlike poles is stronger than any repulsive force between the further like poles, resulting in a net attractive force that pulls the iron bar towards the magnet.

context_text: A horizontal current-carrying wire PQ is placed in the gap between the N-pole and S-pole of a permanent magnet. The N-pole is at the bottom, and the S-pole is at the top. The current in wire PQ flows from left to right.
question_text: (a) Indicate on Fig 9.1, with an arrow, the direction of the force acting on the wire PQ.
answer_text:
Using Fleming's Left-Hand Rule:
1. The magnetic field (B) goes from the N-pole (bottom) to the S-pole (top), so it is directed upwards.
2. The current (I) in wire PQ flows from left to right.
3. Therefore, the force (F) acting on the wire will be directed outwards, perpendicularly out of the plane of the paper.

context_text: A current-carrying wire PQ is placed in a magnetic field between the N-pole and S-pole of a permanent magnet. The force on the wire is given by F = BIL, where B is the magnetic field strength, I is the current, and L is the length of the wire in the field.
question_text: (b) State the effect on wire PQ of increasing the strength of the magnetic field in the gap by using stronger magnet.
answer_text: Increasing the strength of the magnetic field (B) in the gap, by using a stronger magnet, will result in a greater force acting on the wire PQ. This means the wire will move further outwards or with greater acceleration if allowed to move.

context_text: A current-carrying wire PQ is placed in a magnetic field, experiencing a force. The direction of this force is determined by Fleming's Left-Hand Rule, which depends on the direction of the magnetic field and the direction of the current.
question_text: (c) State one modification that can be made to reverse the direction of the force.
answer_text:
To reverse the direction of the force on the wire, one can either:
1. Reverse the direction of the current in the wire (e.g., by swapping the terminals of the power supply).
2. Reverse the direction of the magnetic field (e.g., by swapping the N-pole and S-pole of the magnet).

context_text: A car's motion is represented by a speed-time graph. From t=0 to t=1s, the speed is constant at 30 m/s (reaction time phase). From t=1s to t=5s, the speed decreases linearly from 30 m/s to 0 m/s (braking phase). The total mass of the car is 800 kg.
question_text: (a) State the energy change that occurs as the car brakes.
answer_text: As the car brakes, its kinetic energy (energy of motion) is converted into other forms of energy, primarily heat energy (due to friction between the brake pads and discs/drums) and sound energy (from the braking process).

context_text: The power supply to the heater is turned off, and the water in the cup begins to cool. This is a conceptual question about heat transfer by convection in the air.
question_text: (d) The student turns off the power supply and the water cools. Describe and explain how convection in the air causes the water to cool.
answer_text: As the water cools, thermal energy is transferred from the warm water to the layer of air directly above its surface through conduction and evaporation. This heated air becomes less dense and rises. Cooler, denser air from the surroundings then moves in to replace the rising warm air. This continuous circulation of air, where warm air rises and cool air sinks, creates a convection current. This convection current continuously carries away heat from the water surface, causing the water to cool down.

context_text: An alarm system uses an electromagnet to control a soft iron contact. When the switch is closed, current flows through the electromagnet's coil. The electromagnet is positioned over the soft iron contact. The diagram shows the coil wound such that if current flows from the positive terminal of the power supply, around the coil, then the Right-Hand Grip Rule indicates that the top of the electromagnet (point X) becomes a South pole, and the bottom becomes a North pole.
question_text: (a) When the switch is closed as shown in Fig. 12.1, indicate the pole at the top of the electromagnet, X.
answer_text: When the switch is closed, current flows through the electromagnet. By applying the Right-Hand Grip Rule to the coil (curling fingers in the direction of current flow), the thumb points downwards, indicating that the bottom end of the electromagnet is a North pole and the top end (X) is a South pole.

context_text: In the alarm system, when switch S is closed, the electromagnet needs to be strong enough to attract and hold the soft iron contact in its raised position. If the electromagnet is not strong enough to maintain this position, the system will not function correctly.
question_text: (c) If when S is closed and the electromagnet is not strong enough to maintain the position of the iron contact as shown in Fig. 12.1, suggest one modification that can be made to the circuit.
answer_text:
To increase the strength of the electromagnet (and thus its attractive force) so it can maintain the position of the iron contact, one can:
1. Increase the number of turns in the electromagnet's coil.
2. Increase the current flowing through the electromagnet (e.g., by increasing the e.m.f. of the power supply/cells).
3. Reduce the gap between the electromagnet and the iron contact (e.g., by shifting the lower part of the circuit or the iron contact higher).

context_text: Fig. 12.2 shows the enlarged view of the uniform iron contact, which is a horizontal bar pivoted at its left end. The stopper is positioned at 6.0 cm from the pivot, supporting the contact from below.
question_text: (ii) Indicate with an arrow and label F_s on Fig. 12.2, the force acting on iron contact by the stopper.
answer_text: The stopper supports the iron contact by exerting an upward force on it at the point of contact. An arrow labeled 'Fs' should be drawn vertically upwards from the point where the stopper touches the iron contact (6.0 cm from the pivot).

context_text: Fig. 12.2 shows the uniform iron contact, pivoted at its left end. Its weight is 1.0 N (from 12d-i). The iron contact is uniform, so its center of gravity is at its midpoint. If the stopper is at 6.0 cm from the pivot, the midpoint (CG) is at 3.0 cm from the pivot. The attraction force from the electromagnet is 5.0 N, acting upwards at 4.0 cm from the pivot. The stopper exerts an upward force F_s at 6.0 cm from the pivot.
question_text: (iii) Given that the attraction force due to the electromagnet is 5.0 N, calculate the force acting on the iron contact by the stopper F_s.
answer_text:
Assuming the iron contact is in equilibrium (not rotating), the Principle of Moments can be applied about the pivot.
Anti-clockwise moment = Force from electromagnet × distance from pivot = 5.0 N × 4.0 cm = 20 Ncm.
Clockwise moments = (Weight of iron contact × distance from pivot to CG) + (Force from stopper F_s × distance from pivot to stopper).
The weight (1.0 N) acts at the CG, which is at 3.0 cm from the pivot (midpoint of the section up to the stopper, assuming the stopper position defines the relevant length of the bar section).
Clockwise moments = (1.0 N × 3.0 cm) + (F_s × 6.0 cm) = 3 Ncm + 6.0 F_s Ncm.
For equilibrium: 20 Ncm = 3 Ncm + 6.0 F_s Ncm
17 Ncm = 6.0 F_s Ncm
F_s = 17 / 6.0 ≈ 2.83 N.
The force acting on the iron contact by the stopper F_s is approximately 2.83 N.

context_text: The alarm system uses an electromagnet and a soft iron contact to operate a bell. Soft iron is a temporary magnet; it gets magnetized when current flows and demagnetizes when current stops. The system works by having the soft iron contact fall and ring the bell when the electromagnet demagnetizes.
question_text: (e) If a technician accidentally replaced the iron contact with a steel contact, will the system work? Explain.
answer_text:
No, the system would not work as intended if the iron contact is replaced with a steel contact.
Explanation: Steel is a hard magnetic material, meaning it retains its magnetism even after the magnetizing field is removed. When the switch S is closed, the electromagnet would magnetize the steel contact. However, when the switch S is opened and the electromagnet demagnetizes, the steel contact would remain magnetized. This permanent magnetism would cause the steel contact to stay attracted to the electromagnet, preventing it from falling and closing the bell circuit. Consequently, the bell would not ring, and the alarm system would fail to activate.

The springy copper strip is connected to A and BC. The iron armature is positioned to be attracted by the iron core when the coil is energized.
question_text: Describe how the circuit breaker works and state how it is reset.
answer_text: When current becomes too large, the electromagnet becomes strong and attracts the iron armature more. This will cause the springy copper strip to be released, resulting in an open circuit. The iron armature will then return to its original position.
