The question asks to explain at which position, X or Y, should slider P be for the largest voltmeter reading.
question_text: Explain at which position, X or Y, should slider P be for the largest voltmeter reading.
answer_text: The slider will need to move towards Y (or be at Y). The resistance of the potentiometer across the voltmeter (i.e., between X and P) will be the largest at Y, and hence by the potential divider concept, the voltmeter reading will be the largest.

context_text: Fig. 7.1 shows a magnetic relay that uses circuit X to switch on or off circuit Y. The relay consists of a coil around a soft iron core, a soft iron armature pivoted at one end, a metal strip, and contacts P and Q. Circuit X is connected to the coil via a switch S. Circuit Y is connected to contacts P and Q. The question asks to describe how circuit Y will be closed when switch S is closed.
question_text: Describe how circuit Y will be closed when the switch S is closed.
answer_text: When the switch S is closed, current flows through the coil in circuit X, and the soft iron core is magnetised, becoming an electromagnet. The soft iron armature is attracted to the electromagnet (due to induced magnetism). The soft iron armature rotates in an anti-clockwise direction about the pivot, causing the top end of the armature to push the lower metal strip. This causes contact P to come into contact with Q, thus closing circuit Y.

context_text: Fig. 7.1 shows a magnetic relay. The question asks to explain what effect replacing the soft iron core with a steel bar will have on the ability of circuit X to switch on and off circuit Y.
question_text: The soft iron core is replaced with a steel bar. Explain what effect this has on the ability of circuit X to switch on and off circuit Y.
answer_text: Steel is a hard magnetic material. When magnetised by current in the coil, it will retain magnetism (high retentivity) even when switch S is opened. Hence, the soft iron armature will be permanently attracted to the steel bar even when switch S is opened. This means contacts P and Q will remain in contact, and circuit Y will remain closed even when switch S is opened. The relay will no longer be able to switch circuit Y on and off.

context_text: Fig. 8.1 shows two coils, P and Q, placed near to each other. Coil P is connected to a DC supply and switch S. Coil Q is connected to a galvanometer (device X). The question asks to explain how an electromotive force (e.m.f) is induced in coil Q when switch S is just closed.
question_text: Explain how an electromotive force (e.m.f) is induced in coil Q when switch S is just closed.
answer_text: When switch S is just closed, current flows through coil P, which produces a magnetic field. This magnetic field passes through coil Q, and as the current in P increases from zero to a steady value, the magnetic field strength (and thus magnetic flux linkage) through coil Q increases. By Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction, a changing magnetic flux linkage through coil Q induces an e.m.f. in coil Q.

context_text: Fig. 8.1 shows two coils, P and Q. Coil P is connected to a DC supply and switch S. The direction of windings for coil P is shown. The question asks to state the polarity of the right end of coil P when switch S is closed.
question_text: State the polarity of the right end of coil P when the switch S is closed.
answer_text: South pole

context_text: Fig. 8.1 shows two coils, P and Q. Coil P is connected to a DC supply and switch S. Coil Q is connected to a galvanometer (device X). When switch S is just closed, the right end of coil P becomes a South pole. The question asks to explain the direction of the induced current flowing through device X when switch S is just closed.
question_text: Explain the direction of induced current flowing through device X when switch S is just closed.
answer_text: When switch S is just closed, the left end of coil Q experiences an increase in magnetic field (as the right end of coil P becomes a South pole, effectively a South pole entering the left end of coil Q). By Lenz's Law, the induced current in coil Q will produce a magnetic field that opposes this increase. To oppose an incoming South pole, the left end of coil Q must become a South pole. Using the right-hand grip rule for coil Q, for the left end to be a South pole, the induced current must flow from left to right through device X.

context_text: Fig. 11.1 shows a wave on a rope tied to a ring which can move up and down along a vertical metal pole. The question states that sound is heard when the ring moves along the vertical metal pole.
question_text: Sound is heard when the ring moves along the vertical metal pole. Explain how the metal pole produce sound waves in the air and how these waves are transmitted through the air.
answer_text: The metal pole vibrates. This displaces the layer of air molecules adjacent to the ground and in turns displace the neighbouring air molecules. The air molecules move about their undisturbed positions, and this set up a series of compressions and rarefactions in the air. The sound wave travels in the form of longitudinal wave from the ground towards the listeners.

context_text: Fig. 12.1 shows an electrical kettle containing water. The kettle has a metal outer casing and a heating element inside. It is connected to a power socket via a switch. The question asks to describe, using ideas about energy transfer, how the electrical kettle heats up the water when the switch is closed.
question_text: Describe, using ideas about energy transfer, how the electrical kettle heats up the water when the switch is closed.
answer_text: When current flows through the heating element, the heating effect due to current heats up the heating element. Energy is transferred from the heating element to the neighbouring water via conduction. Water heats up and rises to the top of the kettle. The cold water the top of kettle sinks. and in turn heat up by the heating element. The cycle repeats and set up convection current and heat up the entire water in the kettle.

context_text: Object X falls freely from rest for 3 seconds. Object Y also falls freely from rest for 6 seconds. Both objects are undergoing constant gravitational acceleration 'g'.
question_text: Which of the following statements is true? A Y falls half as far as X. B Y falls twice as far as X. C Y falls three times as far as X. D Y falls four times as far as X.
answer_text: D. Distance fall by X = ½ (g)(3)^2 = 45 m. Distance fall by Y = ½ (g)(6)^2 = 180 m. Since 180 m is four times 45 m, Y falls four times as far as X.

context_text: A U-tube manometer contains two liquids, A and B. Liquid A is on the left arm and liquid B on the right. 0.4 m of liquid A and 0.3 m of liquid B are shown, with the interface level being the reference. The level of liquid A (left) is 0.4 m above the interface, and the level of liquid B (right) is 0.3 m above the interface. The density of liquid A is ρ. Atmospheric pressure is applied to both open ends. At the same horizontal level in the continuous liquid, the pressure must be equal. In this case, at the level of the interface, the pressure from liquid A column and atmosphere must equal the pressure from liquid B column and atmosphere.
question_text: What is the density of liquid B if the density of liquid A is ρ? A 4ρ/3, C 4ρ/7, B 3ρ/4, D 3ρ/7
answer_text: A. According to the marking scheme's calculation, 'Pressure at A = Pressure at B' (at the interface level). ρ_A * g * h_A = ρ_B * g * h_B. Given h_A = 0.4 m and h_B = 0.3 m (from the interface), and density of A is ρ: ρ * g * 0.4 = ρ_B * g * 0.3. Simplifying, ρ * 0.4 = ρ_B * 0.3. Therefore, Density of B (ρ_B) = (0.4 / 0.3) ρ = (4/3) ρ.

context_text: A mercury barometer is shown with a scale from 0 cm to 90 cm. The mercury level in the tube is at the 74 cm mark, and there is a vacuum above it. Point X is located within the mercury column at the 22 cm mark.
question_text: What is the pressure measured at X? A 16 cm Hg, C 52 cm Hg, B 22 cm Hg, D 62 cm Hg
answer_text: C. The pressure at point X is due to the column of mercury above it. The mercury level in the barometer is at 74 cm. Point X is at the 22 cm mark. Therefore, the height of the mercury column above X is (74 cm - 22 cm) = 52 cm. The pressure at X is equivalent to 52 cm Hg.

context_text: A graph shows the electromotive force (e.m.f., ε/V) of a thermocouple as a function of temperature (θ/°C). The e.m.f. increases from 0 V at 0 °C, reaches a maximum, and then decreases. B The relationship between ε and θ is non-linear. C The thermocouple does not always indicate a unique value of e.m.f.. D The e.m.f. has not been measured using temperatures using the Kelvin scale.
answer_text: C. According to the marking scheme, 'The relationship between ε and θ does not give a unique value.' The graph clearly shows that for a given e.m.f. value within the marked 'Temperature range', there are two possible corresponding temperatures, making the thermocouple unsuitable for unambiguous temperature measurement in that range. context_text: Satish mixes 30 g of liquid Q and 50 g of liquid R. The initial temperature of liquid Q is 20 °C and liquid R is 90 °C. The final temperature of the mixture is 45 °C. Assuming no heat loss to the surroundings, the heat gained by liquid Q equals the heat lost by liquid R. The formula for heat change is Q = mcΔT, where m is mass, c is specific heat capacity, and ΔT is temperature change. The question asks for the ratio of heat capacity (mc) of liquid Q to liquid R.
question_text: What is the ratio of heat capacity of liquid Q to heat capacity of liquid R if the initial temperature of liquid Q and R are 20 °C and 90 °C respectively? A 9/5, C 1/3, B 5/9, D 3/1
answer_text: A. Heat gained by Q = Heat lost by R. (m_Q * c_Q) * ΔT_Q = (m_R * c_R) * ΔT_R. Let the heat capacity of liquid Q be C_Q = m_Q * c_Q and for liquid R be C_R = m_R * c_R. So, C_Q * (45 °C - 20 °C) = C_R * (90 °C - 45 °C). C_Q * (25 °C) = C_R * (45 °C). The ratio C_Q / C_R = 45 / 25 = 9/5.

question_text: Which point indicates that it is the centre of rarefaction? A A, B B, C C, D D
answer_text: B. The center of rarefaction is the point where the pressure is at its minimum (lowest pressure) relative to the equilibrium pressure. Point B clearly shows the lowest pressure on the graph.

context_text: Ren Jie is observing a musical instrument through a plane mirror. The mirror is positioned diagonally on the table. The musical instrument is located in the top-right region of the diagram, in front of the mirror. Four possible image locations (A, B, C, D) are marked.
question_text: Where is the position of the image of musical instrument?
answer_text: C. For a plane mirror, the image of an object is formed behind the mirror at the same perpendicular distance from the mirror as the object is in front of it. The image is virtual, upright, and laterally inverted. Point C is positioned such that it represents a virtual image consistent with reflection by a diagonal plane mirror. The marking scheme states 'Image of object is perpendicular distance away from the mirror (double reflection)'.

context_text: An object is placed in front of a thin converging lens on its principal axis. A ray of light, labeled P, originates from the object and travels parallel to the principal axis before striking the lens. The diagram shows four possible paths (A, B, C, D) for this ray after it passes through the lens. Option B shows the ray refracting through the focal point F on the opposite side of the lens.
question_text: Which direction shows correctly the path ray P will take after it passes through the lens?
answer_text: B. A fundamental ray tracing rule for a converging lens states that any ray traveling parallel to the principal axis before hitting the lens will refract through the principal focal point (F) on the opposite side of the lens. The marking scheme states, 'After locating the image of object, draw the ray P towards the tip of the image arrow' which corresponds to option B.

context_text: The question asks to calculate the wavelength of an electromagnetic wave with a frequency of 6.0 x 10⁵ GHz. The speed of light (c) is approximately 3.0 x 10⁸ m/s. The relationship between speed, frequency, and wavelength is c = fλ.
question_text: What is the wavelength of an electromagnetic wave that has a frequency of 6.0 x 10⁵ GHz? A 5.0 x 10⁻¹³ m, C 5.0 x 10⁻⁷ m, B 5.0 x 10⁻¹⁰ m, D 5.0 x 10⁻⁴ m
answer_text: C. First, convert the frequency from GHz to Hz: 6.0 x 10⁵ GHz = 6.0 x 10⁵ x 10⁹ Hz = 6.0 x 10¹⁴ Hz. Then use the formula λ = c / f. λ = (3.0 x 10⁸ m/s) / (6.0 x 10¹⁴ Hz) = 0.5 x 10⁻⁶ m = 5.0 x 10⁻⁷ m.

context_text: The question asks to identify which object, after being prepared, will not attract tiny pieces of paper. This relates to static electricity. Objects can attract small pieces of paper if they are charged (either positively or negatively). Metals are good conductors and tend to lose any induced charge quickly to the surroundings, while insulators can retain charge.
question_text: Which object will not attract tiny pieces of paper? A a metal knife sharpened with a knife sharpener, B a ceramic spoon wiped with a kitchen cloth, C a plastic comb combed through dry hair, D a wooden pencil rubbed with an eraser
answer_text: A. A metal knife is a good conductor of electricity. Even if a charge were induced or transferred during sharpening, it would quickly discharge (lose its excess electrons or gain electrons from the surroundings) due to contact with the hand or air, thus preventing it from attracting tiny pieces of paper. Ceramic, plastic, and wood are insulators and can retain a static charge.

context_text: Yida spends 6 hours each night revising. He uses two 100 W light bulbs in his room. His weekly electricity bill for the room is $3.00 (300 cents). The unit cost of electricity is 24 cents per kilowatt-hour (kWh). The question asks for the amount saved if these lights were not used.
question_text: How much saving would he have in a week if a unit of electricity cost 24 cents? A 270 cents, C 199 cents, B 201 cents, D 98 cents
answer_text: D. First, calculate the total power consumed by the two bulbs: 2 bulbs × 100 W/bulb = 200 W = 0.2 kW. Time spent studying per week = 6 hours/night × 7 nights/week = 42 hours. Energy consumed per week = Power × Time = 0.2 kW × 42 hours = 8.4 kWh. Cost of this energy = 8.4 kWh × 24 cents/kWh = 201.6 cents. Total saving = (Original bill for lights) - (Calculated cost of lights) = 300 cents - 201.6 cents = 98.4 cents.

context_text: A compass is placed inside a closed iron cylinder on a table. The north pole of a permanent magnet is brought near the cylinder from the right side. Iron is a ferromagnetic material and can shield objects inside it from external magnetic fields.
question_text: In which direction does the needle of the compass point? A away from the permanent magnet, B opposite direction, C original direction, D towards the permanent magnet
answer_text: C. An iron cylinder acts as a magnetic shield (or screen). It provides a path of low magnetic reluctance, diverting most of the external magnetic field lines through itself and away from the interior space. Therefore, the compass inside the iron cylinder will be largely unaffected by the external permanent magnet and will continue to point in its original direction (likely aligning with Earth's magnetic field). The marking scheme states, 'The compass needed is not being influenced by the field strength of the permanent magnet.'

context_text: A loudspeaker diagram shows a front view of its components, including an outer South pole, an inner North pole, and a coil positioned between them. The current is flowing in the speaker's coil in an anticlockwise direction.
question_text: If the current is flowing in the speaker's coil in an anticlockwise direction as shown, what is the direction the coil that it will move? A To the right. C To the left. B Out of the page. D Into the page.
answer_text: D. According to the marking scheme, 'Using Fleming's Left Hand rule, the coil will move into the paper.' To apply Fleming's Left Hand Rule: The magnetic field lines from the North pole (inner) go radially outwards to the South pole (outer). If the current is anticlockwise, consider a segment of the coil at the top. Current flows leftwards. The magnetic field is upwards. Applying Fleming's Left Hand Rule (Forefinger = Field, Middle finger = Current, Thumb = Force): Field (Up), Current (Left) results in Force (Into the page). For a segment at the bottom, current flows rightwards, field is downwards, resulting in Force (Into the page). Therefore, the entire coil moves into the page.

context_text: The size of a virus is approximately the size of ultraviolet (UV) wavelength.
question_text: State the wavelength of the ultraviolet in metres.
answer_text: The wavelength of ultraviolet typically ranges from 10⁻⁸ m to 10⁻⁷ m.

context_text: Alex completed a cross-country race by running 5 km around a reservoir. The total distance covered is 5 km, but he returned to his starting point (round a reservoir), meaning his net change in position from start to end is zero.
question_text: State what is meant by displacement of 5 km.
answer_text: Displacement is a vector quantity that describes the shortest distance from the initial position to the final position, and it must include a specific direction. So, 'displacement of 5 km' means that 5 km was travelled in a stated direction.

context_text: Alex ran a 5 km cross-country competition round a reservoir, completing it in 20 minutes. Clement stated Alex's velocity was 15 km/h.
question_text: In the paragraph above, state and explain the two errors found.
answer_text:
1. Error in Displacement vs. Distance: Alex ran 'round a reservoir', implying he returned to his starting point. Therefore, his displacement would be 0 km, not 5 km. He covered a total 'distance' of 5 km. The statement incorrectly uses 'displacement' for a round trip.
2. Error in Velocity vs. Speed: As Alex's displacement is 0 km (for a round trip), his average velocity (displacement/time) would be 0 km/h. Clement incorrectly stated his 'velocity' as 15 km/h. This 15 km/h would actually be Alex's average 'speed' (distance/time = 5 km / (20/60) h = 15 km/h).

context_text:
The velocity-time graph for Alex's run shows velocity (m/s) on the y-axis and time (min) on the x-axis. The graph has three segments:
- From t=0 min to t=13 min: velocity increases linearly from 0 m/s to 5 m/s.
- From t=13 min to t=16 min: velocity increases linearly from 5 m/s to 9 m/s.
- From t=16 min to t=20 min: velocity decreases linearly from 9 m/s to 0 m/s.
Acceleration is represented by the gradient (slope) of the velocity-time graph. The greatest acceleration occurs during the period with the steepest gradient (largest magnitude of slope).
question_text: State and explain the period at which Alex was running with the greatest acceleration.
answer_text: Alex is running with the greatest acceleration between 13 min and 16 min. This is because the change in velocity per unit time (the gradient of the velocity-time graph) is the highest during this duration, making it the steepest segment of the graph. (Note: Visually, the segment from 16 min to 20 min has a steeper negative gradient, indicating a greater magnitude of deceleration/acceleration, but the marking scheme specifies 13-16 min.)

context_text: The velocity-time graph for Alex's run (from Q2c.i) shows that the period of greatest acceleration, according to the marking scheme, is between 13 min and 16 min. In this period, the velocity increases from 5 m/s to 9 m/s. Alex's mass is 50 kg. The question asks to calculate the greatest resultant force Alex experiences.
question_text: Calculate the greatest resultant force that Alex is experiencing. Take Alex's mass as 50 kg.
answer_text:
To calculate the greatest resultant force (F), use Newton's second law: F = ma. First, determine the highest acceleration (a) from the specified period:
According to the marking scheme's calculation for the highest acceleration period (13-16 min), the velocity changes from 5 m/s to 8 m/s (not 9 m/s as per graph visual, but using marking scheme's implied value) over 3 minutes. 
Acceleration (a) = (change in velocity) / (change in time) = (8 m/s - 5 m/s) / (3 min * 60 s/min) = 3 m/s / 180 s = 0.0167 m/s².
Resultant force (F) = mass (m) × acceleration (a) = 50 kg × 0.0167 m/s² = 0.833 N.

context_text: Andres is trying to open a door. A diagram shows the door with a hinge, and a force F applied at a distance 'r' from the hinge. The angle between the force vector F and the line connecting the hinge to the point of application is θ. For efficient opening, a larger moment (turning effect) is desired for a given force, or a smaller force for a given moment.
question_text: State and explain two ways how Andres could open the door more efficiently.
answer_text:
1. Push at a greater distance from the hinge: Andres should push the door as far as possible from the hinge (maximize 'r'). The moment is calculated as force × perpendicular distance from the pivot. A larger perpendicular distance for the same force will produce a larger moment, making it easier to turn the door.
2. Push perpendicularly to the door: Andres should apply the force perpendicular to the plane of the door (i.e., ensure the angle θ = 90°). This maximizes the perpendicular distance component for a given force application point, leading to the largest possible moment. Pushing at a greater perpendicular distance from the hinge means that a lower force is needed to produce the same opening moment, thus increasing efficiency.

context_text: The question asks for the definition and formula of 'moment'. A moment is a measure of the turning effect of a force.
question_text: State what is moment and its formula.
answer_text: Moment is the turning effect of a force about a pivot point. Its formula is given by the product of the magnitude of the force applied and the perpendicular distance from the pivot to the line of action of the force (Moment = Force × perpendicular distance).

context_text: The question asks for reasons why moment is not measured in Joules (J). Both moment (N m) and energy (J) have units that can be expressed as force times distance, but they represent different physical quantities.
question_text: State two reasons why moment is not measured in Joule.
answer_text:
1. Physical Nature: Moment represents a turning effect or torque (a vector quantity), while Joule is the unit for work or energy, which is a scalar quantity. Although both involve force and distance, the 'distance' in moment is a perpendicular distance from a pivot, whereas the 'distance' in work is the distance moved *in the direction of the force*.
2. Vector vs. Scalar: Moment is a vector quantity (it has magnitude and direction of rotation), while work/energy is a scalar quantity (only magnitude). Therefore, their units cannot be the same, despite superficially appearing similar (N m vs. J).

context_text: A manometer is connected to a gas chamber. The left arm is open to the atmosphere, and the right arm is connected to the gas chamber. The manometer contains mercury. The mercury level in the atmospheric arm is 15 cm higher than the mercury level in the gas chamber arm. Atmospheric pressure is 76 cm Hg, and the density of mercury is 13 600 kg/m³. Pressure is calculated as ρgh.
question_text: State the pressure found in the gas chamber in Pa.
answer_text:
The marking scheme's calculation for gas chamber pressure: 'Pressure of atmosphere is lower than gas pressure by 15 cm Hg. Pressure gas = 76 + 15 = 91 cm Hg. Pressure = ρgh = 13600 x 10 x 0.91 = 123 760 Pa = 124 000 Pa.'
(Note: The visual diagram shows the atmospheric side's mercury level *higher* than the gas chamber side's, which implies that the gas pressure in the chamber is *less* than atmospheric pressure (P_gas = P_atm - 15 cm Hg = 61 cm Hg). However, the marking scheme's explanation states that gas pressure is *higher* than atmospheric pressure and calculates P_gas = 76 cm Hg + 15 cm Hg = 91 cm Hg. Following the marking scheme's calculation based on 91 cm Hg, the pressure in Pascals is: P = 13600 kg/m³ × 10 N/kg × 0.91 m = 123760 Pa, which rounds to 124000 Pa.)

context_text: A hydraulic system is shown (Fig. 5.2). A small force exerted on a small piston (A) is used to generate a larger force on a larger piston (B), pushing it upwards. This system operates based on Pascal's principle and the incompressibility of the hydraulic fluid. The principle of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed or transferred.
question_text: Fig. 5.2 shows a hydraulic system works by exerting a force on the piston A which in turn pushes the piston B upwards with a larger force. Explain how the principle of conservation of energy is applicable in the hydraulic system.
answer_text:
The principle of conservation of energy is applicable because the work done on piston A must be equal to the work done by piston B (assuming an ideal system with no energy losses due to friction or heat):
1. Incompressibility of liquid: Since the hydraulic liquid is virtually incompressible, the volume of liquid displaced by piston A must be equal to the volume of liquid that moves piston B.
2. Area-Displacement Relationship: As piston B has a larger cross-sectional area than piston A, for the same volume of liquid displaced, piston A must travel a larger distance downwards compared to the distance piston B travels upwards (Volume = Area × distance).
3. Work Done: Work done = Force × distance. If a small force (F_A) is applied to piston A over a large distance (d_A), it performs work (W_A = F_A × d_A). This work is transferred through the fluid. Since the pressure is transmitted equally throughout the fluid (Pascal's Principle), and piston B has a larger area (A_B > A_A), it experiences a larger force (F_B = P × A_B).
4. Energy Conservation: For energy to be conserved (W_A = W_B), the larger force F_B on piston B must act over a smaller distance (d_B). Thus, a small force applied over a large distance at piston A results in a large force over a small distance at piston B, demonstrating the conservation of work (and thus energy) within the system.

context_text: From the previous calculation, the gravitational potential energy at position B is 0.1 J. The bob is released from rest at B and swings down to position A. According to the principle of conservation of energy, the loss in potential energy as the bob swings from B to A is converted into kinetic energy at A.
question_text: Calculate the velocity at which the bob will pass through A.
answer_text:
Using the principle of conservation of energy, Loss in GPE from B to A = Gain in KE at A.
Loss in GPE = 0.1 J (from previous calculation).
Gain in KE = ½mv².
So, 0.1 J = ½ × 0.20 kg × v².
0.1 = 0.1 × v².
v² = 1.
v = 1 m/s (since velocity is a speed in this context, it's positive).

context_text: The calculation of velocity at position A (in 6b) relies on the principle of conservation of energy, specifically converting potential energy to kinetic energy.
question_text: State the assumption made in (b).
answer_text: The assumption made in the calculation is that no energy is lost during the swing from B to A. This means that all the gravitational potential energy lost is converted into kinetic energy, implying negligible air resistance and no friction at the pivot. In other words, the total mechanical energy of the pendulum is conserved.

context_text: The question asks for the definition of an electric field. An electric field is a region in space where electric forces are exerted.
question_text: Explain what is meant by electric field.
answer_text: An electric field is defined as a region in which an electric charge experiences an electric force. More specifically, it is a region where a positive test charge would experience an electrostatic force.

context_text: Fig. 7.2 shows a light uncharged metal sphere Y, which is insulated, and a light uncharged metal ball X, which is freely suspended and in contact with Y. A positively charged metal rod, Z, is moved towards sphere Y. Due to induction, charges will redistribute in the connected conducting system (X and Y).
question_text: State the charges induced on spheres X and Y in Fig. 7.2. X: Y:
answer_text:
When the positively charged rod Z is brought near sphere Y, it attracts electrons in the connected conducting system (X and Y) towards Y and repels positive charges away. Since X and Y are in contact, electrons from X will move to Y, accumulating on the side of Y closest to Z. This leaves X with a net positive charge and makes Y negatively charged on the side near Z and positively charged on the side away from Z (but overall, Y and X together form a charged system where electrons have been drawn to Y, leaving X deficient in electrons).
Therefore:
X: positive
Y: negative

context_text: Fig. 7.1 shows an uncharged metal ball X in contact with an uncharged metal sphere Y. The question asks to sketch the electric field pattern between Y and Z. However, context from Q7b and Q7d refers to Fig 7.2 where Z (positive rod) is near Y, and Y and X become charged by induction (Y negatively charged on the side closer to Z, X positively charged). Therefore, this question likely intends for the field pattern between the positively charged rod Z and the induced negatively charged part of sphere Y.
question_text: Sketch in Fig 7.1 the electric field pattern between Y and Z.
answer_text: The sketch should show electric field lines originating from the positively charged rod Z and terminating on the negatively charged surface of sphere Y. The field lines should be perpendicular to the surfaces of Z and Y, and they should be denser closer to the charges, indicating a stronger field.

context_text: Referring to Fig. 7.2, a positively charged metal rod Z is brought near sphere Y (which is in contact with sphere X). In Q7b, X becomes positive and Y becomes negative (on the side near Z). The question asks what happens when Z is brought to *touch* Y and then subsequently removed.
question_text: When Z is brought to touch Y and then removed, suggest what will happen.
answer_text: When the positively charged rod Z touches sphere Y (which is in contact with X), electrons from Y and X will be attracted to Z and transferred to it, partially or fully neutralizing Z. This process leaves both spheres X and Y with a net positive charge. When the positively charged rod Z is then removed, X and Y are left with a net positive charge, and since like charges repel, the light metal ball X will be repelled from sphere Y.

context_text: The same circuit from Q8a is used: Battery E (20.0 V), R2 (200 Ω). R1 is a variable resistor. The ammeter measures the current through R1 and R2 in series. The question asks to calculate the current through the ammeter when R1 is set at 250 Ω.
question_text: Calculate the current through the ammeter when R1 is set at 250 Ω.
answer_text: When R1 is set to 250 Ω, the total resistance in the series circuit is R_total = R1 + R2 = 250 Ω + 200 Ω = 450 Ω. The current (I) through the ammeter is given by Ohm's Law: I = E / R_total = 20.0 V / 450 Ω ≈ 0.0444 A (to 3 significant figures).

context_text: During quality control tests of a hairdryer, measurements were taken with switch S connected to contact J. The hairdryer is connected to a 230 V a.c. supply. The heating element has a resistance of 25 Ω. The temperature of air entering the hairdryer is 28 °C, and the temperature of air flowing out is 33 °C. The rate of air flow through the hairdryer is 46 g/s. The resistor R (40 Ω) and motor are in series in a parallel branch to the heating element.
question_text: Calculate the specific heat capacity of air.
answer_text:
1. Calculate the power supplied by the heating element: When the switch is at J, the heating element (25 Ω) is connected directly across the 230 V mains supply (in parallel with the motor-resistor branch). Power (P) = V² / R = (230 V)² / 25 Ω = 52900 / 25 W = 2116 W.
2. Relate power to heat gained by air: The heat produced by the heater per second (P) is equal to the heat gained by the air per second. Heat gained by air (Q) = mcΔT. Therefore, P = (mass flow rate) × c × ΔT.
3. Calculate specific heat capacity (c): Mass flow rate = 46 g/s. Temperature change (ΔT) = (33 °C - 28 °C) = 5 °C.
   2116 W = 46 g/s × c × 5 °C.
   c = 2116 / (46 × 5) = 2116 / 230 = 9.20 J/g °C.

context_text: In the hairdryer circuit (Fig 9.1), the heating element is in one branch connected to the 230V mains. The motor (fan) is in series with a resistor R (40 Ω) in another parallel branch, controlled by switch S. When switch S is connected to contact J, both the heating element and the R+motor branch are connected. When S is connected to contact K, the resistor R is bypassed, and the motor is directly connected in parallel with the heating element (and the mains).
question_text: Switch S is then connected to contact K. State and explain the change in the rate of air flowing through the hairdryer and the temperature of the air flowing out of the hairdryer, as compared to when switch S is connected to contact J.
answer_text:
When switch S is connected to contact K (bypassing resistor R):
1. Rate of air flowing: The resistance of the motor branch decreases (as resistor R is no longer in series with the motor). This leads to a lower total resistance in the motor's circuit, resulting in a higher current flowing through the motor. A higher current in the motor causes it to spin faster, increasing the fan's speed and thus increasing the rate of air flow through the hairdryer.
2. Temperature of air flowing out: The power of the heating element remains unchanged because it is connected in parallel directly to the 230 V mains supply, regardless of the switch position. However, with an increased rate of air flow (more air passing through the heating element per unit time), the same amount of heat energy from the heater is distributed among a larger mass of air (or faster moving air). Consequently, the temperature rise (ΔT) of the air will decrease, leading to a reduction in the temperature of the air flowing out of the hairdryer.

context_text: A mockup of a drop tower uses two electromagnets. Electromagnet A holds a magnetic falling mass (20 g) in place. Electromagnet B is used to create a braking force. The question asks for the magnetic force required by electromagnet B to instantly stop the 20 g falling mass.
question_text: If the falling mass has a mass of 20 g, suggest with reason the magnetic force that the electromagnet B has in order to allow the falling mass to come to rest instantly.
answer_text:
To bring the falling mass to an instant stop, electromagnet B must exert a net upward force greater than the weight of the falling mass, causing a deceleration.
1. Calculate the weight of the falling mass: Weight = mass × g = 0.020 kg × 10 N/kg = 0.2 N.
2. Determine the required magnetic force: For the mass to come to rest instantly (i.e., undergo rapid deceleration to zero velocity), the upward magnetic braking force exerted by electromagnet B must be greater than the downward weight of the mass. This creates a net upward force, causing a large negative acceleration. If the force were only equal to the weight, the mass would continue to fall at a constant velocity (if it had one), or remain at rest if initially at rest. To stop it instantly, a net upward force is needed.

context_text: Electromagnets are used to create a braking force for a falling mass. The question asks for two ways to increase the strength of an electromagnet if a larger falling mass needs to be stopped.
question_text: Suggest two ways the electromagnet can increase its strength if a larger falling mass is used.
answer_text:
The strength of an electromagnet can be increased by:
1. Increasing the number of turns: Winding more turns of wire around the core of the electromagnet increases the magnetic field strength for a given current.
2. Increasing the current: Passing a larger electric current through the coil of the electromagnet produces a stronger magnetic field.

context_text: Fig. 11.3 shows a type of motor. It includes two solenoids, PQ and RS, and a coil ABCD connected in parallel to a battery via brushes and a split-ring commutator. Current flows from the battery's positive terminal to both solenoids and the coil. Assuming current flows into P and R, and out of Q and S, we can determine polarities. Applying the right-hand grip rule to solenoid PQ, if current wraps around such that it flows into P and out Q, Q would be the South pole.
question_text: State the polarity at end Q.
answer_text: South polarity at Q. (Based on the diagram and typical solenoid construction, if current flows into the end P and out the end Q, and considering the direction of windings, Q would typically be the South pole).

context_text: The motor in Fig. 11.3 consists of solenoids PQ (Q is South pole) and RS (S is North pole), creating a magnetic field from S to Q (right to left through the coil). A coil ABCD is placed within this field and connected to a battery via a split-ring commutator. Assuming current flows into the coil through the left brush, upwards through side AB, then downwards through side CD, and out through the right brush. The question asks for the direction of rotation of the coil as seen by the observer.
question_text: State the direction of rotation of the coil as seen by the observer.
answer_text: The coil will rotate in a clockwise manner. (Note: Using Fleming's Left-Hand Rule with the deduced magnetic field from right to left (N to S) and assuming current upwards in AB and downwards in CD, the force on AB would be out of the page and the force on CD would be into the page, resulting in an anticlockwise rotation. This indicates a contradiction between the visual setup and the provided answer from the marking scheme.)

context_text: The motor in Fig. 11.3 includes a coil ABCD and a split-ring commutator. The coil is placed in a magnetic field. The question asks to explain why the coil rotates continuously.
question_text: Explain why the coil will rotate continuously.
answer_text:
The coil rotates continuously due to the action of the split-ring commutator:
1. Force on Coil Sides: As current flows through the coil, forces are exerted on its sides (e.g., AB and CD) due to the interaction between the current and the magnetic field. These forces produce a turning effect (torque) that causes the coil to rotate.
2. Role of Split-Ring Commutator: As the coil rotates and passes the vertical position (where the torque would momentarily become zero or reverse), the split-ring commutator reverses the direction of the current flowing through the coil. This reversal ensures that the direction of the forces on the coil sides also reverses relative to the coil's position in the magnetic field.
3. Continuous Torque: By reversing the current, the forces continue to produce a torque in the *same rotational direction* (e.g., always clockwise or always anticlockwise). This consistent torque prevents the coil from oscillating and ensures that it rotates continuously in one direction.

context_text: Fig. 11.4 shows current-potential difference (I-V) graphs for two light bulbs, J and K. The current (A) is on the y-axis, and potential difference (V) is on the x-axis. Both graphs are curves starting from the origin (0,0), with the slope (I/V, which is 1/R) decreasing as voltage increases. This indicates that their resistance (V/I) increases with increasing voltage/current. An ohmic conductor has a linear I-V graph passing through the origin, meaning its resistance is constant.
question_text: State, with reason, if the filament of light bulb J and K are ohmic conductors.
answer_text: No, the filaments of both light bulbs J and K are not ohmic conductors. This is because, for an ohmic conductor, the current is directly proportional to the potential difference (V ∝ I), which would result in a straight line passing through the origin on an I-V graph. However, the graphs for both bulbs J and K are curves, indicating that their resistance is not constant but changes with potential difference (typically increasing as temperature rises).

context_text: Fig. 11.4 displays the current-potential difference (I-V) graphs for light bulbs J and K. The question asks to estimate their resistances when operating at a potential difference of 0.20 V.
question_text: Estimate the resistance of bulb J and the resistance of bulb K when they are operating at V = 0.20 V.
answer_text:
To estimate the resistance (R) at V = 0.20 V, read the corresponding current (I) values from the graph and use Ohm's Law (R = V/I):
1. For bulb J: At V = 0.20 V, read the current from the graph. The current for bulb J is approximately 0.05 A. Resistance of bulb J = V / I = 0.20 V / 0.05 A = 4 Ω.
2. For bulb K: At V = 0.20 V, read the current from the graph. The current for bulb K is approximately 0.02 A. Resistance of bulb K = V / I = 0.20 V / 0.02 A = 10 Ω.

context_text: The question presents a table with applications for X-rays, ultraviolet light, and microwaves. The task is to identify the row that correctly matches these electromagnetic radiations with their common uses. Row A: X-rays (mobile phone), UV (fluorescent tube), Microwaves (intruder alarm). context_text:
A velocity-time graph shows the velocity of a sphere falling from rest through the air (y-axis) against time (x-axis). The graph starts at velocity 0 at time 0, then curves upwards and gradually flattens out, indicating the velocity increases but the rate of increase slows down, approaching a terminal velocity. Point P is located on the curved section where the velocity is still increasing, but the slope is decreasing, meaning the acceleration is positive but decreasing. The four diagrams (A, B, C, D) show a sphere with two forces acting on it: 'weight' acting downwards and 'air resistance' acting upwards.
Diagram A shows weight downwards and a very small air resistance upwards.
Diagram B shows weight downwards and air resistance upwards, with air resistance equal in magnitude to weight.
Diagram C shows weight downwards and air resistance upwards, with air resistance smaller in magnitude than weight.
Diagram D shows weight downwards and air resistance upwards, with air resistance larger in magnitude than weight.
question_text: Which diagram shows the forces acting on the sphere when it is at the velocity corresponding to point P on the graph?
answer_text: C. At point P on the velocity-time graph, the sphere is still accelerating downwards (its velocity is increasing), so there must be a net downward force. This means that the weight must be greater than the air resistance. However, the curve is flattening, indicating that the acceleration is decreasing, which implies that the air resistance is increasing and becoming more significant (closer to the weight). Diagram C correctly depicts the weight being greater than the air resistance, allowing for downward acceleration, but with air resistance being a noticeable opposing force.

context_text: A diagram illustrates a wooden block of mass 2.0 kg being pushed horizontally across a table by a 'pushing force' acting to the right. The block experiences an acceleration of 0.40 m/s² to the right. A frictional force of 20 N acts against the block's motion, meaning it acts to the left.
question_text:
If the acceleration of the block is 0.40 m/s² and the frictional force acting against the block's motion is 20 N, determine the magnitude of the pushing force.
A 0.80 N
C 20 N
B 19.2 N
D 20.8 N
answer_text:
D. According to Newton's Second Law, the net force (F_net) acting on an object is equal to its mass (m) times its acceleration (a): F_net = ma. The forces acting horizontally are the pushing force (F_push) in the direction of motion and the frictional force (F_friction) opposing the motion. So, F_net = F_push - F_friction.
Given:
Mass (m) = 2.0 kg
Acceleration (a) = 0.40 m/s²
Frictional force (F_friction) = 20 N
First, calculate the net force: F_net = 2.0 kg × 0.40 m/s² = 0.80 N.
Now, apply the net force equation: 0.80 N = F_push - 20 N.
Solve for F_push: F_push = 0.80 N + 20 N = 20.8 N.

context_text: A diagram shows a man pushing a heavy box along the ground. The man is leaning into the box, applying a force with his hands, and his feet are braced against the ground.
question_text:
In which directions do these forces act on the man?
| | force on man's hands | force on man's feet |
|---|----------------------|---------------------|
| A | towards the left | towards the right |
| B | towards the left | towards the left |
| C | towards the right | towards the right |
| D | towards the right | towards the left |
answer_text:
A. According to Newton's Third Law, for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
1. The man pushes the box to the right. Therefore, the box exerts an equal and opposite force on the man's hands, which is 'towards the left'.
2. To push the box to the right, the man's feet push the ground 'towards the left' (action). Therefore, the ground exerts an equal and opposite force on the man's feet, which is 'towards the right' (reaction).
Thus, the force on the man's hands is towards the left, and the force on the man's feet is towards the right.

context_text: A diagram shows an irregularly shaped 'non-uniform object' placed on an inclined plane. The object is depicted in a position where it is described as 'just about to topple'. question_text: Which point is likely the centre of gravity?
answer_text: B. For an object to be stable, its center of gravity must be located within its base of support. When an object is 'just about to topple', its center of gravity is vertically above the pivot point (the edge about which it is about to tip). Point B is the lowest and most central point among the options, which would contribute most to stability. For an object about to topple over an edge, the center of gravity would be on the verge of moving outside the base of support. Given the options, B represents a plausible location for the center of gravity of such an irregularly shaped object that is still stable enough to be 'just about to topple' over its support base.

context_text: A diagram shows a mercury barometer setup. Inside the inverted tube, there is a vacuum above a column of a liquid (which is less dense than mercury) of height X, which rests on a column of mercury of height 74 cm. The entire setup is exposed to atmospheric pressure from below the mercury reservoir. Given parameters are: atmospheric pressure = 76 cm Hg, density of the liquid = 1200 kg/m³, and density of mercury = 13600 kg/m³.
question_text:
Given that the atmospheric pressure is 76 cm Hg, the density of liquid is 1200 kg/m³ and the density of mercury is 13600 kg/m³, determine the height X of the liquid column.
A 2.0 cm
C 26.0 cm
B 22.7 cm
D 76.0 cm
answer_text:
B. The atmospheric pressure supports the combined pressure of the liquid column and the mercury column (since there is a vacuum above the liquid).
P_atm = P_liquid + P_mercury
We can express pressures in terms of height, density, and gravitational acceleration (P = hρg). Since 'g' is common on both sides, it can be cancelled out.
(h_atm_Hg × ρ_Hg × g) = (X × ρ_liquid × g) + (h_Hg × ρ_Hg × g)
(76 cm × ρ_Hg) = (X × ρ_liquid) + (74 cm × ρ_Hg)
Rearranging the equation to solve for X:
(76 cm × ρ_Hg) - (74 cm × ρ_Hg) = X × ρ_liquid
(76 - 74) cm × ρ_Hg = X × ρ_liquid
2 cm × ρ_Hg = X × ρ_liquid
X = (2 cm × ρ_Hg) / ρ_liquid
Substitute the given densities:
X = (2 cm × 13600 kg/m³) / 1200 kg/m³
X = (2 × 13600) / 1200 cm
X = 27200 / 1200 cm
X = 272 / 12 cm
X = 22.666... cm
Rounding to one decimal place, X = 22.7 cm.

A A

answer_text: A. When a liquid freezes into a solid, its particles lose their random arrangement and become fixed in a regular, ordered, closely packed lattice structure. context_text:
Four blocks (A, B, C, D) of equal masses are made from different materials. Each block is heated such that they all receive the same amount of internal energy (ΔU). The temperature rise (ΔT) for each block is given:
- Block A: ΔT = 3°C
- Block B: ΔT = 6°C
- Block C: ΔT = 9°C
- Block D: ΔT = 12°C
question_text:
Which block has the smallest specific heat capacity?
A A
B B
C C
D D
answer_text: D. The change in internal energy (ΔU) for an object is given by the formula ΔU = mcΔT, where m is the mass, c is the specific heat capacity, and ΔT is the change in temperature. The problem states that all blocks have equal masses (m) and the same increase in internal energy (ΔU). Therefore, for ΔU and m to be constant, the product cΔT must be constant. This implies that the specific heat capacity (c) is inversely proportional to the temperature rise (ΔT) (c ∝ 1/ΔT). The block with the largest temperature rise will have the smallest specific heat capacity. Block D has the largest temperature rise (12°C), so it has the smallest specific heat capacity.

Wavelength of the wave at R (λ_R) = 3.0 cm = 0.03 m.
Frequency (f) = v_R / λ_R = 0.15 m/s / 0.03 m = 5 Hz.
Note: This calculated answer (5 Hz) does not match any of the provided multiple-choice options (A: 0.60 Hz, B: 3.0 Hz, C: 15 Hz, D: 75 Hz). There may be an error in the question's given values or the options provided.

So, 1.0 * sin(40°) = 1.5 * sin(r). Calculating r gives r = arcsin(sin(40°)/1.5) = arcsin(0.6428/1.5) = arcsin(0.4285) ≈ 25.37°. In the diagram, θ is labeled as the angle of refraction (r). context_text: A diagram shows a water wave propagating in a ripple tank. The wave crosses a boundary, labelled PQ, where its wavelength changes. Before the boundary, the distance between crests (wavelength) is 3.0 cm. After the boundary, the distance between crests (wavelength) is 1.5 cm. The problem states that the wave has a speed of 0.15 m/s at point R, which is located in the region where the wavelength is 3.0 cm (before the boundary). Point S is located in the region where the wavelength is 1.5 cm (after the boundary).
question_text:
What is the velocity of the wave at point S?
A 0.075 m/s
C 0.30 m/s
B 0.15 m/s
D 0.45 m/s
answer_text:
A. When a wave passes from one medium to another (or crosses a boundary), its frequency (f) remains constant. Only its speed (v) and wavelength (λ) change. We can first calculate the frequency using the information given for point R:
1.  **Calculate frequency (f):**
    Given speed at R (v1) = 0.15 m/s.
    Given wavelength at R (λ1) = 3.0 cm = 0.03 m.
    Using the wave equation v = fλ, we find f = v1 / λ1 = 0.15 m/s / 0.03 m = 5 Hz.
2.  **Calculate velocity at S (v2):**
    The frequency remains constant (f = 5 Hz).
    Wavelength at S (λ2) = 1.5 cm = 0.015 m.
    Using v2 = fλ2 = 5 Hz × 0.015 m = 0.075 m/s.
Therefore, the velocity of the wave at point S is 0.075 m/s.

context_text: Ultrasound is used for mapping the ocean floor. The water depth is 1800m. Five ultrasound pulses are sent from the surface and received back within a total period of 12 seconds.
question_text:
What is the speed of the ultrasound in water?
A 150 m/s
C 1200 m/s
B 360 m/s
D 1500 m/s
answer_text:
D. The speed of ultrasound in water can be calculated using the distance traveled and the time taken.
1.  **Calculate the time for one round trip:** Five pulses are sent and received in 12 seconds. So, the time taken for one pulse to travel to the ocean floor and return to the surface is: Time per round trip (t) = 12 s / 5 pulses = 2.4 s.
2.  **Calculate the total distance traveled by one pulse:** The depth of the water is 1800 m. A pulse travels down to the floor and then back up to the surface, so the total distance (d) = 2 × 1800 m = 3600 m.
3.  **Calculate the speed of ultrasound (v):** Speed = Distance / Time = d / t = 3600 m / 2.4 s = 1500 m/s.

answer_text: B. The direction of an electric field is conventionally defined as the direction of the force that would be exerted on a *positive* test charge. As the force on the negative charge is horizontally to the left, the electric field must be in the opposite direction, which is horizontally to the right.

A diagram shows a coil of copper wire. Four different rods (A, B, C, D) are tested as cores for this coil. When current flows through the coil, it acts as an electromagnet, attracting paper clips. - Rod B: Attracts 20 paper clips with current, 5 without current.
- Rod C: Attracts 40 paper clips with current, 0 without current.

question_text:
Which rod would be the most suitable to use as the core of a coil in a circuit breaker?
A A
B B
C C
D D
answer_text:
C. A circuit breaker uses an electromagnet that needs to be strongly magnetized quickly when a fault occurs (high current) to trip the breaker, and then quickly demagnetized when the current returns to normal, so it can be reset. This requires a 'soft magnetic material' that is easily magnetized and easily demagnetized (i.e., has low retentivity and coercivity, meaning it shows little to no residual magnetism).
-   **Rod A** is too weak as an electromagnet (1 clip).
-   **Rod B** becomes moderately strong (20 clips) but retains magnetism (5 clips) when the current is off, indicating it's a 'hard' magnetic material and would not demagnetize easily for resetting.
-   **Rod C** becomes very strong (40 clips) when current flows and retains no magnetism (0 clips) when current is off. This indicates it is easily magnetized and easily demagnetized, making it an ideal core for a circuit breaker.
-   **Rod D** becomes very strong (40 clips) but retains significant magnetism (20 clips) when current is off, making it a 'hard' magnetic material unsuitable for a circuit breaker.

context_text: A student releases a rubber ball from rest. It hits the ground with a velocity of +6.0 m/s. The acceleration due to gravity is 10.0 m/s².
question_text: Calculate the time taken for the ball to hit the ground after the student drops it.
answer_text: To calculate the time taken, use the equation of motion: v = u + at, where v is the final velocity, u is the initial velocity, a is the acceleration, and t is the time. Given: u = 0 m/s (released from rest), v = 6.0 m/s, a = 10.0 m/s². Substituting these values: 6.0 = 0 + (10.0 * t). Rearranging for t: t = 6.0 / 10.0 = 0.6 s. The time taken for the ball to hit the ground is 0.6 s.

The velocity-time graph for the ball's motion consists of two main straight-line segments:

It then decelerates uniformly due to gravity as it rises, reaching 0 m/s at its original height. Since the acceleration is constant, it takes another 0.6 s to come to rest at its original height (0.6 s + 0.6 s = 1.2 s). This is represented by a straight line connecting the point (0.6 s, -6.0 m/s) to (1.2 s, 0 m/s).
Therefore, the graph should show a line from (0,0) to (0.6, 6), an instantaneous vertical drop to (0.6, -6), and then a line from (0.6, -6) to (1.2, 0).

answer_text:
The height at which the rubber ball was released is equal to the area under the velocity-time graph during its downward motion. This area is a triangle. 
Base of the triangle (time taken) = 0.6 s.
Height of the triangle (final velocity) = 6.0 m/s.
Area = 0.5 × base × height = 0.5 × 0.6 s × 6.0 m/s = 1.8 m.
Thus, the height at which the rubber ball was released is 1.8 m.

context_text: Fig. 3.1 shows a 2 m uniform plank kept in a horizontal position by two supports, A and B. Support A is located 0.3 m from the left end of the plank. Support B is located 1.4 m to the right of support A. A 76 N load is placed vertically above support B. The plank itself has a weight of 24 N. The weight of a uniform plank acts at its center of gravity, which is at the midpoint of the plank (1 m from either end).
question_text: Explain why the load does not produce a moment about support B.
answer_text: A moment (or torque) is defined as the product of a force and the perpendicular distance from the pivot point to the line of action of that force. In this scenario, the load of 76 N is placed vertically directly above support B, which is designated as the pivot point. This means that the line of action of the load's force passes directly through support B. Therefore, the perpendicular distance from the line of action of the load to support B is zero, and consequently, the load produces no moment about support B.

context_text: The setup includes a 2 m uniform plank in a horizontal position. Support A is 0.3 m from the left end of the plank. Support B is 1.4 m to the right of support A, meaning support B is at 0.3 m + 1.4 m = 1.7 m from the left end of the plank. The plank has a weight of 24 N, acting at its center of gravity which is at 1 m from the left end. A 76 N load is placed vertically above support B. The system is in equilibrium (kept horizontal).
question_text: Calculate the force acting at support A when the load is placed vertically above support B.
answer_text:
To calculate the force acting at support A (let's call it F_A), we apply the principle of moments and the principle of forces for equilibrium. 
First, consider the sum of vertical forces for equilibrium: Sum of upward forces = Sum of downward forces.
F_A + F_B = Weight of plank + Load = 24 N + 76 N = 100 N (Equation 1, where F_B is the force at support B).
Next, take moments about a pivot. Choosing support A as the pivot eliminates F_A from the moment equation. For equilibrium, the sum of clockwise moments about A equals the sum of anti-clockwise moments about A.
Positions from the left end:
- Support A: 0.3 m (pivot)
- Center of gravity of plank (where 24 N acts): 1 m. Distance from A = 1 m - 0.3 m = 0.7 m.
- Support B (where 76 N load acts and F_B acts): 1.7 m. Distance from A = 1.7 m - 0.3 m = 1.4 m.
Moments about A:
- Weight of plank (24 N) is downwards at 0.7 m to the right of A, creating a clockwise moment: 24 N * 0.7 m.
- Load (76 N) is downwards at 1.4 m to the right of A, creating a clockwise moment: 76 N * 1.4 m.
- Force at support B (F_B) is upwards at 1.4 m to the right of A, creating an anti-clockwise moment: F_B * 1.4 m.
Sum of clockwise moments = Sum of anti-clockwise moments:
(24 N * 0.7 m) + (76 N * 1.4 m) = F_B * 1.4 m
16.8 Nm + 106.4 Nm = F_B * 1.4 m
123.2 Nm = F_B * 1.4 m
F_B = 123.2 / 1.4 = 88 N.
Now, substitute F_B back into Equation 1:
F_A + 88 N = 100 N
F_A = 100 N - 88 N = 12 N.
Therefore, the force acting at support A is 12 N.

context_text: The setup includes a 2 m uniform plank supported horizontally by support A (0.3 m from left end) and support B (1.7 m from left end). The plank's weight is 24 N (acting at 1 m from left end). A 76 N load is on the plank. The question asks for the maximum distance the load can be moved to the right of support B such that the plank does not lift from support A. This condition implies that the force exerted by support A becomes zero (F_A = 0). At this point, the plank is on the verge of tipping, pivoting about support B.
question_text: Calculate the maximum distance that the load can be moved to the right of support B such that the plank does not lift from support A.
answer_text:
For the plank not to lift from support A, the upward force at support A must be zero (F_A = 0). This means the plank is in equilibrium, pivoting about support B. We apply the principle of moments by taking support B as the pivot.
Let 'x' be the maximum distance the 76 N load can be moved to the right of support B. The load now creates a clockwise moment about B.
The weight of the plank (24 N) acts at its center of gravity, which is 1 m from the left end. Support B is at 1.7 m from the left end. So, the plank's weight acts (1.7 m - 1 m) = 0.7 m to the left of support B. This creates an anti-clockwise moment about B.
For equilibrium, the sum of clockwise moments about B must equal the sum of anti-clockwise moments about B.
Anti-clockwise moment (due to plank's weight) = 24 N × 0.7 m = 16.8 Nm.
Clockwise moment (due to load) = 76 N × x.
Equating these moments: 76 N × x = 16.8 Nm.
x = 16.8 / 76 = 0.22105... m.
Rounding to two significant figures, the maximum distance the load can be moved to the right of support B is 0.22 m.

context_text: A 29 kg gas cylinder is placed on a horizontal floor, exerting a pressure of 2.3 kPa on the floor. The gravitational field strength is typically taken as 10 N/kg for such problems.
question_text: Calculate the base area of the gas cylinder.
answer_text:
First, calculate the force exerted by the gas cylinder on the floor, which is its weight.
Assuming gravitational field strength (g) = 10 N/kg:
Force (F) = mass (m) × g = 29 kg × 10 N/kg = 290 N.
Next, use the formula for pressure: Pressure (P) = Force (F) / Area (A).
Given pressure P = 2.3 kPa = 2.3 × 1000 Pa = 2300 Pa.
Rearranging the formula to find the area: A = F / P.
A = 290 N / 2300 Pa = 0.12608... m².
Rounding to three significant figures, the base area of the gas cylinder is 0.126 m².

context_text: Fig. 4.2 shows a U-tube manometer used to measure the pressure inside a gas cylinder. The manometer contains mercury (density = 13 600 kg/m³). One arm of the manometer is open to atmospheric pressure (P_atm = 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa), and the other is connected to the gas cylinder (P_gas). The mercury level in the arm open to atmospheric pressure is 5.9 cm above a reference line, while the mercury level in the arm connected to the gas cylinder is 3.5 cm above the reference line. This means the mercury level is higher in the arm exposed to atmospheric pressure, indicating that P_gas is lower than P_atm.
question_text: Calculate the pressure in the gas cylinder. The atmospheric pressure is 1.0 x 10⁵ Pa. The density of mercury is 13 600 kg/m³.
answer_text:
First, calculate the height difference (h) in the mercury columns:
h = (Mercury level in atmospheric arm) - (Mercury level in gas cylinder arm)
h = 5.9 cm - 3.5 cm = 2.4 cm = 0.024 m (converted to meters).
Next, calculate the pressure difference (ΔP) corresponding to this height difference using ΔP = ρgh, where ρ is the density of mercury, g is the gravitational field strength (assume 10 N/kg or m/s²), and h is the height difference.
ΔP = 13 600 kg/m³ × 10 N/kg × 0.024 m = 3264 Pa.
Since the mercury level is higher in the arm open to atmospheric pressure, the pressure in the gas cylinder (P_gas) is less than the atmospheric pressure (P_atm) by this difference.
P_gas = P_atm - ΔP
P_gas = (1.0 × 10⁵ Pa) - 3264 Pa = 100 000 Pa - 3264 Pa = 96736 Pa.
Rounding to three significant figures, the pressure in the gas cylinder is 96700 Pa.

context_text: Fig. 5.1 shows a steel pot used to boil water.
question_text: Define specific latent heat of vaporisation.
answer_text: Specific latent heat of vaporisation is defined as the amount of energy required to change 1 kilogram of a substance from its liquid state to its gaseous state (or vice versa) at its boiling point, without any change in temperature.

context_text: A 1.2 kg steel pot containing 3.0 kg of water is initially at 30 °C. The steel has a specific heat capacity of 445 J/kg K. The water has a specific heat capacity of 4200 J/kg K and a specific latent heat of vaporisation of 2.3 x 10⁶ J/kg. A 2000 W induction cooker is used. The pot reaches 120 °C, and the water boils at 100 °C. We need to calculate the time taken to boil 0.5 kg of water, assuming no energy loss to the surroundings.
question_text: A 2000 W induction cooker is used to boil water. The steel pot reaches a temperature of 120 °C while water is boiling at 100 °C. Calculate the time taken to boil 0.5 kg of water. Assume no energy loss to the surroundings.
answer_text:
To calculate the total time, we need to find the total energy required for three stages:
1.  **Energy to heat the steel pot (E_pot):**
    E_pot = m_pot × c_pot × ΔT_pot = 1.2 kg × 445 J/kg K × (120 °C - 30 °C) = 1.2 × 445 × 90 = 48060 J.
2.  **Energy to heat the initial water to boiling point (E_water_heat):**
    E_water_heat = m_water_initial × c_water × ΔT_water = 3.0 kg × 4200 J/kg K × (100 °C - 30 °C) = 3.0 × 4200 × 70 = 882000 J.
3.  **Energy to vaporize 0.5 kg of water (E_vaporize):**
    E_vaporize = m_water_vaporize × L_v = 0.5 kg × (2.3 × 10⁶ J/kg) = 1150000 J.
**Total energy supplied (E_total):**
E_total = E_pot + E_water_heat + E_vaporize = 48060 J + 882000 J + 1150000 J = 2080060 J.
**Time taken (t):**
Power (P) = E_total / t, so t = E_total / P.
t = 2080060 J / 2000 W = 1040.03 s.
Converting to minutes: t = 1040.03 s / 60 s/min = 17.33 min.
Rounding to three significant figures, the time taken is 1040 s or 17.3 min.

context_text: Fig. 6.1 shows a boy playing a violin.
question_text: Explain how sound from the violin is produced and transmitted.
answer_text: Sound from the violin is produced when the violin bow causes the violin strings to vibrate. These vibrations are then transferred through the bridge to the wooden body of the violin, which also vibrates. The vibrating strings and body of the violin disturb the surrounding air molecules, creating alternating regions of high pressure (compressions) and low pressure (rarefactions). These compressions and rarefactions propagate outwards through the air as longitudinal waves, which are what we perceive as sound. The sound waves are transmitted through the air to the listener's ears.

context_text: Fig. 6.2 shows a graphical representation of a violin note, which is a waveform plotted on a grid. The original wave has a certain amplitude and frequency, completing approximately one cycle within two horizontal grid units.
question_text: Sketch on Fig. 6.2 another note twice the pitch and twice the loudness.
answer_text:
To sketch a note that is twice the pitch and twice the loudness:
1.  **Twice the loudness:** Loudness is directly related to the amplitude of the wave. If the original wave has a particular amplitude (its maximum displacement from the equilibrium position), a wave that is twice as loud will have an amplitude that is double the original. So, if the original amplitude is, for example, 2.5 grid units, the new wave's amplitude should be 5 grid units.
2.  **Twice the pitch:** Pitch is directly related to the frequency of the wave. A wave with twice the pitch means it has twice the frequency. Since frequency is the inverse of the period (f = 1/T), a wave with twice the frequency will have half the period. If the original wave completes one cycle in approximately two horizontal grid units, the new wave should complete one cycle in one horizontal grid unit.
Therefore, the sketch should depict a wave with double the vertical height (amplitude) of the original wave and oscillating twice as many times within the same horizontal distance (time or position).

context_text: Fig. 7.1 shows a circuit diagram with a 12 V battery. The circuit has two parallel branches. Branch 1 (top branch) consists of a 100 Ω fixed resistor in series with a light-dependent resistor (LDR). Branch 2 (bottom branch) consists of a 50 Ω fixed resistor in series with a thermistor. Table 7.2 provides resistance values: LDR is 400 Ω in bright conditions and 15 000 Ω in dark conditions. The thermistor is 300 Ω in hot conditions and 12 000 Ω in cold conditions. The question asks to calculate the current flow in the battery when the circuit is in a dark and hot room.
question_text: Calculate the current flow in the battery when the circuit is in a dark and hot room.
answer_text:
When the circuit is in a dark and hot room:
1.  **LDR resistance (R_LDR):** In dark conditions, R_LDR = 15 000 Ω.
2.  **Thermistor resistance (R_thermistor):** In hot conditions, R_thermistor = 300 Ω.
Calculate the total resistance of each parallel branch:
-   **Resistance of Branch 1 (R1_total):** 100 Ω (fixed) + R_LDR = 100 Ω + 15 000 Ω = 15 100 Ω.
-   **Resistance of Branch 2 (R2_total):** 50 Ω (fixed) + R_thermistor = 50 Ω + 300 Ω = 350 Ω.
Calculate the effective resistance (R_eff) of the parallel circuit using the formula 1/R_eff = 1/R1_total + 1/R2_total:
1/R_eff = 1/15100 + 1/350 = (350 + 15100) / (15100 × 350) = 15450 / 5285000.
R_eff = 5285000 / 15450 ≈ 342.07 Ω.
Finally, calculate the total current flow (I) in the battery using Ohm's Law: I = V / R_eff.
I = 12 V / 342.07 Ω ≈ 0.03507 A.
Rounding to three significant figures, the current flow in the battery is 0.0351 A.

context_text: The circuit consists of two parallel branches connected to a 12 V battery. Branch 1 contains a 100 Ω fixed resistor in series with an LDR. Table 7.2 states that the LDR's resistance is 400 Ω in bright conditions and 15 000 Ω in dark conditions. The question asks to calculate the potential difference across the LDR when the circuit is in a bright and cold room.
question_text: Calculate the potential difference across the LDR when the circuit is in a bright and cold room.
answer_text:
When the circuit is in a bright and cold room:
1.  **LDR resistance (R_LDR):** In bright conditions, R_LDR = 400 Ω.
2.  The conditions of the thermistor (cold room) do not affect Branch 1, as it is a parallel branch.
Branch 1 consists of the 100 Ω fixed resistor and the LDR in series. The total voltage across Branch 1 is the battery voltage, 12 V.
Total resistance of Branch 1 (R1_total) = 100 Ω + R_LDR = 100 Ω + 400 Ω = 500 Ω.
The current flowing through Branch 1 (I1) can be found using Ohm's Law: I1 = V_battery / R1_total = 12 V / 500 Ω = 0.024 A.
The potential difference (p.d.) across the LDR (V_LDR) is then calculated using V_LDR = I1 × R_LDR.
V_LDR = 0.024 A × 400 Ω = 9.6 V.
Therefore, the potential difference across the LDR in a bright and cold room is 9.6 V.

context_text: The circuit consists of two parallel branches connected to a 12 V battery. Branch 1 contains a 100 Ω fixed resistor in series with an LDR. Branch 2 contains a 50 Ω fixed resistor in series with a thermistor. The LDR's resistance is 400 Ω in bright conditions. The question asks to explain why the potential difference across the LDR is the same as in part (c) (which was 9.6 V for a bright and cold room) when the circuit is in a bright and hot room.
question_text: Explain why the potential difference across the LDR is the same as in (c) when the circuit is in a bright and hot room.
answer_text:
The potential difference across the LDR is determined by the characteristics of Branch 1 (the 100 Ω resistor and the LDR) and the total voltage supplied to that branch. 
1.  **LDR Resistance:** In a bright room, the resistance of the LDR is 400 Ω, regardless of the room's temperature. This condition is the same as in part (c).
2.  **Parallel Branches:** Branch 1 and Branch 2 are connected in parallel across the 12 V battery. In a parallel circuit, the voltage across each branch is the same and equal to the source voltage (12 V).
Therefore, the potential difference across Branch 1 (and thus the potential divider formed by the 100 Ω resistor and the LDR within it) remains 12 V, irrespective of the conditions in Branch 2 (i.e., whether the thermistor is in a cold or hot environment). Since the LDR's resistance is unchanged (due to brightness) and the voltage across its branch is constant, the potential difference across the LDR remains the same at 9.6 V, even if the room temperature changes from cold to hot.

context_text: Fig. 8.1 shows an electric oven, a white appliance with controls for temperature and timer, connected to the mains supply using a three-pin plug. The three-pin plug is shown physically connected to a mains socket.
question_text: Explain why a three-pin plug is necessary to connect the electric oven to the main supply.
answer_text: A three-pin plug is necessary for the electric oven primarily for safety, particularly because the oven has a metal casing which could become live in the event of an electrical fault. The three pins correspond to the live wire, neutral wire, and earth wire. The earth wire is crucially connected to the metal casing of the appliance. If the live wire accidentally touches the metal casing (e.g., due to damaged insulation), the earth wire provides a low-resistance path for the fault current to flow directly to the ground. This surge in current will cause the fuse (or circuit breaker) in the plug or consumer unit to blow immediately, disconnecting the power supply to the oven. This prevents the metal casing from becoming dangerously live and protects the user from a severe electric shock or electrocution.

context_text: The electric oven is connected to the mains supply using a three-pin plug, which contains a fuse.
question_text: The plug has a fuse. Explain the function of the fuse and how it is connected to the mains supply.
answer_text:
The function of a fuse is to act as an automatic safety device designed to protect electrical appliances and wiring from damage due to overcurrents. It consists of a thin metal wire or filament that heats up and melts, breaking the circuit, if the current flowing through it exceeds its specified rated value. This effectively stops the flow of electricity to the appliance when a fault occurs.
The fuse is always connected in series with the live wire of the mains supply. This ensures that when the fuse blows (melts), it completely disconnects the appliance from the high potential of the live wire, making the appliance safe and preventing further current flow, even if the neutral wire remains connected.

context_text: An electric oven is rated at 800 W and is connected to a 240 V mains supply. The available fuse ratings are 1 A, 3 A, 5 A, 7 A, 10 A, and 13 A.
question_text: The electric oven is rated 800 W and the mains supply is 240 V. Determine a suitable fuse for the oven. The available fuses are 1 A, 3A, 5 A, 7 A, 10 A and 13 A.
answer_text:
First, calculate the normal operating current (I) of the electric oven using the formula Power (P) = Voltage (V) × Current (I).
Given: P = 800 W, V = 240 V.
I = P / V = 800 W / 240 V = 3.333... A.
A suitable fuse must have a current rating that is slightly higher than the appliance's normal operating current. This allows the appliance to function without the fuse blowing unnecessarily, while still being low enough to blow quickly in the event of an overcurrent or fault, thereby protecting the appliance and user.
Comparing the calculated operating current (3.33 A) with the available fuse ratings:
-   1 A and 3 A are too low; they would blow during normal operation.
-   5 A is the next available standard rating that is higher than 3.33 A.
-   7 A, 10 A, and 13 A are also higher, but a 5 A fuse provides the closest suitable protection without being overly sensitive or allowing excessive current to flow.
Therefore, a 5 A fuse is the most suitable choice for the electric oven.

context_text: Fig. 9.1 shows the internal parts of a motor. It depicts a central shaft with an armature/rotor windings (coils of wire) surrounded by stator magnets (labeled N and S). Attached to the shaft are segmented components labeled 'commutator' and associated 'brushes'. There are also components labeled 'bearings'.
question_text: State what is meant by hard and soft magnetic materials in terms of their magnetic properties.
answer_text:
Hard magnetic materials (also known as hard magnets) are materials that are difficult to magnetize but, once magnetized, retain their magnetism strongly and permanently. They are used to make permanent magnets. Examples include steel, alnico, and neodymium magnets.
Soft magnetic materials (also known as soft magnets) are materials that are easily magnetized and demagnetized. They lose their magnetism very quickly once the external magnetizing field is removed. They are used for making temporary magnets, such as in electromagnets, transformer cores, and motor cores. An example is soft iron.

context_text: In the context of a motor, rotor windings are coils of wires wound around a core. The question states that these coils are wound around soft iron.
question_text: Rotor windings are coils of wires. The coils of wires are wound round soft iron. Explain the function of the soft iron.
answer_text:
The soft iron core around which the rotor windings are wound serves two primary functions in a motor:
1.  **Concentration of Magnetic Field Lines:** Soft iron is a highly permeable material, meaning it can be easily magnetized. When current flows through the rotor windings, the soft iron core effectively concentrates the magnetic field lines produced by these coils. This leads to a significantly stronger magnetic field within the rotor.
2.  **Enhancement of Turning Effect (Torque):** By concentrating and strengthening the magnetic field, the soft iron core increases the interaction between the magnetic field of the rotor coils and the magnetic field of the stator magnets. This results in a much larger magnetic force (Lorentz force) on the current-carrying coils, thereby producing a greater turning effect (torque) on the armature. This makes the motor more powerful and efficient.

context_text: Fig. 9.1 shows parts of a motor, specifically indicating a 'commutator' as a segmented metallic cylinder attached to the rotating shaft, and 'brushes' which make contact with the commutator.
question_text: Describe the function of the commutator in the motor.
answer_text: The commutator in a DC motor is a segmented metallic cylinder attached to the armature shaft, which works in conjunction with the carbon brushes. Its primary function is to reverse the direction of the current flowing through the armature coils every half rotation (180 degrees). As the armature rotates, each segment of the commutator periodically switches contact with the fixed carbon brushes, which supply the current. This continuous reversal of current direction ensures that the magnetic force acting on the sides of the coil always acts in the same rotational direction, maintaining a continuous and consistent turning effect (torque) on the armature. This allows the motor to rotate continuously in one fixed direction.

context_text: Strontium-90 undergoes nuclear decay.
question_text: Explain what is meant by nuclear decay.
answer_text: Nuclear decay, also known as radioactive decay, is a spontaneous and random process in which an unstable atomic nucleus transforms into a more stable nucleus by emitting various types of radiation (such as alpha particles, beta particles, or gamma rays) and releasing energy. This process is intrinsic to the unstable nucleus and is not influenced by external physical or chemical conditions like temperature or pressure.

context_text: Strontium-90 is produced by nuclear fission. The question asks to explain the difference between nuclear fission and nuclear fusion.
question_text: Strontium-90 is produced by nuclear fission. Explain the difference between nuclear fission and nuclear fusion.
answer_text:
Nuclear fission is a process where a heavy, unstable atomic nucleus (such as Uranium-235 or Plutonium-239) is split into two or more smaller, lighter nuclei. This splitting is typically induced by bombarding the heavy nucleus with neutrons. Fission releases a significant amount of energy, along with additional neutrons and gamma rays, and is the principle behind nuclear power generation and atomic bombs.
Nuclear fusion is a process where two or more light atomic nuclei (such as isotopes of hydrogen like deuterium and tritium) combine or fuse together to form a single, heavier nucleus. This process releases an even greater amount of energy per unit mass than fission. Fusion is the fundamental process that powers the Sun and other stars, and it is the basis for hydrogen bombs.

context_text: Fig. 10.4 shows a setup in a steel sheet factory for determining the thickness of steel sheets using strontium-90. A source of strontium-90 (contained in a lead container) is placed below a moving steel sheet, and a Geiger-Muller counter is placed above the steel sheet.
