context_text: The diagram shows a bicycle dynamo that generates current as a magnet rotates within coils, causing a lamp to light up. The brightness of the lamp depends on the current generated.
question_text: Suggest one way in which the brightness of the lamp could be increased.
answer_text: To increase the brightness of the lamp, the current generated by the dynamo needs to be increased. This can be achieved by: 1. Cycling faster, which increases the speed of rotation of the magnet, leading to a faster rate of change of magnetic flux linkage and thus a larger induced current. 2. Using a stronger permanent magnet, which would produce a stronger magnetic field and thus a larger magnetic flux linkage change. 3. Increasing the number of turns in the coils of wire, which would increase the induced e.m.f. and current for the same rate of magnetic flux change.

context_text: The diagram shows two pieces of soft iron placed horizontally, separated by a small gap, within the magnetic field of a strong permanent magnet. The N pole of the permanent magnet is positioned to the left of these pieces, and the S pole is to the right, creating a horizontal magnetic field that passes through the soft iron.
question_text: Mark the magnetic poles produced at each end of both pieces of soft iron.
answer_text: When the soft iron pieces are placed in the magnetic field created by the permanent magnet, they become temporary induced magnets. For each soft iron piece, the end closer to the N pole of the permanent magnet (the left end) will acquire an induced South (S) pole, and the end closer to the S pole of the permanent magnet (the right end) will acquire an induced North (N) pole. Therefore, for both soft iron pieces, the left ends should be marked 'S' and the right ends 'N'.

context_text: The reed switch consists of two soft iron pieces (reeds) that become magnetized and attract each other when a magnetic field is applied. This arrangement is used in a greenhouse warning system with two separate circuits. Circuit 1 contains the reed switch, a cell, and a warning lamp, all in series. Circuit 2 contains a thermistor, a cell, and a coil wound around the reed switch, all in series. When the temperature in the greenhouse changes, the thermistor's resistance changes, affecting the current in Circuit 2 and thus the magnetic field generated by the coil.
question_text: Explain how this arrangement can be used to warn the farmers when the temperature in a greenhouse is too high.
answer_text: When the temperature in the greenhouse is too high, the resistance of the thermistor (which is sensitive to temperature) decreases significantly. This decrease in resistance causes an increase in the current flowing through Circuit 2, which includes the coil wound around the reed switch. The increased current in the coil strengthens the electromagnet, which then creates a stronger magnetic field. This strong magnetic field magnetizes the soft iron reeds of the reed switch, inducing opposite poles at their adjacent ends (e.g., N and S). These induced poles attract each other, causing the reeds to close the switch contacts in Circuit 1. This completes Circuit 1, allowing current from its cell to flow through the warning lamp, causing it to light up and alert the farmers to the high temperature.

context_text: The diagram shows a simple electric motor with a rectangular coil WXYZ in a magnetic field (N pole left, S pole right). The coil is connected to a battery via brushes and a split-ring commutator, allowing it to spin about axis PQ. Current flowing through the coil interacts with the magnetic field, generating forces that cause rotation.
question_text: Explain how the electric motor works and how it is able to rotate continuously in one direction.
answer_text: The electric motor works based on the motor effect. When current flows through the coil WXYZ, each side of the coil experiences a force due to the interaction between the current and the magnetic field of the permanent magnets (Fleming's Left-Hand Rule). For example, if current flows from W to X, the force on side WX will be downwards, and simultaneously, the force on side YZ (where current flows from Y to Z, opposite to WX's direction relative to the field) will be upwards. These two forces, acting in opposite directions on opposite sides of the coil, create a turning effect or torque, causing the coil to rotate (e.g., clockwise). To ensure continuous rotation in one direction, a split-ring commutator is used. Every half-turn (180 degrees), the commutator reverses the direction of the current flowing through the coil segments. This reversal ensures that the forces on sides WX and YZ always act in the same direction relative to the coil's motion, maintaining the torque and allowing the coil to spin continuously in the same direction (e.g., continuously clockwise).

context_text: The diagram shows a simple electric motor circuit that includes a coil, permanent magnets, a battery, brushes, and a commutator. This motor converts electrical energy into mechanical energy, causing the coil to rotate.
question_text: Why would it be better to include a rheostat in the circuit?
answer_text: It would be better to include a rheostat (variable resistor) in the circuit because a rheostat allows for the control of the current flowing through the motor's coil. By varying the current, the strength of the magnetic forces acting on the coil can be adjusted, which in turn allows for the control and adjustment of the speed of rotation of the motor.

context_text: The experiment is designed to determine the speed of a wave on the surface of water. You are provided with a digital calipers, a plate, a dropper, a stopwatch, a 30 cm ruler, a beaker, and paper towels. The instruction is to fill the plate with water to the level marked by a black line on the side of the plate. Figure 1.1 illustrates a wavefront moving outwards from the center of a plate filled with water. A water drop from a dropper initiates this wavefront. The dropper is shown at the top, dispensing a 'water drop' onto the surface of the water in the plate. The spreading circular disturbance on the water surface is labeled 'wavefront'.
question_text: Using a digital calipers, measure the depth of the water, d, at the centre of the plate.
answer_text: The depth of the water, d, should be measured using the digital calipers to the nearest 0.1 mm or better. An example recorded value could be 6.50 mm (which falls within the expected range of 5.00 mm to 8.00 mm).

context_text: The experiment describes observing a wavefront initiated by a single drop of water from a dropper falling into the center of a plate filled with water. The wavefront travels to the edge of the plate, reflects back to the center, and then travels back out again, moving in and out several times. The task is to determine an accurate time t for the wavefront to travel once from the center of the plate and back to the center. This involves putting 1.0 cm³ of water into the dropper and then allowing one drop to fall into the center of the plate.
question_text: Take measurements to determine an accurate time t for the wavefront to travel once from the centre of the plate and back to the centre.
answer_text: To determine an accurate time t, at least two measurements should be taken and recorded to the nearest 0.1 s or better. This typically involves timing several oscillations (e.g., 5 or 10 cycles of the wavefront traveling to the edge and back) and then dividing the total time by the number of cycles to get the average time for one cycle. The average time, t, with its unit and appropriate significant figures, should be in the range of 0.40 s to 1.00 s. An example recorded value could be t = 0.75 s.

context_text: The task is to calculate the speed of the wavefront using the equation `speed = distance / time`. The time (t) was determined in the previous step, representing the time for the wavefront to travel from the center to the edge and back to the center. To complete this calculation, an additional measurement of the diameter of the water surface is required, as the distance travelled by the wavefront in one full cycle (center to edge and back to center) is equal to the diameter of the water surface. We can assume the diameter of the water surface is 17.0 cm (within the range of 16.5 cm to 17.5 cm) and the time t is 0.75 s.
question_text: Using your answer to (a)(ii), calculate the speed of the wavefront using the equation shown. You will need to make and record an additional measurement of the diameter of the water surface.
answer_text:
First, measure the diameter of the water surface. Let's assume the measured diameter is 17.0 cm. The distance travelled by the wavefront in one full cycle (from the center to the edge and back to the center) is equal to this diameter. Using the sample time t = 0.75 s from (a)(ii):
Distance = 17.0 cm = 0.170 m
Time = 0.75 s
Speed = Distance / Time = 0.170 m / 0.75 s = 0.227 m/s.
The speed calculated using candidate's values should have the correct unit and appropriate significant figures.

context_text: The experiment involves pressing a glass ball into modelling clay. The setup shown in Figure 2.2 includes a stand, boss, clamp, and a wooden strip (metre-rule) clamped in the boss. A loop of string, a mass-hanger, and a 30 cm ruler are also provided. The supervisor has clamped the wooden strip, and it's ensured the clamp can rotate freely. The glass ball and modelling clay are placed between the center of the wooden strip and the bench. Two 100 g masses are placed onto the mass hanger, resulting in a combined weight of 3.0 N for the mass hanger and masses. This mass hanger and masses are placed directly above the glass ball for about one minute. After removal, the wooden strip is raised, and the ball is removed from the modelling clay, revealing a small circular indentation. The task is to measure the diameter of this indentation.
question_text: Measure and record the diameter d₁ of the indentation.
answer_text: The diameter d₁ of the indentation formed in the modelling clay by the glass ball is measured using a ruler or digital calipers. This measurement should be recorded to the nearest mm (0.1 cm). It is expected that d₁ will be less than or equal to the diameter D of the glass ball. A typical value for d₁ could be 1.2 cm.

context_text: The area of a circle can be calculated using the equation `A = πd^2 / 4`, where 'A' is the area and 'd' is the diameter of the circle. The task is to calculate the area A₁ of the indentation using the diameter d₁ measured previously. If we use the sample value d₁ = 1.2 cm from the previous step.
question_text: The area of a circle can be calculated using the equation shown. `A = πd^2 / 4` where A is the area and d is the diameter of the circle. Calculate the area A₁ of the indentation with diameter d1.
answer_text:
Given the formula `A = πd^2 / 4` and using the sample value d₁ = 1.2 cm:
A₁ = π * (1.2 cm)^2 / 4
A₁ = π * 1.44 cm^2 / 4
A₁ = 0.36π cm^2
A₁ ≈ 1.13 cm^2
The calculation should be performed using the candidate's measured value for d₁, and the result should include the correct unit (e.g., cm² or mm²) and appropriate significant figures.

context_text: The experimental setup shown in Figure 2.3 involves flipping the modelling clay over and replacing the glass ball on the clay under the wooden strip. The wooden strip is lowered to rest on top of the glass ball. A loop of string is used to attach the mass hanger and masses near the end of the wooden strip. In Figure 2.3, a wooden strip (metre-rule) is shown resting on a glass ball which is on modelling clay. The strip is pivoted at a clamp, which acts as a fulcrum. A mass hanger with masses is suspended from the right end of the strip. The distance from the clamp (fulcrum) to the center of the glass ball is labeled 'x'. The distance from the clamp (fulcrum) to the point where the mass hanger is suspended is labeled 'y'. The task is to measure and record these distances, 'x' and 'y'.
question_text: Measure and record x and y.
answer_text: The distances 'x' and 'y' are measured using a ruler. Both values should be recorded to the nearest mm. It is essential that 'x' (distance from clamp to glass ball) is less than 'y' (distance from clamp to mass hanger). Sample values could be x = 10.0 cm and y = 25.0 cm.

context_text: The task is to calculate the force F exerted on the modelling clay using the equation `F = (3y) / x`. This equation relates the force to the measured distances 'x' and 'y'. The value '3' in the numerator likely represents the total weight of the mass hanger and two 100g masses, which is given as 3.0 N. Using the sample values from (c)(i): x = 10.0 cm and y = 25.0 cm.
question_text: Calculate the force F exerted on the modelling clay using the equation shown. `F = (3y) / x` Show your working.
answer_text:
Given the equation `F = (3y) / x`, and using the sample values x = 10.0 cm and y = 25.0 cm, where the '3' represents 3.0 N (the total weight of the mass hanger and masses):
F = (3.0 N * 25.0 cm) / 10.0 cm
F = 75.0 N cm / 10.0 cm
F = 7.5 N
The calculation should be performed using the candidate's measured values for x and y, and the result should include the correct unit (Newtons, N) and appropriate significant figures.

context_text: The task involves measuring and recording the diameter d2 of a new indentation produced by the ball in the clay, presumably under the force F calculated in the previous step. After measuring d2, the area A2 of this circular indentation needs to be calculated using the formula `A = πd^2 / 4`. It is expected that d2 will be greater than d1, and consequently A2 will be greater than A1, as a larger force F was likely applied to create this indentation. Let's assume a sample value for d2 = 1.5 cm.
question_text: Measure and record the diameter d2 of the indentation produced by the ball in the clay. Using the equation in (b)(ii), calculate the area A2 of the circle with diameter d2.
answer_text:
First, measure the diameter d2 of the new indentation. Let's assume d2 = 1.5 cm. This value should be greater than the previously measured d1. Now, calculate the area A2 using the formula `A = πd^2 / 4`:
A2 = π * (1.5 cm)^2 / 4
A2 = π * 2.25 cm^2 / 4
A2 = 0.5625π cm^2
A2 ≈ 1.77 cm^2
The calculated A2 should be greater than A1, and the result should include the correct unit (e.g., cm²) and appropriate significant figures.

context_text: The task is to calculate the change in temperature (Tc) and the change in voltage (Vc) using the recorded values. The provided equations are `TC = TW - TR` and `VC = VR - VW`. We will use the sample values: TR = 32.0 °C, VR = 3.60 V, Tw = 86.0 °C, and Vw = 2.00 V.
question_text: Calculate the change in temperature Tc and voltage Vc using the equations shown. `TC=TW-TR` `VC = VR-Vw`
answer_text:
Using the given equations and sample values:
Calculate the change in temperature Tc:
Tc = Tw - TR = 86.0 °C - 32.0 °C = 54.0 °C.

Calculate the change in voltage Vc:
Vc = VR - Vw = 3.60 V - 2.00 V = 1.60 V.

Both calculated values, Tc and Vc, should have appropriate units (°C and V respectively) and significant figures, based on the candidate's own recorded values.

context_text: The relationship between Tc and Vc is given by `Tc = G Vc + Q`. From the graph plotted in (e) of Tc against Vc, G represents the gradient of the straight line, and Q represents the y-intercept (the value of Tc when Vc = 0). The task is to determine these constants with appropriate units from the graph. The expected value for G is around 28.4 °C/V, and for Q is around 8.56 °C.
question_text: Determine, with appropriate units, the constant G and Q.
answer_text:
From the graph of Tc against Vc:

**To determine G (gradient):**
1.  Select two points on the best-fit line that are as far apart as possible, ideally using a gradient triangle that spans more than half the length of the drawn line.
2.  Calculate the gradient using the formula: `G = (Change in Tc) / (Change in Vc)`. For example, using two points (0.90 V, 34.0 °C) and (1.60 V, 54.0 °C) from the sample graph:
    G = (54.0 °C - 34.0 °C) / (1.60 V - 0.90 V)
    G = 20.0 °C / 0.70 V
    G ≈ 28.6 °C/V.
    The value should be calculated correctly with appropriate significant figures and unit (°C/V).

**To determine Q (y-intercept):**
1.  Extend the best-fit line until it intersects the y-axis (where Vc = 0).
2.  Read the value of Tc at this intersection point, which is Q. Alternatively, Q can be calculated by substituting G and one data point (Vc, Tc) into the equation `Q = Tc - G * Vc`.
    For example, using G = 28.6 °C/V and point (0.90 V, 34.0 °C):
    Q = 34.0 °C - (28.6 °C/V * 0.90 V)
    Q = 34.0 °C - 25.74 °C
    Q ≈ 8.26 °C.
    The value should be recorded with appropriate significant figures and unit (°C). A graphical read from the sample graph shows Q ≈ 8.56 °C.

context_text: The body temperature can be measured with a thermistor. The task is to calculate the voltage VN across the thermistor when the temperature is 37.0 °C. The provided equation is `VN = VR - (37.0 - TR) / G`. We will use the previously established values: VR = 3.60 V (room temperature voltage), TR = 32.0 °C (room temperature), and G = 28.6 °C/V (gradient from the graph).
question_text: Calculate the voltage VN across the thermistor when temperature is 37.0 °C using the equation shown. `VN = VR - (37.0 - TR) / G`
answer_text:
Using the given equation `VN = VR - (37.0 - TR) / G` and the sample values:
VR = 3.60 V
TR = 32.0 °C
G = 28.6 °C/V

VN = 3.60 V - (37.0 °C - 32.0 °C) / 28.6 °C/V
VN = 3.60 V - (5.0 °C) / 28.6 °C/V
VN = 3.60 V - 0.1748 V
VN ≈ 3.4252 V
VN ≈ 3.43 V (to 3 significant figures)

The calculated voltage VN should have the correct unit (V) and appropriate significant figures based on the candidate's values for VR, TR, and G.

context_text: The ball is thrown vertically downwards with an initial speed (u) of 8.4 m/s. It reaches the ground with a final speed (v) after time (t). The acceleration due to gravity (a) is 10 m/s², acting downwards. Air resistance is negligible, meaning acceleration is constant.
question_text: Assuming acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/s², express t in terms of v.
answer_text: Using the equation of motion v = u + at, where v is the final velocity, u is the initial velocity (8.4 m/s), a is the acceleration due to gravity (10 m/s²), and t is the time. Substituting the given values: v = 8.4 + 10t. Rearranging to express t in terms of v: 10t = v - 8.4, so t = (v - 8.4) / 10.

context_text: The ball is thrown downwards from a height of 5.0 m with an initial velocity (u) of 8.4 m/s. It reaches the ground with a final velocity (v) after time (t). The acceleration due to gravity (a) is 10 m/s². The velocity-time graph (from part a) is a trapezium with parallel sides representing the initial velocity (8.4 m/s) and final velocity (v m/s), and the height representing the time (t). The area under this graph represents the distance travelled (5.0 m). The expression from part b(i) is t = (v - 8.4) / 10.
question_text: Using your sketch in (a) and expression in b(i), determine the speed, v m/s, which the ball hits the ground.
answer_text: The distance travelled is the area under the velocity-time graph, which is a trapezium. The area of the trapezium is given by ½ * (sum of parallel sides) * height. Here, the parallel sides are the initial velocity (u = 8.4 m/s) and the final velocity (v), and the height is the time (t). So, Distance = ½ * (u + v) * t. We are given the distance is 5.0 m. Substituting the values: 5.0 = ½ * (8.4 + v) * t. From part (b)(i), we have t = (v - 8.4) / 10. Substitute this expression for t into the distance equation: 5.0 = ½ * (8.4 + v) * ((v - 8.4) / 10). This simplifies to 5.0 = (v² - 8.4²) / 20. So, 100 = v² - 70.56. v² = 170.56. Taking the square root, v = √170.56 ≈ 13.06 m/s. Rounded to 3 significant figures, v = 13.1 m/s.

context_text: This question requires stating a fundamental principle in physics related to rotational equilibrium.
question_text: State the principle of moments.
answer_text: The principle of moments states that for a body to be in rotational equilibrium, the sum of all clockwise moments about any chosen pivot must be equal to the sum of all anticlockwise moments about the same pivot.

context_text: A diagram shows a horizontal handrail in equilibrium, supported by two vertical supports at points A and B. Point A is on the left and point B is on the right. The bar has two downward forces: 700 N at 1.0 m to the right of A, and 500 N at 3.0 m to the right of A (1.0 m + 2.0 m). The upward force at A is F1, and the upward force at B is F2. The total distance from A to B is 4.0 m (1.0 m + 2.0 m + 1.0 m). The problem asks to take moments about A to find F2.
question_text: Taking moments about A, determine the value of F2.
answer_text:
Taking moments about point A:
Clockwise moments = (700 N × 1.0 m) + (500 N × 3.0 m) = 700 Nm + 1500 Nm = 2200 Nm.
Anticlockwise moments = (F2 × 4.0 m).
According to the principle of moments, for equilibrium, the sum of clockwise moments equals the sum of anticlockwise moments:
2200 Nm = F2 × 4.0 m
F2 = 2200 Nm / 4.0 m
F2 = 550 N.

context_text: A horizontal handrail is in vertical equilibrium. The upward forces are F1 at support A and F2 at support B. The total downward force is the sum of a 700 N force and a 500 N force. From part (b)(i), the value of F2 is 550 N.
question_text: Hence, find the value of F1.
answer_text:
For the handrail to be in vertical equilibrium, the sum of the upward forces must equal the sum of the downward forces.
Upward forces: F1 + F2
Downward forces: 700 N + 500 N = 1200 N
So, F1 + F2 = 1200 N
Substitute the value of F2 = 550 N:
F1 + 550 N = 1200 N
F1 = 1200 N - 550 N
F1 = 650 N.

context_text: A student boards a train and stands between a man and a lady, but has no handle to hold onto. The train comes to a sudden stop. The question asks for a way to stand to increase stability, relating to the base area and center of gravity.
question_text: Using your knowledge of stability, suggest one way how the student should stand on the train so that she does not fall over when it comes to a sudden stop at the next station.
answer_text: To increase stability and prevent falling during a sudden stop, the student should increase her base area and/or lower her center of gravity. One effective way to achieve this is to stand with her feet apart, which widens the base of support. Another way is to bend her knees slightly, which lowers her center of gravity, making it harder for the line of action of her weight to fall outside her base of support.

context_text: This question asks for a fundamental principle in physics related to energy.
question_text: State the principle of conservation of energy.
answer_text: The principle of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed. Instead, it can only be converted from one form to another, or transferred from one energy store to another. Consequently, the total energy of an isolated system remains constant.

context_text: A ball of mass 0.30 kg is projected horizontally with a speed of 8.0 m/s from point A, which is 45 m above the level ground. It moves in a parabolic path. Point B is a point on this parabolic path, 32 m above the ground. As the ball moves from A to B, its height decreases, and its speed changes.
question_text: Describe the energy transfer as the ball moves from A to B.
answer_text: As the ball moves from point A (height 45 m) to point B (height 32 m), its height decreases. This means its gravitational potential energy (GPE) decreases. This decrease in GPE is primarily converted into kinetic energy (KE), causing the ball's speed to increase. Thus, energy is transferred from the gravitational potential energy store of the ball to its kinetic energy store. Additionally, some energy may be dissipated as heat and sound to the surroundings due to work done against air resistance.

context_text: A diagram, drawn to scale, shows positions of particles in a longitudinal wave. Vertical lines represent original undisturbed positions, and dots represent air particles. Regions where particles are spread apart are rarefactions (less dense), and regions where particles are close together are compressions (denser). The question provides two empty boxes aligned with different particle distributions.
question_text: In the boxes provided, write down if the particle at that position is in a region of compression, C, or rarefaction, R.
answer_text: The first box, covering a region where the particles (dots) are spread out more than their undisturbed positions (lines), represents a region of **R**arefaction. The second box, covering a region where the particles (dots) are closer together than their undisturbed positions (lines), represents a region of **C**ompression.

context_text: The diagram illustrating the longitudinal wave is stated to be "drawn to scale". To find the magnitude of the wavelength, one must measure the distance between two consecutive identical points on the wave, such as the distance between the centers of two adjacent compressions or two adjacent rarefactions, using a ruler directly on the diagram.
question_text: State the magnitude of the wavelength.
answer_text: By measuring the marked wavelength (λ) directly from the diagram, the magnitude of the wavelength is approximately **9.5 cm** (acceptable range 9.5 cm to 9.6 cm due to measurement variations).

context_text: A student's notes depict the electromagnetic spectrum with the following order: gamma rays, X-rays, ultra violet, micro waves, infra red, radio waves. An arrow points to the left labeled "increasing wavelength".
question_text: Make corrections to two errors in the student's notes.
answer_text:
Two errors in the student's notes are:
1.  **Incorrect order of infra-red and microwaves:** In the correct electromagnetic spectrum, moving from higher frequency/shorter wavelength to lower frequency/longer wavelength, the order should be Ultraviolet, Visible light, Infrared, Microwaves. The student has 'micro waves' before 'infra red'.
2.  **Incorrect direction for increasing wavelength:** The arrow indicates 'increasing wavelength' to the left. However, in the standard electromagnetic spectrum, wavelength increases from gamma rays (shortest wavelength) to radio waves (longest wavelength). Given the order in the notes (gamma to radio), the arrow pointing left would indicate 'increasing frequency', or the arrow should point right for 'increasing wavelength'.

context_text: Gamma rays are a form of high-energy electromagnetic radiation. Exposure to such radiation can have biological effects.
question_text: Describe the effect of extended gamma ray exposure on human cells.
answer_text: Extended exposure to gamma rays can cause significant damage to human cells. Gamma rays are highly ionizing radiation, meaning they can strip electrons from atoms and molecules within the cells. This ionization disrupts chemical bonds, damages vital cellular components like DNA, and interferes with normal cellular processes, leading to cell damage, mutations, uncontrolled cell growth (cancer), or cell death.

context_text: The diagram (Fig 12.1) shows a 1.60 m tall lady standing 0.50 m in front of a vertical plane mirror. Her reflection is shown to her right. The task is to draw light rays from her head and feet to her eye, reflecting off the mirror.
question_text: Draw one light ray to show how the lady sees through the mirror (i) the top of her head, and (ii) her feet.
answer_text:
To show how the lady sees the top of her head: Draw an incident ray from the top of her head to the mirror, and a reflected ray from that point on the mirror to her eye. Extend the reflected ray backwards as a dashed line to show it originates from the virtual image of her head.
To show how the lady sees her feet: Draw an incident ray from her feet to a lower point on the mirror, and a reflected ray from that point on the mirror to her eye. Extend this reflected ray backwards as a dashed line to show it originates from the virtual image of her feet.
Both incident and reflected rays should be drawn with arrows indicating their direction of travel.

context_text: The E.M.F. of the battery is 6.0 V (calculated in 8a(i)). The PQR branch consists of a 2.0 Ω resistor and a 4.0 Ω resistor in series, making its total resistance 6.0 Ω. The switch QS is open, so the current flows only through the series combination PQR. The voltage across parallel branches is the same as the E.M.F. of the battery.
question_text: Calculate the current flowing in PQR.
answer_text:
The voltage across the PQR branch is equal to the E.M.F. of the battery, which is 6.0 V. The total resistance of the PQR branch (R_PQR) is the sum of the series resistors: 2.0 Ω + 4.0 Ω = 6.0 Ω.
Using Ohm's Law (V = IR):
Current in PQR (I_PQR) = V / R_PQR = 6.0 V / 6.0 Ω = 1.0 A.

context_text: The setup involves a conducting rod PQ in a magnetic field, where current causes a magnetic force, changing the newton meter readings. The magnitude of the magnetic force (F) on a current-carrying conductor is directly proportional to the current (I) flowing through it (F = BILsinθ). To control the change in readings, the magnetic force needs to be controlled.
question_text: Describe how you can modify the set-up so that the change in the newton meter readings can be controlled.
answer_text: To control the change in the newton meter readings, which is directly related to the magnetic force on the rod, the current flowing through the rod needs to be adjustable. This can be achieved by incorporating a **variable resistor (rheostat)** in series with the power supply and the conducting rod in the circuit. By varying the resistance of the rheostat, the current (I) in the circuit can be precisely controlled, thereby regulating the magnetic force (F=BILsinθ) and thus the change in the newton meter readings.

context_text: The setup involves a conducting rod PQ in a magnetic field. Initially, a DC battery caused a steady force. Now, the battery is replaced by an A.C. (alternating current) source with a frequency of 0.50 Hz. The motor effect force on the rod depends on the direction of the current.
question_text: If the battery is replaced by an a.c. source of frequency 0.50 Hz, describe the motion of the rod with respect to time when the switch is closed.
answer_text:
When the battery is replaced by an A.C. source with a frequency of 0.50 Hz, the direction of the current in the rod will periodically reverse. Since the direction of the magnetic force on the rod is dependent on the direction of the current (according to Fleming's Left-Hand Rule), the force will also periodically reverse direction.
The frequency of 0.50 Hz means that the current completes one full cycle of direction change in a period (T) of 1/f = 1/0.50 Hz = 2.0 seconds. During one half-cycle (1.0 second), the current flows in one direction, causing a force (e.g., downwards). During the next half-cycle (the subsequent 1.0 second), the current reverses, causing the force to act in the opposite direction (e.g., upwards). Therefore, the rod will **oscillate up and down**, completing one full oscillation (moving down and then up, or vice versa) every **2.0 seconds**.

context_text: Table 10.1 provides specifications of aluminium rods: Dimensions (length x diameter) are 5.00 cm x 2.66 cm, and the density of aluminium is 2.7 g/cm³. The rod is cylindrical, so its volume can be calculated using V = π * (d/2)² * l, and then mass = density * volume.
question_text: Calculate the mass of each aluminium rod. Leave your answer to the nearest gram.
answer_text:
1.  Calculate the radius (r) of the rod: r = diameter / 2 = 2.66 cm / 2 = 1.33 cm.
2.  Calculate the volume (V) of the rod: V = π × r² × length = π × (1.33 cm)² × 5.00 cm = π × 1.7689 cm² × 5.00 cm ≈ 27.784 cm³.
3.  Calculate the mass (m) of the rod: m = density × V = 2.7 g/cm³ × 27.784 cm³ ≈ 75.0168 g.
Rounding to the nearest gram, the mass of each aluminium rod is **75 g**.

context_text: The mass (m) of each aluminium rod is 75 g (0.075 kg) from part (a). The specific heat capacity (c) of aluminium (from Table 10.1) is 880 J/kg°C. Table 10.2 shows the temperature of the rods over time: at 0 s, the temperature is 0 °C, and at 600 s, the temperature is 650 °C. The change in temperature (Δθ) is 650 °C - 0 °C = 650 °C. The formula for heat energy supplied to change temperature is Q = mcΔθ.
question_text: Calculate the energy supplied to each rod between 0 s to 600 s.
answer_text:
The energy supplied (Q) to each rod to increase its temperature can be calculated using the formula Q = mcΔθ, where:
m = mass of the aluminium rod = 75 g = 0.075 kg (from part a)
c = specific heat capacity of aluminium = 880 J/kg°C
Δθ = change in temperature = Final temperature - Initial temperature
From Table 10.2, at 0 s, temperature is 0 °C. At 600 s, temperature is 650 °C.
Δθ = 650 °C - 0 °C = 650 °C
Q = 0.075 kg × 880 J/kg°C × 650 °C = 42900 J.
The energy supplied to each rod between 0 s and 600 s is **42900 J**.

context_text: Table 10.2 shows the temperature of rods versus time. Between 600 s and 1000 s, the temperature of the aluminium rods remains constant at 650 °C, even though heating is ongoing (implied by being in a furnace). This indicates a phase change (melting) is occurring. According to the kinetic model of matter, the internal energy of a substance is the sum of the kinetic energy and potential energy of its constituent particles.
question_text: Using your understanding of the kinetic model of matter, describe the effect of heating on the amount of energy in the internal store of the aluminium rods from 600 – 1000 s.
answer_text:
From 600 s to 1000 s, the temperature of the aluminium rods remains constant at 650 °C. This constant temperature during continuous heating indicates that the aluminium is undergoing a phase change, specifically melting, at its melting point. According to the kinetic model of matter:
1.  The kinetic energy of the aluminium particles remains constant because the temperature, which is a measure of the average kinetic energy of the particles, does not change during a phase change.
2.  The supplied heat energy is used to overcome the intermolecular forces of attraction between the particles, allowing them to move further apart and transition from a more ordered solid state to a less ordered liquid state. This process increases the internal potential energy of the particles.
Therefore, the total internal energy of the aluminium rods increases during this period, primarily due to an increase in internal potential energy.

context_text: An aluminium rod (m_Al = 0.075 kg, from part a) at an initial temperature (θ_Al_initial) of 70 °C is placed into 350 g of water (m_water = 0.350 kg). The specific heat capacity of water (c_water) is 4200 J/kg°C. The specific heat capacity of aluminium (c_Al) is 880 J/kg°C (from Table 10.1). The system reaches an equilibrium temperature (θ_final) of 30 °C. The principle of calorimetry states that heat lost by the hotter object equals heat gained by the colder object, assuming no heat loss to the surroundings.
question_text: Determine the initial temperature of the water, given that the specific heat capacity of water is 4200 J/kg°C.
answer_text:
According to the principle of calorimetry, assuming no heat loss to the surroundings, heat lost by the aluminium rod equals heat gained by the water.
Heat lost by aluminium rod (Q_Al) = m_Al × c_Al × (θ_Al_initial - θ_final)
Q_Al = 0.075 kg × 880 J/kg°C × (70 °C - 30 °C)
Q_Al = 0.075 × 880 × 40 = 2640 J.
Heat gained by water (Q_water) = m_water × c_water × (θ_final - θ_water_initial)
Q_water = 0.350 kg × 4200 J/kg°C × (30 °C - θ_water_initial)
Since Q_Al = Q_water:
2640 J = 0.350 kg × 4200 J/kg°C × (30 °C - θ_water_initial)
2640 = 1470 × (30 - θ_water_initial)
30 - θ_water_initial = 2640 / 1470 ≈ 1.7959
θ_water_initial = 30 - 1.7959 = 28.2041 °C.
Rounding to one decimal place, the initial temperature of the water is **28.2 °C**.

context_text: The text states that Carbon-14 is a radioactive isotope of carbon. The question asks for the meaning of this statement.
question_text: State what is meant by the following statements. Carbon-14 is an isotope of carbon.
answer_text: Carbon-14 is an isotope of carbon means that it is an atom of carbon that has the same number of protons (and thus the same atomic number) as other forms of carbon, but a different number of neutrons. This difference in neutron count results in a different mass number (14) for Carbon-14 compared to other common carbon isotopes like Carbon-12 or Carbon-13.

context_text: The text states that Carbon-14 has a half-life of 5730 years. The question asks for the meaning of this statement.
question_text: State what is meant by the following statements. Carbon-14 has a half-life of 5730 years.
answer_text: Carbon-14 having a half-life of 5730 years means that for any given sample of Carbon-14, it will take 5730 years for exactly half of its radioactive nuclei to undergo radioactive decay. Alternatively, it means that after 5730 years, the activity (rate of decay) of a Carbon-14 sample will reduce to half of its initial value.

context_text: The question states that constant exposure to beta radiation is harmful to the body. Beta radiation consists of high-energy electrons (or positrons), which are a form of ionizing radiation.
question_text: Describe the effect of constant exposure to beta radiation on the human body.
answer_text: Constant exposure to beta radiation is harmful because beta particles are a form of ionizing radiation. When these high-energy particles penetrate human tissues, they can collide with and eject electrons from atoms and molecules within cells. This process of ionization can disrupt chemical bonds, damage vital cellular components like DNA, and interfere with normal biological processes. This can lead to cellular dysfunction, genetic mutations, cell death, and an increased risk of developing health conditions such as burns, radiation sickness, and various types of cancer.

context_text: People work with beta radiation. Beta radiation has moderate penetrating power, being able to penetrate skin and some light materials. The question asks for one precaution to reduce health risks.
question_text: Write down one precaution that people working with beta radiation should take to reduce the risk to their health.
answer_text: To reduce the risk from beta radiation, one important precaution is to use appropriate **shielding**. Since beta particles can penetrate skin and cause internal damage, materials such as a thin sheet of aluminium, plastic, or even thick clothing and gloves can be effective at absorbing most beta particles. Other precautions include minimizing the time of exposure and maximizing the distance from the radioactive source.

context_text: Carbon-14 has a half-life of 5730 years. An identical bone in a living animal contains 80 units of carbon-14. A bone taken from an archaeological site contains 5 units of carbon-14. The age of the bone is determined by calculating how many half-lives have passed.
question_text: A bone taken from an archaeological site was found to contain 5 units of carbon-14. An identical bone in a living animal contains 80 units of carbon-14. Determine the age of the bone.
answer_text:
The initial amount of Carbon-14 in a living animal's bone is 80 units. The archaeological bone has 5 units. We need to find how many half-lives have occurred for the amount to decrease from 80 units to 5 units:
1.  After 1 half-life: 80 units × (1/2) = 40 units.
2.  After 2 half-lives: 40 units × (1/2) = 20 units.
3.  After 3 half-lives: 20 units × (1/2) = 10 units.
4.  After 4 half-lives: 10 units × (1/2) = 5 units.
So, 4 half-lives have passed.
The age of the bone = Number of half-lives × Half-life period
Age = 4 × 5730 years = 22920 years.
The age of the bone is **22920 years**.

context_text: A 750 g fish hangs from a spring balance. The reading on the spring balance equals the tension acting on the fish. The lift is stationary. When stationary, the fish is in equilibrium, meaning the net force on it is zero. The mass (m) of the fish is 750 g (0.750 kg). Acceleration due to gravity (g) is typically assumed to be 10 N/kg or 10 m/s².
question_text: State the reading on the spring balance when the lift is stationary.
answer_text:
When the lift is stationary, the fish is in equilibrium, so the net force acting on it is zero. This means the upward tension (T) from the spring balance is equal in magnitude to the downward weight (W) of the fish.
Mass of fish (m) = 750 g = 0.750 kg.
Weight (W) = m × g = 0.750 kg × 10 N/kg = 7.5 N.
Therefore, the reading on the spring balance is **7.5 N**.

context_text: A 750 g fish (mass m = 0.750 kg) hangs from a spring balance. The weight (W) of the fish is 7.5 N. The lift is now accelerating upwards (a) at 1.5 m/s². According to Newton's Second Law, the net force (F_net) acting on the fish is equal to its mass times its acceleration (F_net = ma). The forces acting on the fish are upward tension (T) from the spring balance and downward weight (W). Since the acceleration is upwards, the upward tension must be greater than the downward weight.
question_text: Calculate the reading on the spring balance when the lift is accelerating up at 1.5 m/s².
answer_text:
When the lift accelerates upwards, the fish experiences a net upward force. Applying Newton's Second Law (F_net = ma):
The net force is the difference between the upward tension (T) and the downward weight (W). Since the acceleration is upwards, T must be greater than W:
T - W = ma
We know:
m = 0.750 kg
W = 7.5 N (from part ii)
a = 1.5 m/s² (upwards)
Substitute the values:
T - 7.5 N = 0.750 kg × 1.5 m/s²
T - 7.5 = 1.125
T = 7.5 + 1.125 = 8.625 N.
Rounding to three significant figures, the reading on the spring balance is **8.63 N**.

context_text: A diagram (Fig 12.1) shows the side view of a "pickup" for an electric guitar. A steel guitar string is positioned above a coil of wire. Inside the coil, there is a permanent magnet with its North pole (N) at the top, nearest to the string, and its South pole (S) at the bottom. The question asks to indicate the induced polarity on the side of the guitar string nearest to the permanent magnet.
question_text: On Fig 12.1, indicate the induced polarity on the side of the guitar string that is nearest to the permanent magnet.
answer_text: The permanent magnet has its North pole (N) facing the steel guitar string. According to the principle of magnetic induction, when a ferromagnetic material (like the steel string) is brought near a magnet, an opposite pole will be induced in the part of the material closest to the magnet. Therefore, a **South pole (S)** should be indicated on the bottom surface of the guitar string, directly facing the North pole of the permanent magnet.

context_text: An electrical signal (induced e.m.f. and current) is produced in the coil when the guitar string vibrates, due to electromagnetic induction. The strength of this induced e.m.f. depends on the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage through the coil, according to Faraday's Law. The question asks for ways to increase the signal strength without changing the strength of the permanent magnet.
question_text: Suggest how the strength of the electrical signal can be increased without changing the strength of the magnet.
answer_text:
To increase the strength of the electrical signal (induced e.m.f.) without changing the strength of the permanent magnet, several modifications can be made:
1.  **Increase the number of turns in the coil:** A greater number of turns means more magnetic flux lines are cut per unit time for a given change in flux, leading to a larger induced e.m.f.
2.  **Move the string closer to the coil/magnet:** Reducing the average distance between the vibrating string and the coil/magnet will increase the magnetic flux linkage with the coil. For a given vibration, this results in a faster and larger rate of change of magnetic flux, inducing a stronger e.m.f.
3.  **Vibrate the string with a greater amplitude or velocity:** Plucking the string with a greater force will make it vibrate with a larger amplitude and/or faster speed. This leads to a more rapid and significant change in magnetic flux linkage through the coil, thereby inducing a stronger e.m.f.

context_text: A U-tube glass is used to determine the density of oil. Oil is poured into the left arm, and water into the right arm. The diagram, and the solution's calculation, imply effective heights for balancing pressures are: height of oil (h_oil) = 27.2 cm = 0.272 m, and height of water (h_water) = 24.5 cm = 0.245 m. The density of water (ρ_water) is 1000 kg/m³, and acceleration due to gravity (g) is 10 m/s². At the common horizontal level within the continuous mercury, the pressure exerted by the oil column equals the pressure exerted by the water column.
question_text: Calculate the density of oil.
answer_text:
At the common horizontal level within the continuous mercury, the pressure exerted by the oil column on the left arm must be equal to the pressure exerted by the water column on the right arm. Assuming the effective heights for balancing are h_oil = 0.272 m and h_water = 0.245 m (as used in the provided solution):
Pressure due to oil = Pressure due to water
h_oil × ρ_oil × g = h_water × ρ_water × g
0.272 m × ρ_oil × 10 m/s² = 0.245 m × 1000 kg/m³ × 10 m/s²
0.272 × ρ_oil = 0.245 × 1000
ρ_oil = 245 / 0.272 ≈ 900.735 kg/m³.
Rounding to 3 significant figures, the density of oil is **901 kg/m³**.

context_text: Point B is located at the interface between the water and mercury in the right arm of the U-tube. The pressure at point B is the sum of the atmospheric pressure acting on the surface of the water and the pressure due to the column of water above point B. The atmospheric pressure (P_atm) is 101000 Pa. The density of water (ρ_water) is 1000 kg/m³. Acceleration due to gravity (g) is 10 m/s². The height of the water column (h_water) is taken as 0.245 m (24.5 cm), as consistently implied by the numerical values used in the provided solution for this problem part (instead of the 5.50 cm explicitly labeled for the water column height in the diagram, which appears contradictory).
question_text: Calculate the pressure at B.
answer_text:
The pressure at point B is the sum of the atmospheric pressure and the pressure exerted by the water column above B.
Pressure at B (P_B) = P_atm + (h_water × ρ_water × g)
Using the effective height of water as 0.245 m (24.5 cm), as implied by the solution's consistent use of this value:
P_B = 101000 Pa + (0.245 m × 1000 kg/m³ × 10 m/s²)
P_B = 101000 Pa + 2450 Pa
P_B = 103450 Pa.
Rounding to 3 significant figures, the pressure at B is **103000 Pa**.

context_text: The initial setup has a U-tube with uniform cross-sectional area, containing oil and water, balanced by mercury. Now, an identical U-tube is used, but the left arm (oil side) has a cone-shaped opening, meaning its cross-sectional area increases with height. The right arm (water side) remains uniform. The tube contains the same volume of mercury, and the same volume of water is poured into the right side. The question asks whether the height of the oil needs to be equal, less than, or greater than the previous setup to maintain the same mercury levels at A and B.
question_text: State and explain if the height of the oil in this set-up will be equal, less than or greater than the previous one in order to maintain the height of the mercury at A and B.
answer_text:
The height of the oil in this new set-up will be **equal** to the previous one.
This is because the pressure exerted by a column of liquid depends only on its height (h), its density (ρ), and the acceleration due to gravity (g), according to the formula P = hρg. The pressure exerted by a liquid column is independent of the shape of the container or the cross-sectional area of the column, as long as the column is supported. To maintain the same mercury levels (and thus the same pressure balance) as in the previous setup, the pressure exerted by the oil column must remain constant. Since the density of the oil and gravitational acceleration are constant, the height of the oil column must also remain the same, regardless of the cone-shaped opening or the varying cross-sectional area.

context_text: A negatively charged metal sphere with an insulated handle is brought near to an uncharged metal plate. The metal plate is connected to a galvanometer (G) and is earthed. The galvanometer shows a momentary deflection.
question_text: Explain why there was a momentary deflection in the galvanometer when the metal sphere was brought near to the metal plate.
answer_text: When the negatively charged metal sphere is brought near the uncharged metal plate, the free electrons within the metal plate are repelled by the negative charge of the sphere due to electrostatic induction (like charges repel). Since the metal plate is connected to the ground via the galvanometer, these repelled electrons flow away from the metal plate, through the galvanometer, and into the Earth. This temporary flow of electrons constitutes a momentary current, which causes the galvanometer to show a temporary deflection, indicating the movement of charge.

context_text: A negatively charged metal sphere is brought near an uncharged metal plate, which is connected to a galvanometer and earthed. This causes electrons to be repelled from the plate to the earth, resulting in a momentary galvanometer deflection. Consequently, the metal plate loses negative charges and is left with a net positive charge. The question asks to draw this charge distribution on the metal plate.
question_text: On Fig 13.1, draw the distribution of the charges on the metal plate after the deflection in the galvanometer.
answer_text: After electrons are repelled from the metal plate and flow to the ground, the metal plate is left with a net positive charge. These positive charges are immobile within the metal lattice and will be attracted by the negatively charged sphere. Therefore, positive (+) signs should be drawn distributed on the left surface of the metal plate, facing the negatively charged metal sphere, indicating the induced positive charge concentration.

context_text: A negatively charged metal sphere with an insulated handle is brought near an uncharged metal plate, causing a momentary deflection in the galvanometer. Now, consider if the metal sphere was held directly in a person's hand instead of an insulated handle and then brought near the metal plate. The human body is a conductor, which can provide a path for charge to flow to or from the Earth.
question_text: State and explain what will happen to the galvanometer if the metal sphere was held directly in a person's hand instead and brought near to the metal plate.
answer_text: If the negatively charged metal sphere was held directly in a person's hand, the excess negative charges on the sphere would flow through the person's body (which acts as a conductor to the ground) and into the Earth. This transfer of charge would effectively neutralize the metal sphere before it is even brought near the metal plate. When a neutral sphere is subsequently brought near the metal plate, there will be no electrostatic induction on the plate, and therefore no flow of charge to or from the Earth through the galvanometer. Consequently, the **galvanometer will not show any deflection**.

context_text: A ruler is shown, marked in centimeters from 0 cm to 11 cm. A small cylinder is depicted at two positions. Its 'start' position has a mark on the cylinder aligned with the 0 cm mark on the ruler. After completing 'two revolutions', the cylinder's mark is aligned with the 8.7 cm mark on the ruler. The cylinder's position is indicated by its left edge and the 'mark on cylinder' at 0 cm for 'start' and at 8.7 cm for 'finish'.
question_text:
A small cylinder is rolled along a ruler and completes two revolutions. What is the circumference of the cylinder?
A 4.4 cm
B 5.2 cm
C 8.7 cm
D 10.1 cm
answer_text:
The distance covered by the cylinder in two revolutions is the difference between the finish mark and the start mark on the ruler: 8.7 cm - 0 cm = 8.7 cm.
Since the cylinder completes two revolutions, the total distance covered is equal to two times its circumference.
Let C be the circumference of the cylinder.
2 * C = 8.7 cm
C = 8.7 cm / 2 = 4.35 cm.
Among the given options, 4.4 cm is the closest value.

context_text: The diagram shows a simple mercury barometer next to a mercury manometer. The barometer on the left has a mercury column of 76 cm, indicating atmospheric pressure (P_atm) is 76 cm of mercury. The manometer on the right is a U-shaped tube with mercury, where one arm contains 'trapped gas' and the other arm (implicitly open to the atmosphere) has higher mercury levels. The mercury level in the arm with the trapped gas is at 30 cm on the scale, and the mercury level in the other arm is at 60 cm on the scale. The height difference between the mercury levels in the manometer is 60 cm - 30 cm = 30 cm.
question_text:
What is the pressure of the trapped gas?
A 10 cm of mercury
B 50 cm of mercury
C 66 cm of mercury
D 86 cm of mercury
answer_text:
From the barometer, the atmospheric pressure (P_atm) = 76 cm of mercury.
In the manometer, the mercury level in the arm open to the atmosphere (left side, at 60 cm) is higher than the mercury level in the arm connected to the trapped gas (right side, at 30 cm).
This indicates that the pressure of the trapped gas (P_gas) is less than the atmospheric pressure.
The difference in mercury levels (h) = 60 cm - 30 cm = 30 cm.
Therefore, the pressure of the trapped gas is:
P_gas = P_atm - h
P_gas = 76 cm Hg - 30 cm Hg = 46 cm Hg.

Note: The calculated value of 46 cm Hg is not among the given options (10 cm, 50 cm, 66 cm, 86 cm). This suggests a potential discrepancy in the question's values or options provided. If forced to choose an option, and assuming an error in the visual representation of height difference, option D (86 cm Hg) would imply P_gas = P_atm + 10 cm Hg, meaning the trapped gas pressure is higher and the height difference is 10 cm. However, based strictly on the provided visual and barometer reading, the calculated pressure is 46 cm Hg.

context_text: The diagram shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer with calibration marks. At 0 °C, the length of the liquid column is 2.0 cm. At 100 °C, the length of the liquid column is 22.0 cm. The thermometer operates linearly.
question_text:
What is the length of the liquid column at 40 °C?
A 6.0 cm
B 8.0 cm
C 8.8 cm
D 10.0 cm
answer_text:
Given:
- Length at 0 °C (L₀) = 2.0 cm
- Length at 100 °C (L₁₀₀) = 22.0 cm

The change in length for a 100 °C temperature change is:
ΔL = L₁₀₀ - L₀ = 22.0 cm - 2.0 cm = 20.0 cm.

The change in length per degree Celsius (sensitivity) is:
Length_per_degree = ΔL / 100 °C = 20.0 cm / 100 °C = 0.20 cm/°C.

To find the length at 40 °C, we calculate the increase in length from 0 °C to 40 °C:
Increase_in_length = 40 °C × 0.20 cm/°C = 8.0 cm.

Finally, the total length of the liquid column at 40 °C is:
L₄₀ = L₀ + Increase_in_length = 2.0 cm + 8.0 cm = 10.0 cm.

Therefore, the length of the liquid column at 40 °C is 10.0 cm.

context_text: When the Brownian motion of smoke particles in air is observed with a microscope, bright specks of light are seen.
question_text:
When the Brownian motion of smoke particles in air is observed with a microscope, bright specks of light are seen. These bright specks of light are reflections from
A air molecules only, moving randomly.
B both smoke particles and air molecules, moving randomly.
C smoke particles only, moving randomly.
D smoke particles only, vibrating.
answer_text: Brownian motion describes the erratic, random movement of microscopic particles (like smoke particles) suspended in a fluid (like air or liquid) due to collisions with the much smaller, invisible, fast-moving molecules of the fluid (air molecules). When observing this phenomenon under a microscope, the 'bright specks of light' that are seen are light reflected from the larger smoke particles. These smoke particles are observed to move randomly as a direct result of the collisions with the air molecules. The air molecules themselves are too small to be seen directly by the microscope, so the reflections are from the smoke particles, which are undergoing random motion.

context_text: A diagram shows a red-hot electric 'grill' positioned above a 'slice of bread'.
question_text:
A slice of bread is placed under a red-hot electric grill to make toast. How is thermal energy transferred from the grill to the bread?
A radiation only
B conduction and radiation
C convection and radiation
D conduction, convection and radiation
answer_text:
Thermal energy transfer from a red-hot electric grill to bread primarily occurs through radiation. The hot grill elements emit infrared radiation, which travels directly through the air to the bread and is absorbed, heating it.
Additionally, the air directly in contact with the hot grill elements will be heated by conduction from the grill. This heated air can then transfer some thermal energy to the surface of the bread through conduction (direct contact between hot air molecules and the bread surface). While convection currents (bulk movement of heated air) typically rise from a heat source, making them less efficient for heating an object directly beneath it, some heat transfer via the heated air to the bread via conduction still occurs. Therefore, the significant modes of transfer are radiation and some conduction through the intervening air.

context_text:
The diagram shows a transverse 'rope wave' propagating from point A to point B, which means the wave is moving to the right. Three specific points, P, Q, and R, are marked on the wave at a particular instant.
- Point P is located at the peak (crest) of the wave.
- Point Q is at the equilibrium position, where the wave is sloping downwards.
- Point R is located at the bottom (trough) of the wave.
question_text: The diagram shows a rope wave moving from point A to B. P, Q and R are points on the wave. At the particular instant shown, what is the direction of movement of points P, Q and R?
answer_text:
To determine the direction of movement of points on a transverse wave, imagine the wave propagating slightly forward in time. Since the wave is moving from A to B (to the right):
- Point P is at a crest. As the wave moves slightly to the right, the crest will pass point P, and P will move **downwards** from its peak position.
- Point Q is at the equilibrium position, on a downward slope. As the wave moves slightly to the right, the portion of the wave to the left of Q (which is above Q) will move into Q's current position. Therefore, Q will move **upwards** from its equilibrium position.
- Point R is at a trough. As the wave moves slightly to the right, the trough will pass point R, and R will move **upwards** from its lowest position.

Thus, the directions of movement are: P: down, Q: up, R: up. This corresponds to option B in the provided table.

context_text: The problem states that the wavelengths of visible light range from 4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m to 7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m. A table provides four combinations of wavelengths for 'infrared', 'red light', and 'violet light'.
question_text: The wavelengths of visible light range from 4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m to 7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m. Which combination represents wavelengths for infrared, red and violet light?
answer_text:
To determine the correct combination, we need to recall the relative wavelengths of different parts of the electromagnetic spectrum:
1.  **Visible light:** Ranges from approximately 4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m (violet) to 7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m (red).
2.  **Red light:** Has the longest wavelength within the visible spectrum, close to 7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m.
3.  **Violet light:** Has the shortest wavelength within the visible spectrum, close to 4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m.
4.  **Infrared radiation:** Has wavelengths longer than red light, typically ranging from about 7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m up to 1 millimeter (10⁻³ m).

Let's evaluate the options:
-   **A: infrared = 1.0 x 10⁻⁴ m, red light = 4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m, violet light = 7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m**
    -   Infrared (1.0 x 10⁻⁴ m) is longer than red light, which is correct.
    -   Red light (4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m) is incorrect; this is the wavelength for violet light.
    -   Violet light (7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m) is incorrect; this is the wavelength for red light.
-   **B: infrared = 1.0 x 10⁻⁴ m, red light = 7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m, violet light = 4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m**
    -   Infrared (1.0 x 10⁻⁴ m) is longer than red light, which is correct.
    -   Red light (7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m) is correct for the longer end of the visible spectrum.
    -   Violet light (4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m) is correct for the shorter end of the visible spectrum.
    This option is consistent with the known electromagnetic spectrum.
-   **C: infrared = 1.0 x 10⁻⁷ m, red light = 4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m, violet light = 7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m**
    -   Infrared (1.0 x 10⁻⁷ m) is shorter than red light, which is incorrect.
-   **D: infrared = 1.0 x 10⁻⁹ m, red light = 7.0 x 10⁻⁷ m, violet light = 4.0 x 10⁻⁷ m**
    -   Infrared (1.0 x 10⁻⁹ m) is in the X-ray/gamma-ray region, which is incorrect.

Therefore, option B is the correct combination.

context_text: The diagram shows a light ray passing from 'air' into a 'glass block'. The refractive index of the glass block is given as 1.5. The angle between the incident light ray (in air) and the normal (a dashed line perpendicular to the surface) is 33°. This is the angle of incidence (i = 33°). The refracted ray is shown inside the glass block, bending towards the normal. The diagram is labeled 'NOT TO SCALE'. A table provides four options for the 'angle of refraction' and the 'critical angle' of the glass.
question_text: What is the angle of refraction in the glass and critical angle of the glass?
answer_text:
Given:
- Angle of incidence (i) = 33°
- Refractive index of air (n_air) ≈ 1.0
- Refractive index of glass (n_glass) = 1.5

**1. Calculate the critical angle (c) of the glass:**
The critical angle is defined by the formula sin(c) = n_lower / n_higher.
For light going from glass to air:
sin(c) = n_air / n_glass = 1.0 / 1.5 = 2/3 ≈ 0.6667.
c = arcsin(0.6667) ≈ 41.81°.
Rounding to the nearest degree, the critical angle is approximately 42°.

**2. Calculate the angle of refraction (r) in the glass:**
Using Snell's Law: n_air × sin(i) = n_glass × sin(r)
1.0 × sin(33°) = 1.5 × sin(r)
sin(r) = sin(33°) / 1.5
sin(33°) ≈ 0.5446
sin(r) = 0.5446 / 1.5 ≈ 0.3631
r = arcsin(0.3631) ≈ 21.30°.

Comparing these calculated values with the options:
- The calculated critical angle is approximately 42°, which matches the critical angle values in options A and C.
- The calculated angle of refraction is approximately 21.3°, which does not match any of the angle of refraction values provided in the options (34°, 38°).

Since the angle of refraction derived from Snell's law (21.3°) does not match the options, and the critical angle (42°) matches options A and C, there is an inconsistency in the question's provided values for the angle of refraction. However, if forced to choose an option that is 'most correct' based on a partial match, options A and C both correctly state the critical angle as 42°. Given the discrepancy in the angle of refraction, a definitive choice for both values is not possible based purely on the given numbers. Based on the options, and assuming the critical angle is consistently derived, the values would be 34° for angle of refraction and 42° for critical angle (Option A).

context_text: A student stands 210 m in front of a vertical, flat cliff. The student makes a short, loud sound by banging two pieces of wood. A timer records that the echo of the sound is heard 1.5 seconds after the sound was made.
question_text:
A student stands 210 m in front of a vertical, flat cliff and bangs together two pieces of wood to make a short, loud sound. A timer records the echo of the sound 1.5 seconds after the pieces of wood are banged together. Based on this result, what is the speed of sound?
A 140 m/s
B 280 m/s
C 320 m/s
D 630 m/s
answer_text:
Given:
- Distance from the student to the cliff (d) = 210 m.
- Time taken for the echo to be heard (t) = 1.5 s.

For an echo to be heard, the sound must travel from the source (student) to the reflector (cliff) and then back to the listener (student). Therefore, the total distance travelled by the sound is twice the distance to the cliff.
Total distance (D_total) = 2 × d = 2 × 210 m = 420 m.

The speed of sound (v) can be calculated using the formula: Speed = Distance / Time.
v = D_total / t = 420 m / 1.5 s.
v = 280 m/s.

Therefore, the speed of sound is 280 m/s.

context_text: The diagram shows a potential divider circuit. A voltage source is connected across a resistor X-Y. A sliding contact K is placed on the resistor X-Y. Lamp L1 is connected in parallel across the section K-Y of the resistor, and lamp L2 is connected in parallel across the section X-K. Initially, contact K is halfway between X and Y, and both lamps L1 and L2 are equally bright.
question_text: The contact K is halfway between X and Y and the lamps are equally bright. What will happen to the brightness of the lamps when contact K is moved a short distance towards X?
answer_text:
Initially, K is halfway between X and Y. Since the lamps L1 and L2 are identical and are equally bright, this confirms that the voltage across XK (V_XK) is equal to the voltage across KY (V_KY), and thus the resistance of section XK (R_XK) is equal to the resistance of section KY (R_KY).

When contact K is moved a short distance towards X:
1.  **Resistance of section XK (R_XK):** Moving K towards X makes the section XK shorter. Therefore, the resistance R_XK will **decrease**.
2.  **Resistance of section KY (R_KY):** Moving K towards X makes the section KY longer. Therefore, the resistance R_KY will **increase**.

In a potential divider circuit, the voltage across a section is proportional to its resistance. Since the total voltage across XY remains constant:
1.  **Voltage across L2 (V_XK):** As R_XK decreases, the voltage across section XK (and thus across lamp L2) will **decrease**.
2.  **Voltage across L1 (V_KY):** As R_KY increases, the voltage across section KY (and thus across lamp L1) will **increase**.

Since the brightness of a lamp depends on the power it dissipates (P = V²/R), and both lamps are identical, a higher voltage means a brighter lamp, and a lower voltage means a dimmer lamp.
- Lamp L1 (connected across KY) will become **brighter**.
- Lamp L2 (connected across XK) will become **dimmer**.

This matches option B, where L1 is brighter and L2 is dimmer.

context_text: An electrical household appliance uses 12 kWh of electrical energy over 4 hours of operation. The cost of one unit of electricity (1 kWh) is 26 cents. A table provides four options, each showing a combination of 'electrical power / kW' and 'cost / cents'.
question_text: An electrical household appliance uses 12 kWh of electrical energy after 4 hours of operation. If one unit of electricity costs 26 cents, what would be the electrical power of the appliance and the cost of energy usage?
answer_text:
Given:
- Electrical energy used (E) = 12 kWh
- Time of operation (t) = 4 hours
- Cost per unit of electricity (1 kWh) = 26 cents

**1. Calculate the electrical power (P) of the appliance:**
Power is defined as energy consumed per unit time:
P = E / t
P = 12 kWh / 4 hours = 3 kW.

**2. Calculate the cost of energy usage:**
The total energy used is 12 kWh, and 1 kWh is considered 'one unit'.
Total cost = (Energy used in kWh) × (Cost per kWh)
Total cost = 12 kWh × 26 cents/kWh = 312 cents.

Therefore, the electrical power of the appliance is 3 kW, and the cost of energy usage is 312 cents.

context_text: The diagram shows a straight wire, P, carrying current *into* the plane of the paper (indicated by an 'X' symbol within a circle). This wire produces circular magnetic field lines around it in a clockwise direction. The wire P is also placed within a 'uniform magnetic field' represented by parallel horizontal lines pointing to the right. Four points (A, B, C, D) are marked around wire P in this combined field: A is above P, B is to the right of P, C is below P, and D is to the left of P.
question_text: P represents one straight wire carrying current into the plane of the paper. This produces a circular magnetic field in the region around P. P is placed in a uniform magnetic field. At which point will the magnetic field be the strongest?
answer_text:
To find where the magnetic field is strongest, we need to consider the vector sum of the magnetic field due to the current-carrying wire (B_wire) and the uniform magnetic field (B_uniform) at each point.
1.  **Magnetic field due to wire P:** For a current flowing *into* the page (X), the magnetic field lines around the wire are clockwise, according to the right-hand grip rule.
    -   At point A (above P), B_wire is to the right.
    -   At point B (right of P), B_wire is downwards.
    -   At point C (below P), B_wire is to the left.
    -   At point D (left of P), B_wire is upwards.
2.  **Uniform magnetic field:** B_uniform is consistently to the right.

Now, let's combine the fields at each point:
-   **Point A:** B_wire (right) + B_uniform (right). Both fields are in the same direction, so they add up constructively, resulting in a stronger net magnetic field.
-   **Point B:** B_wire (down) + B_uniform (right). The fields are perpendicular, so they add vectorially (Pythagorean theorem), but not in a way that directly maximizes the magnitude compared to parallel addition.
-   **Point C:** B_wire (left) + B_uniform (right). The fields are in opposite directions, so they subtract (partially cancel out), resulting in a weaker net magnetic field.
-   **Point D:** B_wire (up) + B_uniform (right). The fields are perpendicular, similar to point B.

The magnetic field will be strongest where the two fields are in the same direction and thus add up. This occurs at point A.

context_text: The diagram shows a bar magnet oscillating vertically (moving up and down) above a coil of wire. The magnet is suspended by a spring, and its South (S) pole is at the top, and North (N) pole is at the bottom, facing the coil. The magnet oscillates between points P (above the N pole) and R (below the N pole), where P and R are the extreme points of its vertical motion. Point Q is explicitly marked at the position of the N pole, which is the midpoint of the oscillation (between P and R).
question_text:
The bottom of the magnet moves up and down between P and R. Where is the bottom of the magnet when there is no induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) in the coil?
A at P and at Q
B at P and at R
C at Q only
D at R only
answer_text:
According to Faraday's Law of electromagnetic induction, an electromotive force (e.m.f.) is induced in a coil only when there is a *change* in magnetic flux linkage through the coil. This change in flux linkage occurs when the magnet is moving relative to the coil.

In an oscillation, the moving object (the magnet in this case) momentarily stops and reverses its direction at the extreme points of its motion.
-   Points P and R are the extreme points of the magnet's vertical oscillation (the magnet moves up to P and down to R).
-   At these extreme positions (P and R), the magnet's instantaneous velocity is zero as it momentarily stops before reversing direction.
-   When the magnet's velocity is zero, the rate of change of magnetic flux linkage through the coil is momentarily zero, and therefore, no e.m.f. is induced.
-   Point Q is the midpoint of the oscillation where the magnet's speed (and thus the rate of change of flux linkage) is maximum, leading to maximum induced e.m.f., not zero.

Therefore, there is no induced e.m.f. in the coil when the bottom of the magnet is at points P and R.

context_text: No specific diagram or experimental setup is provided. The question describes a ball being dropped from the top of a 125 m tall building and asks for the time it takes to fall to the ground, with gravitational acceleration (g) given as 10 m/s².
question_text: A ball is dropped from the top of a 125 m tall building. What is the time it takes to fall to the ground? Take g to be 10 m/s². A 0.325 s B 1.25 s C 5.00 s D 10.00 s
answer_text: Since the ball is dropped, its initial velocity (u) is 0 m/s. The vertical displacement (s) is 125 m, and the acceleration due to gravity (g) is 10 m/s². We use the kinematic equation: s = ut + ½gt². Substituting the values: 125 = (0)(t) + ½(10)t² => 125 = 5t² => t² = 125/5 => t² = 25 => t = 5 s (since time cannot be negative). Therefore, the time it takes for the ball to fall to the ground is 5.00 s. The correct answer is C.

context_text: The diagram shows a pail containing two layers: water at the top and sand at the bottom. Point X is indicated as the center of gravity (CG) of the sand layer, located lower down in the pail. Point Z is indicated as the center of gravity of the water layer, located higher up than X. Point Y is a reference point located vertically between X and Z, which represents the initial overall center of gravity of the pail and its contents. The question states that more sand is added to the pail.
question_text: More sand is added to the pail. This affects the position of the centre of gravity of the pail and its contents, and the stability of the pail. Which of the following shows how the position of the centre of gravity of the pail and its contents, and the stability of the pail will be affected? A centre of gravity moves from X towards Y, stability decreases B centre of gravity moves from X towards Y, stability increases C centre of gravity moves from Y towards Z, stability decreases D centre of gravity moves from Y towards Z, stability increases
answer_text: Initially, the overall center of gravity (CG) of the pail and its contents is at point Y. When more sand is added to the pail, the sand layer at the bottom increases in volume and mass. This causes the center of gravity of the sand layer itself (X) to move upwards. Since sand is denser than water, the overall CG of the pail and its contents (Y) will shift towards the higher position of the increased sand mass. Therefore, the overall CG (Y) will move upwards, away from its initial position and towards Z (the CG of the water layer, which is above X). A higher center of gravity reduces the stability of an object. Thus, the center of gravity moves from Y towards Z, and the stability decreases. The correct answer is C.

context_text: The diagram shows three beakers, each containing a different liquid. The properties of each liquid are given: Liquid 1 has a mass of 100 g and a volume of 100 cm³. Liquid 2 has a mass of 50 g and a volume of 50 cm³. Liquid 3 has a mass of 100 g and a volume of 50 cm³.
question_text: Which statement about the densities of the liquids is correct? A Liquid 1 has twice the density of liquid 3. B Liquid 3 has twice the density of liquid 1. C The liquids all have different densities. D The liquids all have the same density.
answer_text: To compare the densities, we calculate the density (mass/volume) for each liquid: Density of Liquid 1 (ρ1) = 100 g / 100 cm³ = 1 g/cm³. Density of Liquid 2 (ρ2) = 50 g / 50 cm³ = 1 g/cm³. Density of Liquid 3 (ρ3) = 100 g / 50 cm³ = 2 g/cm³. Comparing these values: ρ1 = 1 g/cm³, ρ2 = 1 g/cm³, and ρ3 = 2 g/cm³. We can see that ρ1 = ρ2, and ρ3 = 2 * ρ1. Therefore, Liquid 3 has twice the density of Liquid 1. The correct statement is B.

context_text: The diagram depicts a U-tube manometer filled with water. One arm of the U-tube is connected to a gas pipe, and the other arm is open to the atmosphere. A vertical scale in millimeters (mm) is shown alongside the open arm. The water level in the arm open to the atmosphere is at the 0 mm mark. The water level in the arm connected to the gas pipe is at the 52 mm mark. This indicates a height difference (h) of 52 mm (0.052 m) between the two water levels. The density of water (ρ) is given as 1000 kg m⁻³, and the gravitational field strength (g) is 10 N kg⁻¹.
question_text: Find the pressure of the gas supply in Pa. A 380 Pa B 380 Pa above atmospheric pressure C 520 Pa D 520 Pa above atmospheric pressure
answer_text: The pressure difference (ΔP) across the manometer is calculated using the formula ΔP = hρg. The height difference (h) between the two water levels is 52 mm, which is 0.052 m. The density of water (ρ) is 1000 kg m⁻³, and the gravitational field strength (g) is 10 N kg⁻¹. Substituting these values: ΔP = 0.052 m * 1000 kg/m³ * 10 N/kg = 520 Pa. The options specify whether this pressure is above or below atmospheric pressure. Although the visual diagram shows the water level higher in the gas pipe arm, suggesting the gas pressure is lower than atmospheric pressure, the provided correct answer for this question is D. Therefore, assuming the question intends for the gas pressure to be higher than atmospheric pressure for a pressure difference of 520 Pa, the answer is 520 Pa above atmospheric pressure (Option D).

context_text: The diagram illustrates a hydraulic pump system, comprising two connected cylinders of different cross-sectional areas, filled with an incompressible liquid. A smaller piston, labeled 'piston P', is on the left, with a downward force 'F' applied to it. A larger piston, labeled 'piston Q', is on the right, supporting a 'load'. The liquid levels under both pistons are shown to be equal. Piston P has a smaller surface area than piston Q.
question_text: Which of the following comparison is true? A The force F is the same as the weight of the load. B The force F is greater than the weight of the load. C The pressure on piston P is the same as the pressure on piston Q. D The pressure on piston P is smaller than the pressure on piston Q.
answer_text: According to Pascal's principle, an external pressure applied to an enclosed fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid. Therefore, the pressure exerted by piston P on the liquid is transmitted equally to all parts of the liquid, including under piston Q. This means the pressure on piston P is the same as the pressure on piston Q. Thus, statement C is true. Since Pressure (P) = Force (F) / Area (A), and the area of piston Q is larger than that of piston P (A_Q > A_P), a smaller force F on piston P can generate a larger force on piston Q (Force_Q = P * A_Q) to lift the load. Therefore, force F is smaller than the weight of the load, making options A and B incorrect. Option D is incorrect because the pressure is equal throughout the enclosed fluid.

context_text: The experiment aims to deduce the path taken by a light ray undergoing total internal reflection in a glass block. The materials provided are an A4 Plain Paper, a Cork mat, five optical pins (P1, P2, P3, P4), a rectangular glass block, a Protractor, a 30.0 cm ruler, and a Set square. The procedure involves placing the glass block on paper, tracing its outline and labeling corners ABCD. A normal is drawn at point M, located 1.0 cm from corner B on side AB. An incident ray (P1, P2) is constructed using a protractor at an angle of incidence 'i' of 30° to this normal. The block is replaced, and pins P1 and P2 are placed along the incident ray. The user observes two reflected images of P1 and P2 appear at side BD when looking through side CD of the block. Pins P3 and P4 are then placed in line with these reflected images, such that all four pins (P1, P2, P3, P4) appear to be one behind the other when viewed through the block.
